summary: 01/02/2000: Police defused a pentonite bomb in downtown Bogota, Colombia before it detonated. The bomb was near a hardware store in a busy pedestrian area. The perpetrators of this incident were unknown.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bomb consisted of 1 kg of pentonite in a cardboard box.
scite1: “Bogota Police Defuse Powerful 'Pentonite' Bomb,” EFE, January 2, 2000.

summary: 01/02/2000: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) dynamited nine electric towers in the Antioquia department, Colombia. Many communities in the area were without electricity for an extended period of time.
target1: Nine electricity towers within the department of Antioquia, Colombia
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: FARC used dynamite in the attack
scite1: “FARC Bombs Another Nine Towers In Antioquia,” Radio Cadena Nacional WWW-Text, January 2, 2000.

summary: 01/04/2000: The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) headquarters in Bogota, Colombia was attacked and forty people were taken hostage. The 100 unidentified perpetrators demanded that the government and the ICRC find them new homes. The hostage-takers had left their homes during the Colombian government's war with local rebel groups. There is no information on what happened to the hostages, but the ICRC suspended operations in the country following this attack.
corp1: International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC)
motive: The perpetrators wanted the government and the ICRC to find them new homes.
weapdetail: Sticks were used in this attack.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

location: The helicopter was approaching Puerto Rico when it was attacked.
summary: 01/07/2000: Suspected members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) attacked with rifle fire a Counternarcotics Police helicopter on an operation that had destroyed two cocaine complexes. The attack took place near the town of Puerto Rico.
target1: A counternarcotics police helicopter near Puerto Rico
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Suspected FARC Rebels Attack Narcotics Police Helicopter,” Agence France Presse to Mexico Central America and the Caribbean, January 7, 2000.

summary: 01/09/2000: In Colombia, police defused an 8-kg bomb, placed at the base of a flag pole in a south Bogota park. While no one claimed responsibility for planting the bomb, Ejercito de Liberación Nacional (ELN – Army of National Liberation) was suspected.
targsubtype1_txt: Public Area (garden, parking lot, garage, beach, public building, camp)
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: An 8-kg bomb was defused
scite1: “Dijin Report 8-kg Bomb Defused in Bogota,” EFE, January 9, 2000.

summary: 01/12/2000: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) rebels attacked the police station in Puerres, Narino Department, as well as some banks and government facilities with rockets and gas tanks. Several people died.
target3: Government buildings in Puerra
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Numerous facilities were attacked and damaged.
scite1: “FARC Launch Attacks in Narino; 24 People Reported Dead,” Emisoras Caracol Network WWW, January 12, 2000.

summary: 01/12/2000: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) rebels attacked the police station in Cordoba, Narino Department, as well as some banks and government facilities with rockets and gas tanks.
target3: Government buildings in Cordoba
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Numerous facilities were attacked and damaged.
scite1: “FARC Launch Attacks in Narino; 24 People Reported Dead,” Emisoras Caracol Network WWW, January 12, 2000.

summary: 01/12/2000: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) rebels attacked the police station in Potosi, Narino Department, as well as some banks and government facilities with rockets, gas tanks, and rifles. At least two policemen were injured and two were kidnapped.
target3: Government buildings in Potosi
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Numerous facilities were attacked and damaged.
scite1: “FARC Launch Attacks in Narino; 24 People Reported Dead,” Emisoras Caracol Network WWW, January 12, 2000.

summary: 01/17/2000: A car bomb exploded outside the National Police club in Anapoima. One civilian was injured and significant damage was caused to surrounding buildings. The perpetrators of this attack were unknown.
target1: The National Police club in Anapoima
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A car bomb was parked in front of the club
propcomment: Surrounding buildings were seriously damaged
scite1: “Car-Bomb Explodes Outside Police Club in Anapoima,” NOTIMEX, January 17, 2000.

summary: 01/17/2000: Ejercito de Liberación Nacional (ELN – Army of National Liberation) bombed 21 power towers and power lines in the Antioquia department belonging to Public Enterprises of Medellin and Electrical Inter-Connection, Inc., ISA causing millions to be without power. ELN was protesting the nationalization of one of the power companies and hoped to pressure the government to establish a demilitarized zone for negotiations.
target1: Power towers and power lines belonging to Public Enterprises of Medellin
target2: Power towers and power lines belonging to Electrical Inter-Connection, Inc., ISA
motive: ELN was protesting the nationalization of one of the power companies and hoped to pressure the government to establish a demilitarized zone for negotiations.
propcomment: Twenty-one power towers and power lines were exploded
scite1: “ELN Attacks Energy Sector To Pressure Government,” Cambio (Internet version), January 24, 2000.

summary: 01/18/2000: One girl died and six were injured when two grenades exploded in a Bogota school. Authorities suspected Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) involvement.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Terrorist Attack in Bogota Leaves One Dead, Six Injured,” Agence France Presse to Mexico Central America and the Caribbean, January 19, 2000.

summary: 01/21/2000: A bomb exploded outside the Ecuadorian Banking Superintendency (SBE) in Quito. No one was injured, but the SBE building was slightly damaged with broken windows. Ecuadorian Indians were violently protesting nearby at the time of the explosion, but there was no claim of responsiblity.
target1: The Ecuadorian Banking Superintendency (SBE) building in Quito
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The windows of the building were shattered
scite1: “Bomb Explodes Outside Banking Superintendency in Quito,” Agence France Presse to Mexico Central America and the Caribbean, January 21, 2000.

summary: 01/23/2000: The headquarters of the National Republic Association, or the Colorado Party (ANR), Colorado Reconciliation Movement (MRC) in Asuncion, Paraguay, was attacked with a homemade explosive device. Damage was caused to the walls, ceiling, and doors within 23 feet.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
target1: The headquarters of the National Republic Association, or the Colorado Party (ANR), Colorado Reconciliation Movement (MRC)
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A home-made device was used
propcomment: Windows were broken and the office was damaged in the blast
scite1: “Police Investigating Explosion at MRC Headquarters,” ABC Color (Internet version), January 24, 2000.
scite2: “Minister Blames Explosion on 'Oviedo, the Assassin',” Agence France Presse to Mexico Central America and the Caribbean, January 23, 2000.

summary: 01/26/2000: Three perpetrators with unknown affiliations were captured just after they threw a grenade at a police post in Bogota. The explosion caused property damage to the police post and broke the windows of a passing car, though no one was injured.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The police station was damaged and the windows of a passing car were shattered
scite1: “Terrorist Grenade Damages Bogota Police Post,” EFE, January 27, 2000.

location: The highway between Bucaramanga and Santa Marta
summary: 1/28/2000: Members of the Popular Liberation Army (EPL) took 19 people hostage at a roadblock in the province of Santander, Colombia.  11 of the 19 hostages were released on January 29, 2000, when the military began to close in on the rebels and their hostages.
target1: Civilians stopped at a roadblock in northeastern Colombia
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: No mention of weapons was made
scite1: "Columbia - kidnapping ELP releases 11 of 19 hostages," EFE News Service, January 29, 2000.

location: The village of Santa Cecilia, in Cesar province
summary: 1/27/2000: Approximately 40 members of the right-wing United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) attacked the village of Santa Cecilia, in Cesar province, Colombia.  They occupied the town for 12 hours, executing 11 villagers who were believed to be leftists or rebel sympathizers.  They abducted an additional two villagers.
target1: Villagers from Santa Cecilia who were believed to be leftists or rebel sympathizers
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: The purpose of the attack was to kill suspected leftists and sympathizers, in order to gain the upper hand in the struggle to control certain geographical areas.
addnotes: Sources state the incident happened on different days
scite1: "Eleven killed in death squad attack on Colombian village," Deutsche Presse-Agentur, January 29, 2000.
scite2: "Colombia - Massacre paramilitary group kills nearly a dozen people," EFE News Service, January 28, 2000.
scite3: "Paramilitary gang kills at least 11 Colombians," Reuters, January 28, 2000.

summary: 01/29/2000: A section of the Cano-Limon pipeline in Arauquita, Colombia was bombed, causing major damage and suspending oil production for three days. The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) and the National Liberation Army (NLA) were suspected in the attack.
target1: A section of the Cano-Limon Pipeline in Arauquita, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The explosion caused major damage and a suspension in oil production.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

location: A reserve for vicuna in the central Andes, 275 miles southeast of Lima
summary: 2/1/2000: Masked assailants shot three park rangers in a reserve for vicuna in the central Andes, Peru.  The rangers had their hands bound and were shot with a single bullet to the head, a trademark of the rebel group Shining Path.
targsubtype1_txt: Public Area (garden, parking lot, garage, beach, public building, camp)
target1: Park rangers in a vicuna reserve in the central Andes
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A single bullet to the head
scite1: "Suspected Peru rebels kill park rangers during wave of attacks," Associated Press, February 2, 2000.
scite2: "World," St. Louis Patch-Dispatch, February 3, 2000.
scite3: "China indignation expressed over U.S. passage of Taiwan bill," Seattle Post-Intelligencer, February 3, 2000.

summary: 02/03/2000: A section of the Cano-Limon pipeline in the Putumayo Department of Colombia was bombed, causing major damage and suspending oil production for three days. The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) and the National Liberation Army (NLA) were suspected in the attack.
target1: A section of the Cano-Limon Pipeline in Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The explosion caused major damage and a suspension in oil production.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

location: In the downtown commercial district
summary: 2/4/2000: A car exploded in front of the Guirama hotel in Puerto Asis, Colombia.  The car was holding approximately 40 kilograms of dynamite.  Two people were killed, including a 6 year old boy, and at least four were injured in the explosion.  The hotel was destroyed and several surrounding buildings were damaged.  Authorities believe that the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) are responsible for the attack.  Source speculate that the attack may have been in protest of government attempts to destroy coca  crops.
target1: Civilians in the vicinity of Guirama hotel in Puerto Asis
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but sources speculate that the attack was in protest of the Colombian government attempts to destroy coca crops
weapdetail: Approximately 40 kilograms of dynamite
propcomment: One hotel was destroyed, several businesses were damaged, and one car exploded
addnotes: Two sources state that four people were injured; one states that ten people were injured.
scite1: "Columbia - terrorism two killed, four wounded in car-bomb attack in border town," EFE News Service, February 4, 2000.
scite2: "Car bomb kills two in Colombia," Xinhua News Agency, February 4, 2000.
scite3: "Fourteen killed in Colombian attacks," Reuters, February 4, 2000.

summary: 02/08/2000: A bomb exploded along the Canadian-British-Colombian-run ONCESA oil pipeline in Campo Hermoso, Colombia, causing damage, an oil spill and a forest fire. The National Liberation Army (NLA) was suspected, but no one claimed for the attack.
target1: ONCESA pipeline in Campo Hermoso, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The explosion caused major damage, an oil spill and a forest fire.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

location: Guayaquil city, Ecuador
summary: 2/16/2000: A small bomb hidden in a video tape was sent to Telecentro television network in Guayaquil city, Ecuador.  It exploded, slightly wounding the network's news editor, Rafael Cuesta.  The network had received warnings from a group calling itself National Liberation Army (Ecuador); the group warned the network to change its pro-governmental perspective.  Authorities believe that the group may be responsible for the bombing, however the People's Combatant Group (GCP) also claimed responsibility.
target1: Telecentro television network and journalist Rafael Cuesta in Guayaquil
motive: Authorities believe the attack was motivated by the pro-governmental perspective utilized by the television network
weapdetail: A bomb hidden in a video cassette that was sent in a package
scite1: Fernando Arroyo, "Ecuador - guerillas Ecuadorians fear bomb attack may herald new leftist rebel group," EFE News Service, February 17, 2000.
scite2: "Ecuador - bomb waves of letter bombs sows panic in troubled Ecuador," EFE News Service, February 23, 2000.

location: The construction site for a new police barracks in Dagua, southwest of Colombia
summary: 2/17/2000:  Several hooded men dressed in military clothes placed 50 kilograms of dynamite at a construction site for a new police barracks in Dagua, Colombia.  The bomb exploded, killing one construction worker and wounding another. Part of the construction site was destroyed and the surrounding buildings were damaged.  Authorities blamed the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) for the attack.
target1: A police barracks under construction in Dagua
target2: Construction workers at a construction site for a police barracks
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: 50 kilograms of dynamite
propcomment: Part of a construction site was destroyed and several buildings were damaged
scite1: "Columbia - terrorism one dead and one injured In bombing of Columbian police station," EFE News Service, February 17, 2000.
scite2: "Bomb attack kills one in Colombian southwest," Xinhua News Agency, February 17, 2000.
scite3: "One person killed, heavy damage reported in alleged rebel operations," Caracol TV, February 19, 2000.

summary: 02/18/2000: About 100 members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) attacked the city of Mitu, Colombia, with exploding gas tanks. The FARC focused its attack on the police station, which was operating in the former governor's house. Two people were injured in the attack.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The FARC used 100-pound and 20-pound propane gas tanks mortars, launched with a lighted fuse system.
propcomment: Five homes were destroyed and the police station was damaged.
addnotes: FARC was attempting to takeover the town, but was repelled.  The fighting lasted over 10 hours.
scite1: "Fighting in Mitu, Tulua, Convencion,” El Tiempo, February 20, 2000.
scite2: "Fighting during attempted takeover of Mitu,” Caracol, February 21, 2000.

summary: 02/18/2000: 200 United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia (AUC) members killed 15 peasants thought to be helping guerillas in Ovejas, Colombia. The attackers also kidnapped an undetermined number of peasants in the same rural area. The attackers acted under the orders of Carlos Castano, one of the founding members of the AUC.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Revenge against peasants helpful to guerillas
weapdetail: Rifles were used but apparently never shot.  The victims were beheaded, but the weapons used was not reported.
propcomment: Three houses were burned.
addnotes: Reports of kidnapping as part of this incident are unclear. There are no reports as to what happened to the kidnapped victims.
scite1: "Paramilitary group kills 15 peasants in Overjas, Sucre,” Caracol, February 18, 2000.
scite2: Ricardo Maldonado, “Colombia town scarred by massacre,” Associated Press Online, February 21, 2000.

summary: 02/20/2000: Members of the Ejercito de Liberación Nacional (ELN) dynamited a stretch of Colombia's main oil pipeline in Norte de Santander Department, sparking a clash with the army which left two soldiers and seven rebels dead.
target1: Cano Limon-Covenas Pipeline in Norte de Santander
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Dynamite was used to blow up the pipeline and unknown types of firearms were used by the perpetrators during the clashes thereafter.
propcomment: The Cano Limon-Covenas was badly damaged in the incident.
addnotes: Reports stated that this pipeline was target of over 700 attacks since its inauguration in 1986.
scite1: "Two soldiers, seven rebels dead in Norte de Santander,” Radio Cadena Nacional, February 20, 2000.
scite2: "Fighting in Colombia kills 9 people,” Xinhua General News Service, February 20, 2000.

location: El Salado village
summary: 2/16/2000: 200 members of an ultra-right wing death squad raided and occupied the village of El Salado in Colombia from February 16, 2000 through to Feb 19, 2000.  The assailants danced and drank while they tortured and beheaded at least 28 villagers.  Most of the villagers were killed on a table set up on a basketball court but at least one was killed in the village church.  The assailants were searching for suspected communist sympathizers.
motive: The assailants were looking for suspected communist sympathizers
weapdetail: The victims were tortured and beheaded, but no mention of specific weapons were made
scite1: "Colombia death squad said to dance during torture," Reuters, February 23, 2000.
scite2: "Colombia rebels, paramilitaries clash, 20 said dead," Reuters, February 20, 2000.
scite3: "Death squad kills 28," The Daily Telegraph, February 25, 2000.

summary: 02/21/2000: The People's Combatants’ Group (Grupo de Combatientes Populares – GCP) claimed responsibility for sending a bomb hidden within a videocassette to indigenous rights leader Marcos Murillo, in Guayaquil, Ecuador. The bomb was found and defused by police before causing any damage.
target1: Marcos Murillo, leader of the Evangelical Indians of Ecuador
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bomb used in this incident was hidden within a videocassette that was sent to the target's address.
addnotes: The target was suspicious of the videocassette, so they called the Police Intervention and Rescue Team (GIR) who defused it.
scite1: "Indian religious leader sent videocassette bomb,” CRE Satellite Radio, February 22, 2000.
scite2: "Government Promises Crackdown on New Wave of Terrorism,” World Markets Analysis, February 24, 2000.
scite3: Gonzalo Solano, “Ecuador president and defense minister disagree about mail bomb,” Associated Press Worldstream, February 23, 2000.

location: The incident occurred in the Naranjal area of Independencia neighborhood
summary: 02/21/2000: The Shining Path (Sendero Luminoso) was blamed for killing one and injuring six during a rebel attack against Naranjal, Peru. Police sources reported the action as an attempt to boycott the upcoming elections. The police later arrested one of the alleged attackers in the San Francisco District, located two km away from Naranjal.
motive: Police sources reported the action as an attempt to boycott the upcoming elections.
weapdetail: Two grenades were thrown at the victims in the incident.
addnotes: The Peruvian Police stated that the person killed was 35-year-old Victor Contreras Atauqui and that several of the wounded, including a nine-year-old girl, had been maimed and were transferred to the hospital in Huamanga.
scite1: "Shining Path action leaves one dead, six injured,” NOTIMEX, February 21, 2000.

summary: 02/22/2000: In a series of related incidents, the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) was suspected of setting fire to three buses in three different areas of Bogota, Colombia. No passengers were hurt, but one driver suffered third degree burns as a result of the incident.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The specific method used in this incident to set fire to the buses was not reported.
propcomment: Two buses were damaged and one was destroyed in these three incidents.
scite1: "Itar-Tass world news digest of Wednesday, February 23,” ITAR-TASS, February 23, 2000.
scite2: "Buses set alight in Bogota in ‘wave of terrorist attacks’,” RCN Radio, February 23, 2000.

summary: 02/22/2000: In a series of related incidents, the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) was suspected of setting fire to three buses in three different areas of Bogota, Colombia.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The specific method used in this incident to set fire to the buses was not reported.
propcomment: Two buses were damaged and one was destroyed in these three incidents.
scite1: "Itar-Tass world news digest of Wednesday, February 23,” ITAR-TASS, February 23, 2000.
scite2: "Buses set alight in Bogota in ‘wave of terrorist attacks’,” RCN Radio, February 23, 2000.

summary: 02/22/2000: In a series of related incidents, the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) was suspected of setting fire to three buses in three different areas of Bogota, Colombia.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The specific method used in this incident to set fire to the buses was not reported.
propcomment: Two buses were damaged and one was destroyed in these three incidents.
scite1: "Itar-Tass world news digest of Wednesday, February 23,” ITAR-TASS, February 23, 2000.
scite2: "Buses set alight in Bogota in ‘wave of terrorist attacks’,” RCN Radio, February 23, 2000.

summary: 02/24/2000: Unknown urban rebels were believed responsible for bombing the Las Villas bank, at the intersection of 92A and 82nd Street in Bogota, Colombia. The bank was totally destroyed and shrapnel struck several people in the incident. This was one of six bank bombings in Bogota that causing 13 injuries and major damage on 02/24/2000.
target1: Las Villas Bank at the intersection of 92A and 82nd Street in Bogota
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Up to 4 kg of dynamite was used in the incident.
propcomment: The bank was totally destroyed and surrounding buildings were damaged in the incident.
scite1: "Five terrorist bombs rock Bogota,” Santa Fe de Bogota Radionet, February 24, 2000.
scite2: "Urban militias blamed for bomb attacks on six banks in Bogota,” BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, February 28, 2000.
scite3: "Bombs in 4 Bogota banks injure 13,” Agence France Presse, February 25, 2000.

The bank was totally destroyed and shrapnel struck several people in the incident. This was one of six bank bombings in Bogota that causing 13 injuries and major damage on 02/24/2000.

motive: Unknown

summary: 02/24/2000: Unknown urban rebels were believed responsible for bombing the Granhorrar bank on 24th Avenue and 58th Street, in the Siete de Agosto district, Bogota, Colombia. This was one of six bank bombings in Bogota that causing 13 injuries and major damage on 02/24/2000.
target1: Granhorrar Bank on 24th Avenue and 58th Street in the Siete de Agosto district, Bogota

location: The incident occurred in the Siete de Agosto neighborhood
summary: 02/24/2000: Unknown urban rebels were believed responsible for bombing the Bancafe bank on 58th Street and 13th Avenue in the Chapinero district of Bogota, Colombia. This was one of six bank bombings in Bogota that causing 13 injuries and major damage on 02/24/2000.

motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Up to 4 kg of dynamite was used in the incident.

scite3: "Bombs in 4 Bogota banks injure 13,” Agence France Presse, February 25, 2000.

location: In the Yondo region, 380 kilometers north of Bogota
summary: 3/5/2000: Approximately 100 members of the right-wing United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) attacked the village of San Miguel del Tigre in the Yondo region, Columbia.  Six villagers were killed after being dragged from their homes.  Two more villagers were abducted, but authorities believed they were also killed and their bodies were thrown in the river.  The gunmen stated that the victims were selected because they were believed to be collaborating with Marxist guerrillas.
target1: Civilians in the Yondo region who were believed to be collaborating with Marxist guerrillas
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: The attackers accused the victims of collaborating with guerrillas
propcomment: The assailants "destroyed most of a village"
addnotes: It is unclear what happened to the two kidnapped villagers; authorities believe they were killed.
scite1: "16 die in new political violence in Colombia," Reuters, March 5, 2000.
scite2: "At least 30 die in clashes between Colombian paramilitaries, guerrillas," Agence France-Presse, March 6, 2000.
scite3: Yadira Ferrer, "Columbia: Paramilitaries lash out to gain role in peace talks," Inter Press Service, March 7, 2000.

summary: 03/09/2000: The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) attacked the city of El Bordo, Colombia. During the attack they raided a local prison, releasing 100 prisoners, and damaged various buildings in the area.
motive: To raid El Bordo Jail.
addnotes: The raid on the El Bordo Prison was the largest of its kind in nearly two years. Reports did not indicate how many of the escaped prisoners were FARC rebels. In addition to the prison attack the rebels looted the government-run Farmers' Bank and made off with an unspecified amount of money.
scite1: “Colombian guerrillas attack penitentiary, set free 100 colleagues,” Agence France Presse,  March 9, 2000.
scite2: “Colombian Guerrillas Storm Jail, Set 92 Free,” Washington Post, March 9, 2000.

summary: 03/14/2000: The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) attacked Medellin's fourth brigade military headquarters facility, they killed two soldiers and injured ten others. The area sustained extensive damage.
target1: Fourth Brigade Headquarters in Medellin, Colombia
motive: To attack the Medellin Fourth Brigade.
propcomment: Forty-five buildings were damaged in the attack. A total of 12 large buildings were destroyed completely, and 12 vehicles were also destroyed by the explosion of various cooking gas tanks that were hurled by militants at the Fourth Brigade Building.
scite1: “Explosion Leaves 2 Dead, 10 Injured in Medellin,” Santa Fe de Bogotá Radionet, March 14, 2000.
scite2: “FARC Blamed for Attack on Medellin Military Brigade,” Agence France Presse, March 14, 2000.

summary: 03/15/2000: General Carlos Mendez, Commander of the Colombia Military Third Division, was wounded during an attack by the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC). The attack occurred in Cali, Colombia will Mendez was inspecting the Alto Anchicaya Dam.
motive: To attack General Carlos Mendez.
scite1: “General Wounded During FARC Ambush,” Santa Fe de Bogotá Caracol Television, March 15, 2000.

summary: 03/17/2000: A bus carrying civilian recruits for the Colombian military was attacked by the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) in Silvania, Colombia. Two soldiers were killed and four others injured. Several vehicles were also damaged in the attack.
motive: To attack of civilian recruits.
propcomment: Bus heavily damaged
addnotes: The explosive was activated via an electric device apparently by members of FARC's 42nd Front.
scite1: “FARC Attacks Military Convoy, Tapias Reacts,” Santa Fe de Bogotá Caracol, March 17, 2000.

summary: 03/22/2000: In a series of related attacks, the National Liberation Army (NLA) attacked an electricity tower in a rural zone of San Juan de Rio Seco, Colombia. There were no casualties however the tower was severely damaged from the attack.
target1: Electricity tower in San Juan de Rio Seco, Colombia
motive: To jumpstart peace talks.
propcomment: Extensive damage to power transmission tower
addnotes: This was one of two related attacks (cf. 200003220002-03). The ELN launched the attack in regard to its demands for a change in peace talks. The attack knocked out power to much of Bogotá.
scite1: “Rebels cut power in Bogotá, demand place in peace talks: Presidential palace has no electricity, but rebels hope Pastrana will use the phone, which works,” The Standard, March 22, 2000.
scite2: “Colombian Rebel ELN Destroys Two Electricity Towers,” Xinhua News Agency, March 22, 2000.

summary: 03/22/2000: In a series of related attacks, the National Liberation Army (NLA) attacked an electricity tower in Matnzas, Colombia. There were no casualties however the tower was severely damaged from the attack.
motive: To jumpstart peace talks.
propcomment: Extensive damage to power transmission tower
addnotes: This was one of two related attacks (cf. 200003220002-03). The ELN launched the attack in regard to its demands for a change in peace talks. The attack knocked out power to much of Bogotá.
scite1: “Rebels cut power in Bogota, demand place in peace talks: Presidential palace has no electricity, but rebels hope Pastrana will use the phone, which works,” The Standard, March 22, 2000.
scite2: “Colombian Rebel ELN Destroys Two Electricity Towers,” Xinhua News Agency, March 22, 2000.

location: Unknown
summary: 3/22/2000: Approximately 3,200 Terena Indians took two hostages, historian Rogerio Alves de Resende and press officer Geraldo Duarte, and held them for three days in Brazil.  The Indians took the hostages after they were told that they were entitled to a much smaller land mass than they claimed they were entitled.  The Terena tribe demanded to meet with Federal Indian Bureau president Carlos Frederico Mares de Souza Filho and released the hostages after Souza Filho agreed to reevaluate the tribal land claims.  The hostages were not hurt.
target1: Rogerio Alves Rezende, a Federal Indian Bureau historian, and Geraldo Duarte Ferreira, an agency press secretary
motive: The captors wanted to negotiate land claims
weapdetail: No mention of weapons was made
addnotes: One source states that the hostages were held for three days while another source states they were held for two days
scite1: "Oscar award," Express and Echo, March 24, 2000.
scite2: "Brazil - Indians Brazilian Indians release hostages, " EFE News Service, March 26, 2000
scite3: "Brazilian Indians release hostages after compromise," Associated Press, March 26, 2000.

summary: 03/26/2000: The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) attacked Vigia del Fuerte, Colombia, killing 29, including the Mayor, Pastor Daniel Perea Santa and his family. The perpetrators also destroyed multiple buildings in the attack.
target1: Citizens and property in Vigia del Fuerte
target2: Mayor of Vigia del Fuerte, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Extensive damage to the town included the police barracks, the mayor's office, the telephone company and a cluster of simple wooden homes near the town plaza
addnotes: Most of the slain civilians died when stray bullets tore through their homes, but the Mayor was reportedly targeted directly and shot to death by the rebels. Officials said eight of the officers were executed at close range, presumably after having surrendered, and that rebels hacked the dead police with machetes and burned some of their corpses.
scite1: “Colombian Rebel Offensive Claims 19 Lives”, Santa Fe de Bogotá Radio Cadena Nacional, March 27, 2000.
scite2: “United Nations condemns ''cruel'' rebel attack,” Associated Press, March 28, 2000.
scite3: “Rebels kill at least 24 in Bogotá,” Contra Costa Times, March 28, 2000.

summary: 03/26/2000: A remote controlled car bomb was detonated at a market in Giradot, Colombia. The car was left in a parking lot outside the market, a short distance from a small police precinct that provided protection to the commercial area. One police cadet was killed in the attack and 30 civilians were injured. Tens of cars were destroyed, and stores, bank branches, and other buildings near the site had their windows shattered and walls destroyed. The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) was suspected.
target1: Civilians in a marketplace in Giradot, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Tens of cars were destroyed, and stores, bank branches, and other buildings located near the site had their windows shattered and walls destroyed.
addnotes: At the time of the attack Girardot was a popular tourist spot.
scite1: “Car Bomb Kills 1, Injures 24 in Colombian Town,” Paris AFP, March 26, 2000.
scite2: “Colombia One Dead, 30 Injured in Remote Car Bombing,” The Miami Herald, March 27, 2000.
scite3: Baena, Javier, “Fierce rebel attacks kill at least 30 in Colombia,” Associated Press, March 27, 2000.

summary: 03/30/2000: A car bomb exploded near the mayor's office in the central square in Cachipay, Colombia, killing four and injuring 14 others. The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) were blamed for the attack.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Two Killed by Car-Bomb Explosion in Cundinamarca,” Santa Fe de Bogotá Radio Cadena Nacional, March 30, 2000.
scite2: “Car Bomb in Colombia Kills Four”, Xinhua General News Service, March 30, 2000.
scite3: “Car-bomb explodes in Colombia, killing two,” Agence France Presse, March 30, 2000.

summary: 04/00/2000: A five-year old American citizen was kidnapped in Colombia by the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC). The Colombian police rescued the hostage in October 2000.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

location: Along a highway that links northern Cesar with the Caribbean coast
summary: 4/3/2000: Members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) set up a roadblock for two days along a highway that links northern Cesar with the Caribbean coast, in Colombia.  Calling it an "armed strike", the ELN then kidnapped 23 motorists and burned at least ten vehicles.  Antonio Garcia, the ELN's second-in-command, stated that ELN would continue similar activities unless a national convention was called in order to address the country's problems.
target1: Motorists and vehicles on a highway in Cesar Department
motive: The attackers were demanding a national convention to discuss the country's problems
weapdetail: Ten vehicles were torched and the assailants were "armed"
propcomment: Ten vehicles were torched
scite1: "Colombia rebels block four highways, kidnap 23," Reuters, April 3, 2000.
scite2: "Columbia - peace (scheduled) Columbian ELN rebels to press on with offensive," EFE News Service, April 4, 2000.
scite3: "18 Colombian rebels killed amid leftist armed strike," Dow Jones International News, April 5, 2000.

location: Along the main road between Bogota and Medellin
summary: 4/3/2000:  Members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) blew up two bridges located along the road between Bogota and Medellin, Colombia.  The attack was part of an "armed strike".  Antonio Garcia, the ELN's second-in-command, stated that ELN would continue similar activities unless a national convention was called in order to address the country's problems.
target1: Two bridges along the highway between Bogota and Medellin
motive: The attackers were demanding a national convention to discuss the country's problems
propcomment: Two bridges were blown up
scite1: "Colombia rebels block four highways, kidnap 23," Reuters, April 3, 2000.
scite2: "Columbia - peace (scheduled) Columbian ELN rebels to press on with offensive," EFE News Service, April 4, 2000.
scite3: "18 Colombian rebels killed amid leftist armed strike," Dow Jones International News, April 5, 2000.

location: Two barrios of Tibu, near the Venezuelan border
summary: 4/6/2000: Nine suspected paramilitary fighters dressed in camouflage attacked two burrios of Tibu, Colombia.  The gunmen dragged villagers from their home and executed them.  21 villagers were killed in the attack and five were seriously wounded.  It is believed that the villagers were killed because the assailants suspected them of collaborating with leftist guerrillas.
target1: Civilians in two burrios in Tibu
motive: Specific motive is unknown but sources speculate the attackers believed the victims were collaborating with leftist guerrillas
scite1: "21 killed in colombian town massacre; rebels suspected," Dow Jones International News, April 6, 2000.
scite2: "Political & civil unrest - Columbia," Lloyd's Information Casualty Report, April 8, 2000.

location: This incident occurred on a bridge between Anori and Amalfi.
summary: 04/11/2000: The National Liberation Army (NLA) destroyed a bridge and burned three vehicles between Anori and Amalfi, Antioquia Department, Colombia. Two buses belonged to Medellin Private Enterprises. No one was injured in the attack.
target2: Two buses  between Anori and Amalfi, Antioquia Department, Colombia
target3: Private vehicle between Anori and Amalfi, Antioquia Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Two buses and a private vehicle were completely burned, and the bridge was destroyed.
scite1: “ELN Carries Out Attacks in Antioquia, Valle Departments,” Caracol Television, April 11, 2000.

summary: 04/11/2000: A Mormon temple was bombed in Cali, Colombia. The National Liberation Army (NLA) was blamed for this attack. Only material damage was done to the temple. This was one of three temples that was attacked.
corp1: Church of Jesus Christ and the Latter Day Saints
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device was made of dynamite.
propcomment: The church sustained minor damage.
scite1: “Guerrillas Attack Mormon Temples in Cali,” AFP to Mexico Central American and the Caribbean, April 11, 2000.

summary: 04/11/2000: A Mormon temple was bombed in Cali, Colombia. The National Liberation Army (NLA) was blamed for this attack. Only material damage was done to the temple. This was one of three temples that was attacked.
corp1: Church of Jesus Christ and the Latter Day Saints
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device was made of dynamite.
propcomment: The church sustained minor damage.

corp1: Church of Jesus Christ and the Latter Day Saints
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The device was made of dynamite.
propcomment: The church sustained minor damage.
scite1: “Guerrillas Attack Mormon Temples in Cali,” AFP to Mexico Central American and the Caribbean, April 11, 2000.

summary: 04/11/2000: A bomb detonated in the parking lot of the Municipal Station in Cali, Colombia, injuring one. The National Liberation Army (NLA) was blamed for the attack.
target1: Municipal Station parking lot in Cali, Colombia
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Guerrillas Attack Mormon Temples in Cali,” AFP to Mexico Central American and the Caribbean, April 11, 2000.

summary: 04/11/2000: A bomb was found and deactivated at an aqueduct in Cali, Colombia. The National Liberation Army (NLA) was blamed for the bombing attempt.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bomb was discovered and disarmed by the bomb squad.
scite1: “Guerrillas Attack Mormon Temples in Cali,” AFP to Mexico Central American and the Caribbean, April 11, 2000.

summary: 04/12/2000: In Cali, Colombia, a Mexican citizen was kidnapped by the National Liberation Army (NLA), who demanded $5 million in ransom. On April 16, 2000, the police arrested three of the kidnappers and freed the hostage.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

summary: 04/13/2000: The National Liberation Army (NLA) and the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) were suspected of bombing a section of the Cano-Limon oil pipeline in La Cadena, Colombia. The explosion caused major damage and suspended oil production for several days. No one was injured in the attack.
target1: A section of the Cano-Limon Pipeline in La Cadena
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The explosion caused major damage to the pipeline and halted production for several days.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

location: On the Magdalena River between the municipalities of Montecristo and Magangue
summary: 5/7/2000: Unidentified gunmen kidnapped 15 people onboard two boats in the Magdalena river, in Bolivar province, Colombia.  The boats were carrying over 30 million pesos worth of supplies bound for Montecristo.  Unconfirmed reports indicated that the hostages were released not too long after being taken.
target1: Civilians on board two boats in Bolivar province
motive: Unknown
addnotes: It is unclear whether the incident was politically motivated or whether the goal was to steal supplies
scite1: "Colombian rebels kidnap 15 people in south," Columbian Radio, May 7, 2000.
scite2: "Fifteen people kidnapped in southern Bolivar Department," Santa Fe de Bogota Caracol Colombia Radio, May 9, 2000.
scite3: "Columbia - kidnapping 15 people kidnapped near ELN's neutral zone," EFE News Service, May 7, 2000.

summary: 05/14/2000: An Australian missionary and three Colombians were kidnapped in Canito, Colombia, by unknown perpetrators. The Colombian hostages were released later the same day. The fate of the Australian missionary was unknown.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

summary: 05/15/2000: In Chiquinquira, Colombia, members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) barged into the home of Elvia Cortez and strapped an explosive necklace to her. The bomb squad was called and they moved her to a secluded rural highway to defuse the bomb. They were unsuccessful and she was killed. A bomb technician was also killed and three soldiers were wounded.
motive: This specific attack was meant to send a message to the people of Chiquinquira that they had to finance the group or be killed.
scite1: "Woman Killed by Bomb Placed Around her Neck," The Associated Press, May 15, 2000.
scite2: Gary Jones, "The Human Bomb; Minutes Later the Device Exploded and Ransom Victim Elvira was Dead,"  The New York Times, May 17, 2000.
scite3: Jeremy McDermott, “Guerrillas’ Exploding Necklace Kills Woman," British Broadcasting Company, May 17, 2000.

summary: 05/19/2000: Forces loyal to a fugitive coup leader Gen. Lino Oviedo tried to topple the Paraguayan government by driving tanks through the center of the capital and blasting a hole in the Congress building before being persuaded to lay down their arms. The perpetrators of the attack were later arrested. Three civilians were injured in the attack.
target1: Top Paraguay government officials, including President Luis Gonzalez Macchi and the Speaker of Congress, Juan Carlos Galaverna
motive: Rebels wanted to overthrow the existing government and kill top government officials.
weapdetail: Tanks and light firearms were used in the attack.
propcomment: Rebels blew a hole in the building's façade.
addnotes: It was the third time in four years that Paraguay's weak democracy was threatened with a relapse into military rule. Each time Oviedo, a former army chief, has been near the center of events and each time the United States, Brazil and Argentina exerted pressure to ensure democracy survived in Paraguay. Oviedo, like Cubas and Gonzalez Macchi, were all members of the Colorado Party, which had ruled Paraguay without interruption for half a century as of May 2000.
scite1: “Coup attempt fails in Paraguay,” Deseret News (Salt Lake City), May 19, 2000.
scite2: “Shooting Starts Near Legislative Palace,” Madrid EFE, May 19, 2000.

location: On a highway in Colombia's western interior, between Samana and Victoria
summary: 6/4/2000: Members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) 47th Front set up a roadblock on a highway running between Samana and Victoria, Caldas Department, Colombia.  They kidnapped eight people in a "miracle fishing" expedition, where they singled out wealthier individuals to kidnap for ransom.
target1: Civilians traveling on a highway between Samana and Victoria
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but sources suggest that this was a kidnapping for ransom
scite1: "Columbia - rebels FARC kidnap 17 people in two "miracle fishing" raids," EFE News Service, June 6, 2000.
scite2: "Rights worker kidnapped," Radio Cadena Nacional, June 8, 2000.

location: On a highway in Colombia's western interior, between Samana and Victoria
summary: 6/5/2000: Members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) 47th Front set up a roadblock on a highway running between Samana and Victoria, Caldas Department, Colombia.  They kidnapped nine people in a "miracle fishing" expedition, where they singled out wealthier individuals to kidnap for ransom.
target1: Civilians traveling on a highway between Samana and Victoria
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but sources suggest that this was a kidnapping for ransom
scite1: "Columbia - rebels FARC kidnap 17 people in two "miracle fishing" raids," EFE News Service, June 6, 2000.
scite2: "Rights worker kidnapped," Radio Cadena Nacional, June 8, 2000.

summary: 06/19/2000: Between six and ten armed gunmen kidnapped the politician, Guillermo Leon Valencia, the brother of one of the Colombian government’s lead negotiators, after a high-speed car chase and gunfight with his bodyguards in Medellin, Colombia. The group behind the kidnapping was not known.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: One of the weapons was an Israeli-made automatic assault rifle.

location: Modelo National Prison
summary: 5/25/2000: Jineth Bedoya, a reporter for El Espectador, was abducted from Modelo National Prison in Bogota, Colombia, while trying to conduct an interview with an inmate.  Bedoya had been receiving threats from a group of inmates linked to right-wing paramilitary forces.  While trying to meet with one for an interview, she was abducted, bound and drugged, and driven to a city several hours away.  She was beaten, raped, and tortured by four male assailants who accused her of sympathizing with guerrillas.  The assailants told her that she and four other journalists were on a death list.  They released her later that same evening near the city of Villavicencio.
target1: Jineth Bedoya, a journalist from the newspaper El Espectador
motive: Journalists interpret the incident as being a warning to journalists: "Any journalist who dares to talk about human rights will become the subject of a story even more horrific than the one he or she may be investigating"
weapdetail: The victim was beaten, raped and tortured - other than a pistol, there is no other mention of specific weapons
ransomnote: The victim was told that she was on a death list, as was four other journalists.
addnotes: "El Panadero", also known as "the baker", is the inmate that the victim was trying to interview.  He was also a member of the right-wing paramilitary group that was threatening her and other journalists.  She had agreed to meet with him because she planned to dissuade him from harming her or others.
scite1: "Colombia - Journalists caught in cross-fire," M2 Presswire, June 23, 2000.
scite2: Ignacio Gomez, "Terror and the press," NACLA Report on the Americas," July 1, 2000.
scite3: Ignacio Gomez, "Truth and death in Colombia," The New York Times, June 23, 2000.

summary: 07/01/2000: Suspected members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC), launched two homemade rockets at a police station in Bogota, Colombia, killing one person and wounding thirty.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Two homemade rockets were launched from the bed of a pickup truck.
propcomment: There was damage to a car and surrounding buildings as a result of the attack.
scite1: "Terrorists attack police headquarters in Colombia," The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec), July 2, 2000.
scite2: "Briefs: Terrorists Attack Police HQ," The Halifax Daily News (Nova Scotia), July 2, 2000.

summary: 07/01/2000: Suspected members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) attacked a police academy in Cali, Valle del Cauca Department, Colombia, causing no casualties.
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Terrorists attack police headquarters in Colombia," The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec), July 2, 2000.
scite2: "Briefs: Terrorists Attack Police HQ," The Halifax Daily News (Nova Scotia), July 2, 2000.

summary: 07/07/2000: Two children, ages 3 and 9, were kidnapped by the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) in the demilitarized zone in the Putumayo Department. No details on if or when they were released could be found. No casualties were reported from the incident.
target1: Indiscriminate children in the Putumayo Department
motive: Ransom
weapdetail: The weapons used during the kidnapping were unknown.
addnotes: Although there are multiple sources about the original kidnapping, there are no further details available about the resolution of the incident.
scite1: "Kidnapping of two children upsets peace process in Colombia,” Agence France Presse, July 7, 2000.
scite2: "TV Highlights,” Bogota Caracol Television, July 7, 2000.

summary: 07/10/2000: A massacre attributed to Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) left at least three people dead in Dabeiba, Antioquia Department, Colombia.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The weapons used in this incident were unknown.
addnotes: There is only one source for this attack. It is unclear how many people died.
scite1: "Guerrillas, paramilitaries kill six in Uraba,” Radio Cadena National, July 10, 2000.

summary: 07/15/2000: A missile attack by the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) killed thirteen police officers in Roncesvalles, Tolima Department, Colombia.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The attackers used homemade missiles fashioned from gas canisters in the attack.  Later, guns were used to execute the police officers.
addnotes: The attackers shot homemade missiles into the town, probably aimed at the police station. After a protracted firefight, the police attempted to surrender and were executed.
scite1: "Colombia rebel attack kills 13 cops,” Associated Press Online, July 15, 2000.
scite2: "Missile attacks kills 13 police officers,” Akron Beacon Journal (Ohio), July 16, 2000.

summary: 07/22/2000: A Colombian Army Colonel, Oscar Jimmy Trujillo, commander of the Uraba region police battalion, was assassinated by two attackers while on leave in Rivera, Colombia. Police suspected Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) urban commando
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Army colonel assassinated at child beauty contest,” The Associated Press, July 23, 2000.
scite2: “Gunmen assassinate police commander in Huila; FARC rebels suspected,” Radio Cadena Nacional, July 26, 2000.
scite3: “Colombian army colonel assassinated; Marxist guerrilla rebels suspected in slaying,” Houston Chronicle, July 24, 2000.

summary: 07/27/2000: In Colombia, suspected Ejercito Revolucionario Guevarista (Guevarist Revolutionary Army) gunmen kidnapped a French aid worker affiliated with Doctors Without Borders. The fate of the hostage was not known.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

summary: 07/29/2000: Three hundred Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) rebels attacked the village of Arboleda, in the coffee-growing region of Caldas, Colombia. According to authorities, the ensuing confrontation between FARC rebels and police officers resulted in the death at least 8 police officers and two civilians. Additionally, the attack severed local phone and radio transmission capabilities and destroyed the village's church, police station, and numerous homes.
target1: Police outpost in the Village of Arboleda
target2: Indiscriminate Civilians in the village of Arboleda
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The attack severed local phone and radio transmission capabilities and destroyed the village's church, police station, and numerous homes.
addnotes: A number of the officers stationed in Arboleda were believed to be kidnapped during the time of this incident. FARC rebels told a local photojournalist who tried to enter Arboleda that they had killed 23 police officers.
scite1: “Eight police officers, two civilians, dead in rebel attack,” Agence France Presse, July 31, 2000.
scite2: Andrew Selsky, “Colombian Rebels Besiege Town,” The Associated Press, July 30, 2000.
scite3: Andrew Selsky, “8 Cops Found Dead in Colombia,” The Associated Press, July 30, 2000.

summary: 08/11/2000: Twenty-seven tourists, including one American, were kidnapped in the Antioquia Department of Colombia and released the next day. The National Liberation Army (NLA) was suspected in this incident.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

summary: 08/11/2000: A Colombian and an Irish citizen were kidnapped and killed by the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) in Tolima, Colombia.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

summary: 08/14/2000: The Cano Limon-Covenas pipeline in Colombia was bombed in an unspecified location in Colombia. The attack forced a suspension of oil pumping activities. No claim of responsibility was made however the National Liberation Army (NLA) was suspected of this attack.
target1: Ecopetrol's Cano Limon-Covenas pipeline in Colombia
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Dynamite
addnotes: The pipeline runs from the Cravo Norte fields (in eastern Colombia) to the port of Covenas, along the Caribbean coast.
scite1: "Cano Limon-Covenas Oil Pipeline Attacked 'Once More',” Radio Cadena Nacional, August 14, 2000.

summary: 8/27/2000: Suspected right-wing paramilitary fighters interrogated and killed at least nine residents of Cienaga, Colombia.  Carrying a list of names, the assailants pulled the victims from their homes and from a dance hall before killing them.  No group has claimed responsibility but authorities suspect that the attack was perpetrated by members of the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC).
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but civilians are often targeted because they are believed to be supporting rival groups
scite1: "Presumed paramilitary gangs kill 22 in Colombia," Reuters, August 27, 2000.
scite2: "Sixteen killed in two massacres," Agence France-Presse, August 27, 2000.
scite3: "At least 17 dead in Colombia massacres," Associated Press, August 27, 2000.

location: Along a nine mile stretch of highway outside Buenaventura
summary: 8/27/2000: Suspected right-wing paramilitary fighters raided two barrios and killed seven people near the port of Buenaventura, Colombia.  The assailants painted surrounding buildings with the initials AUC, which stands for the umbrella group the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC).
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but civilians are often targeted because they are believed to be supporting rival groups
propcomment: Several buildings were painted with the initials AUC
scite1: "Presumed paramilitary gangs kill 22 in Colombia," Reuters, August 27, 2000.
scite2: "Sixteen killed in two massacres," Agence France-Presse, August 27, 2000.
scite3: "At least 17 dead in Colombia massacres," Associated Press, August 27, 2000.

summary: 8/30/2000: Colombian police discovered and deactivated a two kilogram bomb in the port city of Cartagena, Colombia.  The bomb was discovered in a building approximately five blocks away from an area that President Clinton was scheduled to visit that day.  Authorities believe that the bomb was not intended to cause harm but was intended to cause panic.  At least two men have been arrested in connection to the incident; both are believed to be members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).
target2: Civilians and property in the vicinity of the bomb
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but authorities believe that the bomb was intended to cause panic rather than cause harm or excessive damage.  President Clinton was scheduled to visit the neighboring area later that day; the tour was in conjunction with a U.S. aid package designed to support Colombia's fight against the drug industry.
weapdetail: A two kilogram bomb
addnotes: One source states that bomb-making materials were discovered while two sources state that a functional bomb was discovered.  One source states that five people were arrested, another states that two were arrested, and a third does not mention arrests.
scite1: "Clinton - Bomb," Broadcast News, August 30, 2000.
scite2: Deb Riechmann, "Clinton visits Colombia to support anti-drug plan," Associated Press, August 30, 2000.
scite3: "Colombia police deactivate bomb close to Clinton route," Reuters, August 30, 2000.

summary: 09/03/2000: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) rebels attacked Montezuma Hill, Puerto Rico District, Risaralda Department to gain control of an Army weapons arsenal and communications tower there. 10 Colombian Army personnel and 64 guerrillas were killed.
target1: Colombian Army weapons cache on Montezuma Hill, Risaralda Department
motive: FARC guerrillas aimed to obtain weapons cache at incident site.
propcomment: The clash between Army and FARC forces, with FARC forces numbering at least 1,000, likely caused some form of property damage to military and/or civilian property.
addnotes: A unit of the Colombian Army called the Quick Reaction Force was dispatched to deal with this attack by the FARC.  Unnamed "officials" explained that the hill also contained important telecommunications and mobile network facilities, in additions to a weapons arsenal.  A mid-ranking Colonel was killed, and a Phantom aircraft was destroyed in the clash.  Individual names of the perpetrators were not available.
scite1: "RCN Radio Events Newscast," Radio Cadena Nacional, September 3, 2000.
scite2: "Pastrana Flies Over Area of Reported 'Fierce' Fighting Between Army, FARC," NOTIMEX (NTX), September 2, 2000.
scite3: "FARC Says FAC Planes Killed Many Soldiers," Agence France Presse, September 5, 2000.

summary: 09/03/2000: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) rebels attacked Tomas Razon town, near Riohacha city, Guajira Department, Colombia. FARC elements destroyed the local police station, a telecommunications plant, and a power plant. Seven Policemen, one civilian, and one FARC guerrilla was killed. Local officials stated that the FARC wanted to steal weapons from the police, rob a bank, and frighten the local population.
target1: Police station in Tomas Razon town
target3: Power Plant, Tomas Razon town
motive: FARC guerrillas wanted to steal weapons from the police, rob a bank, and frighten the townspeople.
weapdetail: A bomb squad found a defused land mines and cylinder bombs left by the FARC guerrillas.
propcomment: The attacked destroyed a police station, telecommunications plant, and a power plant.  It is possible that other property damage also occurred, given that land mines and bombs were used.
addnotes: The local Police had confirmed that the FARC was behind the attacks. Troops from the Cartegena Battalion of the Colombian Army arrived to restore order in the area. The town of Tomas Razon is located in the department of Guajira in northern Colombia.
scite1: "RCN Radio Events Newscast," Radio Cadena Nacional, September 3, 2000.
scite2: Margarita Martinez, "Thirty-five people killed over the weekend in Colombia," The Associated Press, September 3, 2000.

summary: 09/04/2000: Between 0300 and 0100 of September 4, 2000, 70kg of explosives in a box, dropped off by a van, heavily damaged the National Customs and Tax Directorate (DIAN) building in Barrancabermeja's commercial district. The building was located on the corner of Carrera (Route) 8D and Sixth Street. Four Policemen, two security guards, one soldier, and a civilian were injured. The building was reported as "blown up" and destroyed several nearby shops. The National Police blamed the incident on the National Liberation Army (NLA) group.
corp1: National Customs and Tax Directorate, Colombia
target1: The National Customs and Tax Directorate office in Barrancabermeja
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The weapon was an explosive reported to be "R1," packed into a box and weighing 70kg.  It was unclear whether R1 refers to the name of an explosive or the "R1" classification of explosives.  A material with a R1 classification is deemed explosive when dry
propcomment: The property damage was extensive to the building containing the DIAN office and nearby stores.  The immediate area on the road where the box was dropped most likely suffered extensive damage as well.  Value of property damage reported as 1.5 billion Colombian pesos.
addnotes: Colombian media reported that around 0015 of September 4, 2000, two individuals in a blue Sprint model vehicle stopped outside the DIAN office and quickly dropped off a box. Minutes later, the box exploded. The National Police asserted that their technical tests on the explosive indicated that the ELN was responsible. Barrancabermeja is in north-central Colombia, and is in the heart of a region long dominated by political instability between the Colombian Government and various guerrilla movements.
scite1: Juan Carlos Ordonez, "Bomb Injures Eight in Barrancabermeja," Caracol Colombia Radio (WWW-Text), September 4, 2000.
scite2: "Bogota TV Highlights 041630: BOG 00--176," Caracol Television, September 4, 2000.

summary: 09/04/2000: In a series of related incidents, in the early morning of September 4, 2000, five bombs were detonated simultaneously at lottery vending and permanent booking offices around Medellin, Colombia. No injuries or casualties were reported, but there was substantial damage to shops and private property. The police suspected rebels from the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) in the attacks.
target1: Lottery vendors and permanent booking (bookies) office
motive: The intent was to bomb the businesses in order to intimidate them into giving the FARC protection money.
weapdetail: Dynamite was used in this incident.
propcomment: The storefronts and windows of the lottery vendors were destroyed.
scite1: "Rebels bomb businesses across Colombia," Deutsche Presse-Agentur, September 4, 2000.
scite2: Juan Carlos Ordonez, "Bomb Injures Eight in Barrancabermeja," Caracol Colombia Radio (WWW-Text), September 4, 2000.
scite3: "Bogota TV Highlights 041630: BOG 00--176," Caracol Television, September 4, 2000.

location: The kidnapping began in Pacho, 36 miles north of Bogota and ended in Zipaquira, 24 miles north of Bogota
summary: 8/30/2000: Gerardo Sanin, a Catholic priest and uncle of the leading presidential candidate Noemi Sanin, was kidnapped in Pacho, Colombia.  Sanin was released in Zipaquira, Colombia, on September 4, 2000.  Sanin claims that Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) abducted him.  The motive behind the kidnapping is unknown.
target1: Gerardo Sanin, a Catholic priest and uncle of the leading presidential candidate
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: No mention of weapons was made
addnotes: The hostage-takers made no demands in return for the safe return of the hostage.
scite1: "Suspected rebels free priest, uncle of presidential candidate," Associated Press, September 5, 2000.
scite2: "World headlines," Dayton Daily News, September 6, 2000.
scite3: "Priest's release celebrated in Colombian city," Chicago Sun-Times, September 6, 2000.

location: The neighborhood of Higienopolis in the center of Sao Paulo city
summary: 9/5/2000: Jose Eduardo Bernardes da Silva, an official with the human rights organization Amnesty International, received a letter bomb sent to his home in Sao Paulo, Brazil.  The police safely detonated the bomb in a controlled explosion.  The bomb was packaged in paper that had two pink swastikas written on it.  Da Silva had been receiving death threats since he had publicly denounced violence directed towards Jewish people, people of African decent, and homosexuals.
target1: Jose Eduardo Bernardes da Silva, an official with Amnesty International
motive: Gay and human rights organizations were being targeted in the lead up to Brazil's independence day (September 7th), when skinheads had threatened to begin "cleansing" the country.
weapdetail: A packaged time bomb
scite1: "Police detonate time bomb mailed to Amnesty International official," Associated Press, September 5, 2000.
scite2: "Letter bomb for Brazil Amnesty official is defused," Reuters, September 5, 2000.
scite3: "Two letter bombs found as skinheads pledge campaign of hatred in Brazil," Agence France-Presse, September 6, 2000.

summary: 09/07/2000: In the early morning hours of September 7, 2000, seven people were killed as they were participating in a religious ceremony in a private home in Palmas District, Area 12, Buenaventura, Colombia. Two individuals were arrested, and confiscated automatic weapons, ammunition, bullet-proof vests, and various documents. Reports indicated there were five gunmen that arrived in a white pickup truck. The Mayor of Buenaventura accused paramilitary groups, including the United SElf-Defense Groups of Colombia (AUC) as perpetrators.
target1: Family and relatives of Benjamin Angulo, and the Garcia Aramburo family
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Bullet casings were found at the scene of the incident, indicating that a number of shots were fired.
propcomment: It is quite possible that some property, such as walls, were damaged by the shooting.
addnotes: The United Self-Defense Group of Colombia (AUC) is a paramilitary group intended as a vigilante group to protect businesses and citizens against guerrilla movements such as FARC and ELN. The Semana news magazine reported that the target family was fleeing the AUC by seeking refuge with relatives in Buenaventura city. Semana also reported that the incident occurred at 9PM on September 6, 2000, instead of early morning September 7, 2000 as reported by other news sources. Groups such as AUC are often backed by wealthy businessmen, landowners, and magnates, and often engage in ransom kidnapping and corrupt activities to raise funds. As a result, the difference between AUC and FARC-like groups are increasingly difficult to distinguish. Buenaventura is a seaside resort in Valle de Cauca Province, the capital of which is Cali--a known hub for the Colombian drug trade.
scite1: "AUC Kill Seven in Buenaventura," El Pais (Internet Version-WWW), September 8, 2000.
scite2: "Bogota TV Highlights 071730: BOG 00--179," Caracol Television, September 7, 2000.
scite3: "Guerrillas, Paras, Drug Traffickers Fighting to Control Buenaventura," Semana (Internet Version-WWW), September 11, 2000.

location: This incident occurred between La Loma mine and Cienaga port in Magdalena Department.
summary: 09/07/2000: Three Colombian nationals working for US-based coal mining and operations company Drummond Co. were kidnapped by rebels on the Drummond-owned railway between the Pribbenow mine at La Loma in Cesar Department and Cienaga port in Magdalena Department. There were no injuries, but the kidnapping involved using dynamite to blast the rail track. The two-engine coal train suffered extensive damage, carrying 82 containers with 4,000 tons of coal. All three hostages were released on September 11, 2000.
target1: Drummond Company's Pribbenow Mine at La Loma, and railway between La Loma and Drummond's port at Cienaga, Magdalena Department
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Dynamite was used in the incident.
propcomment: Lost revenues for this and several other attacks in 2000 on the same rail route inflicted an estimated cost of 10 billion pesos US$2.64 million.  The railway, two train engines, and 82 coal cars were damaged.
addnotes: On the same day as the release of the three hostages, FARC kidnapped three more Drummond employees (cf. 200009110002).
scite1: "US Mining Company Refuses to Pay Ransom for Workers," Colombiano (Internet-WWW), September 14, 2000.
scite2: "Drummond Hit by Guerrilla Attack," Coal Americas, September 29, 2000.
scite3: "Company says employees released from captivity in Colombia," The Associated Press, September 28, 2000.

location: This incident occurred between La Loma mine and Cienaga port in Magdalena Department.
summary: 09/11/2000: Three Colombian nationals working for US-based coal mining and operations company Drummond Co. were kidnapped by the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) on the railway between Pribbenow mine at La Loma in Cesar Department and Cienaga port in Magdalena Department. There were no injuries, but the coal train on which the employees were riding was derailed, damaging one engine and 18 coal cars. Drummond Co. refused to pay a ransom. On September 26, 2000, two of the kidnapped employees in this incident, and one employee from an earlier Drummond kidnapping, were freed. The final employee, a security contractor advisor, was released sometime in October or November 2000. Reports estimated that Drummond lost almost US$440,000 in lost revenue in this incident.
target1: Drummond Company's Pribbenow Mine at La Loma, and railway between La Loma and Drummond's port at Cienaga, Magdalena Department
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Dynamite was used in the incident.
propcomment: Lost revenues for this and several other attacks in 2000 on the same rail route inflicted an estimated cost of 10 billion pesos US$2.64 million.  The railway, one train engine, and 18 coal cars were damaged.
ransomnote: Drummond Company stated during the kidnapping that they would not pay any ransom.  However, there was no mention of ransom paid in reports of the hostages' releases.
addnotes: Another kidnapping occurred on the same railway on 09/07/2000 (cf. 200009070006), where FARC kidnapped two employees and one contractor. On 09/26/2000, FARC released three hostages--the two employees kidnapped on 09/11/2000, and another kidnapped in an earlier incident unspecified in news reports.Drummond Company is based out of Birmingham, Alabama, United States.
scite1: Russell Hubbard," Drummond Operations Attacked by Terrorists," Birmingham News (Alabama), September 15, 2000.
scite2: "Drummond Hit by Guerrilla Attack," Coal Americas, September 29, 2000.
scite3: "Company says employees released from captivity in Colombia," The Associated Press, September 28, 2000.

location: This incident occurred 70 km west of the Caño Limón oil field.
summary: 09/13/2000: The Caño Limón-Coveñas oil pipeline was bombed, with a loss of over 2000 barrels of crude oil. The National Liberation Army (NLA) claimed responsibility for the attacks in protest of American involvement in the Colombian oil industry and Colombia's acceptance of a US$1.3 billion aid package to fight drugs and insurgents. No injuries were reported and no perpetrators were arrested.
target1: Caño Limón-Coveñas oil pipeline, jointly operated by Occidental Petroleum
target2: Caño Limón-Coveñas oil pipeline, jointly-operated by ECOPETROL
motive: The motive was to protest American involvement in the Colombian oil industry and US monetary aid to Colombia's anti-drug and anti-rebel campaigns.
weapdetail: Unknown explosives were used.
propcomment: The pipeline was damaged by the blast, and 2,000 barrels of crude oil on the pipeline at the time of the incident were lost via spillage.  The pipeline was also shut down, preventing further oil transports, and dramatically increasing the lost revenue for
addnotes: The Caño Limón-Coveñas oil pipeline is one of the most frequently attacked structures in Colombia. At the time of the incident, the pipeline had operated for barely a full week since July 23, 2000. This incident occurred only 12 hours after the pipeline was reopened after another blast on 09/09/2000 (cf. 200009090004).
scite1: "New attack by Marxist rebels cripples Colombia crude pipeline: Bombings began in July," National Post (Canada), September 14, 2000.
scite2: "Colombia Shuts Cano Limon; Occidental Petroleum's pipeline bombed; Brief Article," The Oil Daily, September 14, 2000.
scite3: Yadira Ferrer, "Oil-Colombia: Rebel Attacks Hurt Exports While Prices Soar," IPS-Inter Press Service, September 19, 2000.

summary: 09/13/2000: The National Liberation Army (NLA) set up a fake roadblock in Antioquia and kidnapped two Russian civil engineers. The hostages were released on September 21, 2000.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

location: This incident occurred 10 miles outside Cali.
summary: 09/17/2000: Gunmen kidnapped as many as 80 civilians in Cali, Colombia. The victims were church-goers or patrons of an area restaurant. One U.S. citizen was also kidnapped. The National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN) were suspected in this incident.
target1: Restaurant patrons and church-goers in Cali, Colombia
motive: Unknown
addnotes: There were conflicting reports about the hostages.
scite1: “Army Says ELN Kidnapped 80, Released 25,” Bogota Caracol Colombia Radio, September 19, 2000.
scite2: “Gunmen abduct 30 in Colombia raids,” The San Diego Union-Tribune, September 18, 2000.
scite3: “Colombian Gunmen Seize At Least 30,” The Washington Post, September 18, 2000.

location: This incident occurred in Putumayo Department alongside the Trans-Andean pipeline.
summary: 09/23/2000: The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) launched an offensive against the Trans-Andean oil pipeline. Guerrillas blew up three separate sections of the pipeline during the attack. No one was injured in the explosions.
target1: Trans-Andean oil pipeline belonging to Ecopetrol (Colombian Petroleum Enterprise)
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Three sections of pipeline were destroyed in the attacks
addnotes: The attacks occurred five days before a scheduled meeting between Colombian President Andres Pastrana and Ecuadorian President Gustavo Noboa, who had planned to meet Thursday, 28 September, at the International Bridge over the San Miguel river for the bridge's official opening.
scite1: “FARC Attacks Trans-Andean Pipeline in Putumayo,” Bogota El Tiempo (Internet Version-WWW), September 26, 2000.

location: This incident occurred in Putumayo Department alongside the Trans-Andean pipeline.
summary: 09/25/2000: The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) rebels launched three attacks that forced the suspension of pumping activities. There were no injuries reported as a report of the blasts. However, the explosions caused a thick oil spill that spread to several rivers, including the Yurumito river that feeds the Orito water plant, which supplies water to over 7,000 area residents.
target1: Trans-Andean oil pipeline belonging to Ecopetrol (Colombian Petroleum Enterprise)
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The explosions caused a thick oil spill that spread to several rivers, including the Yurumito river that feeds the Orito water plant, which supplies water to over 7,000 area  residents.   This has prompted health officials to declare an emergency.
addnotes: The attacks occurred three days before a scheduled meeting between Colombian President Andres Pastrana and Ecuadorian President Gustavo Noboa, who had planned to meet Thursday, 28 September, at the International Bridge over the San Miguel river for the bridge's official opening.
scite1: “FARC Attacks Trans-Andean Pipeline in Putumayo,” Bogota El Tiempo (Internet Version-WWW), September 26, 2000.

summary: 10/00/2000: In a series of related incidents, at least 200 suspected United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia (AUC) paramilitaries attacked several locations in the Maria Mountain region of Colombia, killing at least 15 campesinos and causing hundreds of families to flee their homes. In this incident, the perpetrators attacked the district of La Sierra in the Sucre department. These attacks occurred in October sometime on or before the 18th of the month.
target1: Indiscriminate Civilians in the Maria Mountain region
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Unknown
addnotes: This was one of five related attacks (cf. 200010000002-04; 200010000006-08). The casualty information was reported collectively for both incidents, so the figures were split evenly across these cases in order to preserve the statistical accuracy of the database. Eleven of the victims were identified as Ezequiel Oscar, Nestor Oscar, Erney Jaraba Oscar, Juan Montes, Pedro Montes, Orlando Oviedo, Lideres Tapias, Alcibiades Mendoza, and Alberto and Manuel de Jesus Palacios.
scite1: “Alleged Paramilitary Attack Leaves 15 Dead in Sucre,” Caracol Colombia Radio, October 18, 2000.

Eleven of the victims were identified as Ezequiel Oscar, Nestor Oscar, Erney Jaraba Oscar, Juan Montes, Pedro Montes, Orlando Oviedo, Lideres Tapias, Alcibiades Mendoza, and Alberto and Manuel de Jesus Palacios.
