location: The incident occurred in the mountains near the town of Quinchia.
summary: 10/01/2000: Members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) kidnapped Ernesto Gomez, a candidate to the Quinchia mayoral seat, as he passed by an area outside of the town. The fate of the victim was unknown.
motive: The mayor was supposedly captured in order to be a spokesman for a message to the public about the electoral campaign.
scite1: "FARC Kidnaps 11 Politicians, Candidates in Risaralda, Santander," NOTIMEX, October 01, 2000.
scite2: "Two mayors among eight kidnapped in Colombia," The Associated Press, October 01, 2000.

location: The incident occurred on a highway connecting Matanza and Bucaramanga.
summary: 10/01/2000: The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) seized eight Colombian civilians, along with Mayor Orlando Lizcano and Mayor Jose Gregorio Plata, on a highway between Matanza and Bucaramanga. There were no casualties during the assault and subsequent kidnapping.
target1: Eight individuals traveling with the Mayors of Matanza and Surata
target3: Mayor Orlando Lizcano
motive: Unknown
addnotes: This was one of two related attacks (cf. 200010010001). Four hostages were released the evening of October 1, 2000. The fate of the other hostage was unknown.
scite1: "FARC Kidnaps 11 Politicians, Candidates in Risaralda, Santander," NOTIMEX, October 01, 2000.
scite2: "Two mayors among eight kidnapped in Colombia," The Associated Press, October 01, 2000.

location: The Caribbean coastal city of Barranquilla
summary: 10/5/2000: At least two unidentified assailants shot and killed Alfredo Castro, a college professor and critic of corruption, while he was walking with his spouse and daughter in Barranquilla, Colombia.  No group has claimed responsibility for the attack and the motive is unknown.
target1: Alfredo Castro, a social sciences college professor
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Motive and perpetrators are unknown; this could be a purely criminal act.
scite1: "Outspoken professor killed in Colombia," Associated Press, October 7, 2000.
scite2: "Army finds alleged ELN explosives on Barrranquilla university campus," El Tiempo, October 11, 2000.
scite3: Lorraine Orlandi, "Violence strangles Colombia intellectuals' voice," Reuters, November 20, 2000.

location: The incident occurred on a highway connecting Medellin with Bogota.
summary: 10/06/2000: A journalist and a photographer of the newspaper El Colombiano were kidnapped on October 6th near Medellin, Colombia. The kidnappers blew up a highway toll both and set fire to the journalist's car. After the attack, the kidnappers fled to an unknown location with their hostages. No group claimed responsibility, although Ejercito de Liberación Nacional (ELN) was suspected of carrying out the attack.
target1: Two El Colombiano newspaper staff members (a journalist and a photographer)
motive: Unknown
propcomment: A car and toll both were destroyed in the attack.
addnotes: Both hostages were released after three days in captivity.
scite1: "ELN Kidnaps Medellin Newspaper Journalist, Photographer," Agence France Presse to Mexico Central America and the Caribbean, October 06, 2000.
scite2: "Colombian reporter, photographer released by guerrillas," Agence France Presse, October 09, 2000.

summary: 10/07/2000: Four explosions occurred in locations throughout Santiago de Cali, Colombia, causing "extensive" damage and injuring seven. The explosions were caused by two car bombs and two other explosives. The first car explosion was aimed at an army brigade battalion. Four passengers on a bus and three people in cars were injured in the explosion. Ejercito de Liberación Nacional (ELN) was suspected in the attack.
target1: Colombian Military base in Santiago de Cali
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A car bomb
propcomment: A passenger bus and several cars were damaged in the explosion.
scite1: "Police Now Report Two Cali Car Bombs, 7 Injured, 'Extensive Property Damage,'" EFE, October 09, 2000.
scite2: "Seven injured in Colombian car bomb blast," Deutsche Presse-Agentur, October 08, 2000.

summary: 10/07/2000: Four explosions occurred in locations throughout Santiago de Cali, Colombia, causing "extensive" damage and injuring seven. The explosions were caused by two car bombs and two other explosives. One car bomb exploded in a drugstore parking lot. Ejercito de Liberación Nacional (ELN) was suspected in the attack.
target1: Colombian drugstore in Santiago de Cali
motive: Unknown

propcomment: A car exploded outside of a drugstore.  Reports do not indicate if the drugstore was damaged in the explosion.
scite1: "Police Now Report Two Cali Car Bombs, 7 Injured, 'Extensive Property Damage,'" EFE, October 09, 2000.
scite2: "Seven injured in Colombian car bomb blast," Deutsche Presse-Agentur, October 08, 2000.

Ejercito de Liberación Nacional (ELN) was suspected in the attack.
target1: Colombian car dealership in Santiago de Cali
motive: Unknown

scite2: "Seven injured in Colombian car bomb blast," Deutsche Presse-Agentur, October 08, 2000.

summary: 10/07/2000: Four explosions occurred in locations throughout Santiago de Cali, Colombia, causing "extensive" damage and injuring seven. The explosions were caused by two car bombs and two other explosives. One bomb exploded at a house in eastern Cali. Ejercito de Liberación Nacional (ELN) was suspected in the attack.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: An explosion occurred outside of a private residence.  Reports do not indicate if the house was damaged as a result of the bombing.
scite1: "Police Now Report Two Cali Car Bombs, 7 Injured, 'Extensive Property Damage,'" EFE, October 09, 2000.
scite2: "Seven injured in Colombian car bomb blast," Deutsche Presse-Agentur, October 08, 2000.

location: The village of Ortega, 250 miles west of Bogota
summary: 10/8/2000: Members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) attacked Ortega village, Tolima department, Colombia.  The rebels shot and killed at least eight villagers, hacking the victims' bodies with machetes after shooting them.  FARC members also burned down 20 homes, a church, and a school.  The rebels had visited the village a month previously to recruit villagers; when the villagers refused, the rebels accused them of working with the army.
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the rebels had tried to recruit villagers previously and had failed.  They had accused the villagers of collaborating with the army.
weapdetail: The villagers were shot and then hacked with machetes.  Their houses were burnt down.
propcomment: 20 houses, a church, and a school were burnt down
addnotes: Two sources stated that eight people were killed; one source stated that 13 were killed.
scite1: Michael Easterbrook, "Rebels level a village and kill eight peasants," Associated Press, October 8, 2000.
scite2: "Political & civil unrest: Columbia," Lloyd's Information Casualty Report, October 11, 2000.
scite3: "Europeans balk at funding the drug war in Colombia," San Francisco Chronicle, October 12, 2000.

summary: 10/8/2000: Members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) killed approximately 20 people in Cauca province, Colombia.  The rebels gathered civilians that had names on a list and executed them in the street.  They also set fire to 40 houses.  The attack is believed to be motivated by revenge; the rebels believed that the civilians had joined forces with paramilitaries against FARC.
target1: Civilians in Cauca province who were believed to have aided paramilitaries
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but sources state that the attack was likely motivated by revenge; the rebels were targeting civilians that they believed had joined forces with paramilitaries against FARC.
weapdetail: Outside of setting fire to houses, no mention of specific weapons was made
propcomment: The rebels burned down 40 houses
addnotes: Sources do not indicate where the attack took place and whether it was one incident or several incidents
scite1: "Colombian rebels kill twenty people," BBC, October 9, 2000.

summary: 10/12/2000: Ten oil workers were kidnapped in eastern Ecuador, then flown across the border into Colombia by guerrillas from the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC). At least fifteen gunmen ambushed the workers in the oil encampment of Tivacuno.
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Helicopter used in jungle abduction," The Advertiser, October 14, 2000.
scite2: "Ecuador Oil Crew Taken in Ambush, Flown to Colombia; Hostages Include at Least 5 Americans; Guerrillas Are Blamed, but Deny Role," The Washington Post, October 13, 2000.
scite3: Clifford Krauss, "Colombia Rebels Deny They Kidnapped Foreign Oil Workers," The New York Times, October 14, 2000.

location: Approximately 30 kilometers northeast of Medellin
summary: 10/15/2000: Members of a right-wing paramilitary group abducted eleven villagers from Barbosa, Antioquia department, Colombia.  The assailants accused the captives of being guerrilla collaborators.  All of the captives, consisting of seven men and four women, were found shot to death on a dirt road near to Barbosa the next day.
motive: The assailants accused the captives of collaborating with guerrillas
scite1: "11 found shot dead," The Daily Telegraph, October 17, 2000.

summary: 10/22/2000: A Bogota mayoral candidate Antanas Mockus, was detained for three hours by rebels of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) as he campaigned in Sumapaz, Colombia. He was released, unharmed, after the incident.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Gunmen kidnap two Colombian lawmakers; rebels detain mayoral candidate,” Associated Press Worldstream, October 22, 2000.
scite2: “World in Brief,” The Atlanta Journal and Constitution, October 23, 2000.
scite3: “Rebels Kidnap Lawmakers,” Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, October 23, 2000.

summary: 10/28/2000: Rebels from the Popular Liberation Army (Ejircito Popular de Liberaciyn - EPL) assassinated Jose Rodriguez, the suspended mayor of Ocana, in the nearby town of Teorama, Colombia.
target1: Jose Rodriguez, the suspended Mayor of Ocana
motive: The rebels killed Jose Rodriguez after trying him on corruption charges in a revolutionary court.
addnotes: Government officials had suspended Rodriguez from office while investigating charges that he had been stealing public funds. The Popular Liberation Army kidnapped him on August 20, 2000, and killed him after apparently trying him for corruption in a revolutionary court.
scite1: “Rebels assassinate a Colombian politician while another disappears, police say,” Associated Press, October 28, 2000.

location: The Toquepala copper mine and the mining town of Masocruz
summary: 10/29/2000: 51 soldiers led by Lieutenant Colonel Ollanta Humala Tasso took brief control of the Toquepala copper mine and the mining town of Masocruz, Tacna province, Peru.  They fled with four hostages, including three mine workers and General Oscar Bardales, and took several vehicles belonging to the mine.  They later released the three mine workers and returned the vehicles the next day.  The army captured the renegade soldiers the next day, although eight remained at large, including the leader.  The soldiers who revolted questioned the legitimacy of the President Alberto Fujimori and his former intelligence chief Vladimiro Montesinos.  They stated that the President had not been elected by the people.
target1: Mine workers at Toquepala copper mine
motive: The renegade soldiers did not believe that the President had been legitimately elected by the people.  They demanded that the President be ousted from government and that his former intelligence chief be imprisoned.
weapdetail: No mention of specific weapons was made
scite1: "Small group of soldiers stage revolt in Peru," Dow Jones International News, October 29, 2000.
scite2: Ricardo Uztarroz, "Rebel soldiers on the run in Peruvian highlands," Agence France-Presse, October 30, 2000.
scite3: Will Weissert, "Standoff draws to an end; Peruvians weigh merits of uprising," Associated Press, October 30, 2000.

location: Unknown
summary: 10/31/2000: Carlos Castano and other members of the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) took seven lawmakers hostage in Colombia.  The hostage-taking was executed in order to protest President Patsrana's policy of negotiating with guerrillas, in general, and the plan to trade leftist rebel prisoners for captured troops and police, in particular.  The government agreed to hold a private meeting with Castano to hear his views concerning ending the conflict in Colombia.  The hostages were released on November 6th and 7th; they were unharmed.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: The kidnappers were protesting President Patsrana's policy of negotiating with guerrillas, in general, and the plan to trade leftist rebel prisoners for captured troops and police, in particular.   They demanded a face-to-face meeting in order to have their views heard.
weapdetail: No mention of weapons was made
addnotes: Two sources state that seven legislators were taken captive, but one source states that eight were released.
scite1: "Paramilitaries in Colombia kidnap seven lawmakers," Agence France-Presse, November 1, 2000.
scite2: "Hostages released and peace talks resumed in Colombia," Xinhua News Agency, November 2, 2000.
scite3: "Warlord frees kidnapped Colombian lawmakers," Reuters, November 7, 2000.

location: This incident occurred near Sabana de Torres, on the road to Magdalena Medio.
summary: 11/02/2000: Twenty-five people were kidnapped at a fake road block near Sabana de Torres on the road to Magdalena Medio by Ejercito de Liberación Nacional (ELN – Army of National Liberation). Twenty-two of the hostages were rescued on November 2, 2000 and the last three were rescued on November 3, 2000.
target1: Civilians stopped at a road block near Sabana de Torres
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Army Reports Three Hostages Rescued in Santander,” Radio Cadena Nacional WWW-Text, November 3, 2000.

summary: 11/03/2000: Nineteen people were killed and five wounded in the Antioquia Department, Colombia, after being attacked by the United Self-defense Forces of Colombia (AUC - Las Autodefensas Unidas de Colombia). The attack was part of an effort by the AUC to control that area of Colombia.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: AUC took action to exert their influence over the Antioquia Department
scite1: “Attack by Alleged Paramilitary Groups Leaves 19 Dead,” NOTIMEX, November 3, 2000.

summary: 11/14/2000: In the first of two related attacks, the National Liberation Army (NLA) denoted a car bomb in Cali, Colombia, killing one man and injuring one woman. The explosion also damaged several buildings.
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Two Terrorist Explosions Kill At Least One, Injure Nine in Cali, Colombia,” EFE, November15, 2000.

summary: 11/14/2000: In the second of two related attacks, the National Liberation Army (NLA) detonated a bomb at a police station in eastern Cali, Colombia. At least one policeman and seven civilians were injured by the explosion, which also damaged a nearby building.
target1: A Police Station in Eastern Cali
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Two Terrorist Explosions Kill At Least One, Injure Nine in Cali, Colombia,” EFE, November15, 2000.

summary: 11/18/2000: A motorcycle bomb exploded in downtown Puerto Asis, Putumayo Department, Colombia, leaving one person dead and seventeen others injured. No one claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Bomb Leaves 1 Dead, 17 Injured in Putumayo,” Agence France Presse, November 18, 2000.

location: This incident occurred on the road connecting the El Encano (Narino) section with Santiago de Cali.
summary: 11/22/2000: Five government aid vehicles, three of them containing food, were burnt by members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) on the road connecting the El Encano (Narino) section with Santiago de Cali, Colombia. The vehicles, which included a truck carrying gas cylinders and a dump truck, were totally burnt after their drivers refused to obey the guerrillas' order not to travel along the road.
target1: Government aid trucks supplying residents of Upper Putumayo
motive: The attack came after FARC rebels warned truck drivers not to travel along the road.
propcomment: Five vehicles, three of them containing food, were burned by the rebels.
scite1: "Rebels attack lorries taking food to Upper Putumayo,” BBC November 23, 2000.

summary: 11/22/2000: At dawn, suspected right-wing paramilitary gunmen, wearing camouflage and armed with automatic assault rifles, ordered the residents of Neuva Venecia, Colombia, out of their homes. They then shot seventeen people whom they identified from a list. Police said that the dead were men who had been singled out for their alleged complicity with left-wing guerrilla groups. Members of Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) were suspected.
target1: Seventeen specific residents of Nueva Venecia
motive: The seventeen residents were accused of cooperation with leftist guerillas.
scite1: "Right-wing rebels shoot 17 on hit list,” Edmonton Journal, November 23, 2000.

location: 40 miles from Bogota
summary: 11/25/2000: Approximately 15 suspected members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) abducted Lazaro Montes from his farmhouse in Silvania, Cundinamarca Department, Colombia.  Montes is the Colombian manager for Hyundai Motor Company.  Specific motive is unknown.
target1: Lazaro Montes, the Colombian manager for the Hyundai Motor Company
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, sources note that FARC members have often employed kidnappings in order to get ransom money to fund their uprising.
addnotes: Although sources state that members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) were responsible for the kidnapping, authorities have not verified that statement.
scite1: "Hyundai manager in Colombia kidnapped," Associated Press, November 27, 2000.
scite2: "Colombian gunmen kidnap Hyundai manager," Reuters, November 26, 2000.
scite3: "Columbia - Kidnapping alleged FARC members kidnap Hyundai's top executive in Columbia," EFE News Service, November 26, 2000.

summary: 11/26/2000: A bomb hidden in a metal gas container exploded in front of the Colombian Embassy in Santiago, Chile. A local radio station said that it had received a call, which attributed the attack to a "nameless" group opposed to the "Plan Colombia." The attack resulted in no casualties and only minor damage.
motive: The unnamed group said the bombing was in opposition to the "Plan Colombia."
scite1: "Bomb emplodes in front of Colombian embassy in Chile,” Agence France Presse, November 27, 2000.

location: A few blocks from the Javeriana University in Bogota
summary: 11/28/2000: Juliana Villegas, the daughter of the president of the National Association of Industries, was abducted near Javeriana University in Bogota, Colombia.  Six armed members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) grabbed her and forced her into a car.  She was released on March 2, 2001, as a "humanitarian gesture".  FARC stated that they released her after they were satisfied that Villegas and her father had no ties to a paramilitary group.  They did not ask for a ransom for her release.
target1: Luis Carlos Villegas, the president of National Association of Industries
target2: Juliana Villegas, the daughter of Luis Carlos Villegas
motive: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) stated that they conducted the kidnapping in order to ensure that the victim and the victim's father did not have any ties to a paramilitary group
addnotes: The victim was abducted in Bogota but was released in southeastern Huila province.  She said that she was in perfect health.
scite1: "Colombia kidnapping teen age daughter of top business leader kidnapped," Associated Press, November 29, 2000.
scite2: "Columbia - Kidnapping Columbian gov't condemns kidnapping of industry leader's daughter," EFE News Service, November 28, 2000.
scite3: Will Weissert, "Guerrillas free daughter of Colombian business leader," Associated Press, March 2, 2001.

location: On the border with Ecuador
summary: 11/29/2000: An unidentified gunman shot and killed Carlos Julio Rosas, the mayor of Orito, as he was leaving his home in Orito, Putumayo province, Colombia.  The gunman fired four rounds at Rosas from the back of a motorcycle, after which he and the driver sped away.  No group has claimed responsibility for the attack and specific motive is unknown.
target1: Carlos Rosas, the mayor of Orito
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, Colombian mayors had been targeted in escalating violence
weapdetail: The gunman shot the victim with four rounds at close range
scite1: "Motorcycle gunman kills rural Colombian mayor," Reuters, November 29, 2000.
scite2: "Columbia - Venezuela government condemns mayor's murder," EFE News Service, November 29, 2000.
scite3: Juan Pablo Toro, "Gunmen kill mayor in southern coca-growing region," Associated Press, November 29, 2000.

location: The town of Granada, 125 miles northwest of Bogota
summary: 12/6/2000: At least 100 members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) attacked the town of Granada in western Colombia.  At least 29 people were killed in the attack and 15 were injured.  The assailants set off explosives, including a car bomb, and demolished numerous buildings.  They also took 15 journalists hostage but released them the next day.  Witnesses report that the assailants had orders to kill police officers.  Specific motive is unknown, but witnesses state that it appeared the attack was motivated by the presence of United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) in the town.  FARC and AUC are engaged in a battle over territory.
target1: Civilians in the vicinity of Granada
target2: Police officers in the vicinity of Granada
target3: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, witnesses state that the attack was prompted by the presence of the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC), a rivalry group.
weapdetail: A car bomb, homemade mortars, and propane cylinders filled with explosives and shrapnel
propcomment: Buildings were destroyed in the bombings
addnotes: Sources differ in the number of attackers, number of fatalities and injuries, and number of buildings destroyed.
scite1: "Rebel attack on Colombian town leaves 29 dead, rescuers look for more," Associated Press, December 8, 2000.
scite2: Ibon Villelabeitia, "At least 21 dead as Colombian rebels attack town," Reuters, December 8, 2000.
scite3: "36 dead, thousands displaced after latest rash of Colombian violence," Agence France-Presse, December 8, 2000.

summary: 12/07/2000: Five unidentified perpetrators firebombed the Chilean Public Prosecutor's office in Santiago, Chile, causing slight damage but no casualties.
corp1: Office of the Chilean Public Prosecutor
target1: Chilean Public Prosecutor's office in Santiago, Chile
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Molotov cocktails were used in this attack.
addnotes: The Chilean Public Prosecutor's office was a plaintiff in the proceedings against Augusto Pinochet.
scite1: “Chilean public prosecutor's office attacked,” Madrid EFE, December 7, 2000.
scite2: “Chile: Public prosecutor's office in Santiago firebombed,” Madrid EFE, December 7, 2000.

summary: 12/15/2000: Three members of the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) attacked Wilson Borja, president of the Federation of State Workers, as he was leaving a parking lot in Bogota, Colombia.  The assailants, armed with automatic assault rifles, shot and wounded Borja, his driver, and his bodyguard.  A female vendor and another man were killed in the shooting; authorities suspect that the dead man may have been one of the attackers.  A few days later, a commander with AUC took responsibility for the attack, claiming that it was an abduction attempt, not an assassination attempt.
target1: Wilson Borja, president of the Federation of State Workers
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Carlos Castano, commander of the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC), accused Borja of being a member of the National Liberation Army (ELN).  As such, Castano sees Borja as an "actor in the conflict" and a "military objective".
weapdetail: Automatic assault rifles
addnotes: While the assailants state that the incident was an attempted abduction, the intended victims state that it was an attempted assassination.
scite1: Andrew Selsky, "Shootout in Bogota leaves 2 dead, prominent Colombian wounded," Associated Press, December 15, 2000.
scite2: "Top Colombia labor leader shot, two others killed," Reuters, December 15, 2000.
scite3: Javier Baena, "Rightist paramilitary boss admits his men shot Colombian labor leader," Associated Press, December 20, 2000.

location: On a highway near Quipile, 45 miles northwest of Bogota
summary: 12/18/2000: Unidentified gunmen shot and killed Alberto Elias Torres, the mayor of Quipile, on a highway near Quipile, Cundinamarca, Colombia. At least one other person, Torres' driver, was wounded in the attack.  No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Alberto Elias Torres, the mayor of Quipile
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, Colombian mayors have been increasingly targeted.
addnotes: One source states that only the driver was wounded, while another source states that the driver and another man were injured.
scite1: "Mayor of central Colombian city murdered," Xinhua News Agency, December 19, 2000.
scite2: "Nineteenth Colombian mayor killed this year," Reuters, December 19, 2000.
scite3: "World wide," The Wall Street Journal, December 19, 2000.

location: Los Cerezos hamlet, 10 miles south of Bogota
summary: 12/17/2000: Suspected members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) killed 11 people in Chipaque village, Cundinamarca, Colombia.  Witnesses report that the assailants arrived in the village with a list of names and accused those on the list of cooperating with a paramilitary group.
motive: Witnesses report that the assailants accused the victims of cooperating with a paramilitary group
scite1: "11 slain in massacre in Colombia," Associated Press, December 17, 2000.
scite2: "Foreign - 11 killed in Colombian massacre," Pakistan Press International, December 18, 2000.
scite3: "Eleven peasants killed near Bogota, three near Buenaventura," El Tiempo, December 18, 2000.

location: Darien Gap between Colombia and Panama
summary: 3/16/2000: Two British men, Paul Winder and Tom Hart Dyke, were kidnapped while hiking in the Darien Gap area of Colombia.  The two were released unharmed nine months later on December 10, 2000.  The captives did not know the purpose of the abduction or who had kidnapped him, although the abductors did ask for a five million dollar ransom for each of them at one point.
target1: Two British hikers, Paul Winder and Tom Hart Dyke
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the abductors did ask for a ransom at one point but did not pursue it.
weapdetail: No mention of specific weapons was made
scite1: Andrew Selsky, "Two Britons freed in Colombia after 9 months captivity," Associated Press, December 20, 2000.
scite2: "Two Britons released after nine-month Colombia kidnap," Reuters, December 20, 2000.
scite3: "Two Britons return home after Colombia kidnap ordeal," Agence France-Presse, December 21, 2000.

location: At a crossroads between Florencia city and the jungle
summary: 12/19/2000: Members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) assassinated a congressman near Florencia, Caquetá department, Colombia.  Diego Turbay, the president of the peace commission and a member of the opposition Liberal party, was in his vehicle  at crossroads when FARC soldiers attacked.  After puncturing the tires, the assailants forced Turbay, his mother, a friend, and four bodyguards to lie facedown on the road before shooting each of them in the head.  Turbay had been deeply involved in peace negotiations designed to put an end to the civil war in Colombia.
target1: Diego Turbay, the president of the peace commission and a member of the opposition Liberal party
target2: A friend and a family member of Diego Turbay
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, Diego Turbay was deeply involved in peace negotiations that aimed to end the civil war in Colombia
weapdetail: The victims were shot while laying facedown on the ground
scite1: Scott Wilson, "Rebels kill key Colombian Congressman," The Washington Post, December 30, 2000.

location: Between Florencia and a rebel enclave
summary: 12/29/2000: Diego Turbay, the president of the peace commission of the lower house of congress, was shot and killed near the town of Doncello, Caqueta state, Colombia.  In addition to Turbay, at least six others were killed, including his mother and several bodyguards.  Turbay and his entourage were ambushed as they traveled from Florencia to Puerto Rico; assailants forced them to stop their vehicle and then opened fire.  Authorities attribute the attack to Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).
target1: Diego Turbay, the president of the peace commission of the lower house of congress
target2: Civilians in the company of Diego Turbay
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, Turbay was leading the commission that sought to facilitate dialogue between the Colombian government and the rebels.
propcomment: The tires on an armored vehicle were punctured
addnotes: Sources provide different accounts concerning the number of victims and whether all of the victims were from Turbay's entourage or were random motorists.
scite1: "Colombian lawmaker assassinated by armed group," Agence France-Presse, December 29, 2000.
scite2: Javier Baena, "Congressman involved in peace talks assassinated in Colombia," Associated Press, December 29, 2000.
scite3: Jude Webber, "Update 2 - Colombia congressman assassinated, FARC blamed," Reuters, December 29, 2000.

summary: 1/8/2001: Paramilitaries killed three farmers in Valle province, Colombia.  According to authorities, the farmers were wearing sneakers that had been part of a shipment stolen by Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) two weeks prior.  Authorities believe that the paramilitaries targeted the farmers for possible connections to FARC.
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, authorities believe that the farmers were targeted because they were wearing shoes that had come from a shipment that the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) had hijacked.
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
addnotes: Sources imply that the attack may have taken place near Restrepo.
scite1: "Twenty murdered in attacks across Colombia attributed to paramilitaries," Agence France-Presse, January 10, 2001.
scite2: "Colombia violence leaves 35 dead," Agence France-Presse, January 10, 2001.

location: The victims were taken 180 miles northeast of Bogota
summary: 01/01/2001: The United Self-defense Forces of Colombia (AUC - Las Autodefensas Unidas de Colombia) kidnapped 24 peasants in Northeastern Colombia. 17 were released on January 7, 2001 after it was clear they had no connection to the guerilla organizations in the area. The fate of the rest of the hostages was unknown.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: The peasants were taken until it could be proven that they had no connections to the leftist guerrilla groups.
addnotes: The fate of the seven hostages not released with the others was not reported.
scite1: “Colombia – Kidnapping 17 Kidnap Victims Freed in Northern Colombia,” EFE News Service, January 7, 2001.
scite2: “Paramilitary Group Releases 17 Peasants it Captured Earlier This Week,” Associated Press, January 7, 2001.

location: In a rural area of Antioquia, northwestern Colombia
summary: 1/3/2001: Approximately 100 suspected paramilitary members attacked the village of Yolombo, Antioquia, Colombia.  They shot and killed 11 members of the village whom they suspected were guerrilla sympathizers.  No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: Sources report that the assailants were killing the villagers because they suspected them of cooperating with guerrilla forces
scite1: "At least 11 murdered in northwest Colombia," Agence France-Presse, January 4, 2001.
scite2: "Eleven killed in northwestern Colombia town," Reuters, January 4, 2001.
scite3: Michael Easterbrook, "Colombia envoy on mission that could decide fate of peace talks," Associated Press, January 4, 2001.

location: Between El Penol and Guatape, 142 miles from Bogota
summary: 1/5/2001: Unidentified gunmen shot and killed at least 12 people near Guatape, Antioquia state, Colombia.  The assailants pulled the victims from the house and shot those they suspected of collaborating with rivals.  Authorities suspect that the attack may have been perpetrated by members of United Self-Defense Groups (AUC).
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: The assailants went from house to house looking for villagers they suspected had cooperated with a rival group.
addnotes: Sources provide different locations for the incident.  One source states it occurred in Guatape while other sources state it occurred between El Penol and Guatape.  In addition, sources differ in the number of fatalities; counts range between 12 and 13 victims.
scite1: "Thirteen die in second regional massacre," Associated Press, January 5, 2001.
scite2: "Twelve dead in second Colombia massacre in two days," Reuters, January 5, 2001.
scite3: "Twelve Colombian farm workers killed - paramilitaries suspected," Radio Cadena Nacional, January 5, 2001.

location: The attack occurred in the eastern Arauca Department which borders the country of Venezuela.
summary: 01/06/2001: Members of the National Liberation Army (NLA) were suspected of dynamiting a section of the Cano Limon-Covenas oil pipeline in the Arauca Department, Colombia. The attack did not result in any casualties and the extent of damage was not reported.
target1: A section of the Caño Limón-Coveñas pipeline
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The Caño Limón-Coveñas pipeline travels 780 kilometers to Coveñas on Colombia's Caribbean coastline. The Colombian oil company Empresa de Petroleos de Colombia (Ecopetrol) and the U.S. company Occidental Petroleum Inc. jointly own the pipeline.
scite1: Center For Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July, 7 2006.
scite2: “Rebels Sabotage Cano Limon Pipeline,” Business News Americas, January 8, 2001.
scite3: “ELN Blaimed for Cano-Limon Pipeline Attack,” El Colombiano, January 8, 2001.

summary: 01/06/2001: One individual was killed while 10 were wounded in a bomb attack on the town of Barrancabermeja, Colombia. Authorities believe that attack was carried out by the National Liberation Army (NLA), but no one has claimed responsibility.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombia-Bomb Child Killed, 10 Wounded in Colombian Bomb Attack,” EFE News Service, January 6, 2001.
scite2: “Violence Without Mercy Continues in Barrancabermeja,” El Espectador, January 8, 2001.

summary: 01/17/2001: Fifty members of the United Self-defense Forces of Colombia (AUC - Las Autodefensas Unidas de Colombia)  attacked a village in Chengue, Colombia. Estimates are that between 24 and 28 were killed with machetes, stones and sledgehammers.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The group also used heavy stones and sledgehammers.
addnotes: Casualty numbers for this incident conflict across sources. Following GTD protocol, the most reliable estimates are reported here.
scite1: Scott Wilson, “Chronicle of a Massacre Foretold; Colombian Villagers Implicate Army in Paramilitary Strike,” Washington Post, January 28, 2001.
scite2: “Death Toll From Chengue Paramilitary Attack Put at 28; Mayor Calls For Aid,” British Broadcasting Corporation, January 23, 2001.
scite3: “Castano Confirms Paramilitary Responsibility for Massacres in Sucre Cauca,” El Tiempo, January 19, 2001.

location: The northeastern port city of Barrancabermeja
summary: 1/8/2001: Unidentified gunmen killed eight people in Barrancabermeja, Santander Department, Colombia.  No group has claimed responsibility for the attack; however, authorities are attributing the attack to right-wing paramilitaries.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Barrancabermeja is the location of the country's largest petroleum refinery.
scite1: "Twenty murdered in attacks across Colombia attributed to paramilitaries," Agence France-Presse, January 10, 2001.
scite2: "Colombia violence leaves 35 dead," Agence France-Presse, January 10, 2001.

location: 150 miles northwest of Bogota
summary: 1/9/2001: Members of the National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN) kidnapped 56 people at a roadblock near Barbosa, Antioquia, Colombia.  Government forces attacked the guerrillas on January 10, 2001, and freed the captives.  One assailant was killed; all of the hostages were released unharmed.
target1: Civilians stopped at a roadblock outside of Barbosa
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the attack occurred during a time of increased fighting between the ELN and government forces
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
addnotes: Sources report that within seven minutes of the rescue helicopters landing, the guerrillas had fled and the hostages were secure.
scite1: Will Weissert, "Colombia's army rescues 56 guerrilla-held kidnap victims," Associated Press, January 10, 2001.
scite2: Jason Webb, "Update 1 - Colombian army rescues 56, rebels kidnap 13," Reuters, January 10, 2001.
scite3: "Political & civil unrest - Colombia," Lloyd's Information Casualty Report, January 12, 2001.

summary: 1/9/2001: Unidentified assailants killed five people near Carmen de Viboral, Antioquia, Colombia.  No group has claimed responsibility for the attack; however, authorities attribute the attack to right-wing paramilitaries.
target1: Civilians located near Carmen de Viboral
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
scite1: "Twenty murdered in attacks across Colombia attributed to paramilitaries," Agence France-Presse, January 10, 2001.
scite2: "Colombia violence leaves 35 dead," Agence France-Presse, January 10, 2001.

location: Near the Venezuelan border
summary: 1/9/2001: Approximately 15 assailants killed four people in Cucuta, Norte de Santander, Colombia.  No group has claimed responsibility for the attack; however, authorities attribute the attack to members of the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC).
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
scite1: "Twenty murdered in attacks across Colombia attributed to paramilitaries," Agence France-Presse, January 10, 2001.
scite2: "Colombia violence leaves 35 dead," Agence France-Presse, January 10, 2001.

location: The incident occurred in the El Tesoro neighborhood
summary: 01/10/2001: A car bomb containing 40 kilograms of dynamite exploded in the basement of Medellin shopping mall, El Tesoro. One person was killed, 51 were injured, 20 buildings were damages and 260 vehicles were damages. No one has claimed the attack.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The perpetrators used 40 kg of dynamite.
propcomment: 20 buildings and 260 vehicles were damaged.
scite1: “Explosion Leaves 50 Injured in Medellin Shopping Mall,” EFE, January 11, 2001.
scite2: “One Dead, 51 Wounded in Final Tally of Colombian Car Bomb Blast,” Agence France Presse, January 11, 2001.
scite3: “Bomb Blast in Colombia Injures at Least 50,” Xinhua General News Service, January 11, 2001.

location: A hamlet named Corral de Piedra
summary: 1/13/2001: At least 40 suspected members of United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) stormed the hamlet of Corral de Piedra outside of San Juan del Cesar, Guajira, Colombia.  The assailants proceeded to pull at least four people from their houses before shooting them.  No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, sources speculate that the attackers were looking for sympathizers of leftist guerrillas.
weapdetail: Assault rifles
scite1: "Gunmen terrorize poor neighborhoods in northern Colombia, killing eight," Associated Press, January 14, 2001.
scite2: "Death squad kills eight in Colombian cattle town," Reuters, January 14, 2001.
scite3: "Colombia - Violence 15 people killed by death squads in Colombia," EFE News Service, January 14, 2001.

summary: 1/13/2001: At least 40 suspected members of United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) stormed a house in a poor neighborhood outside of Valledupar, Cesar, Colombia.  The assailants proceeded to kill three people in the house and injure another two.  Before leaving the area, the attackers threw a grenade into local grocery store, damaging it and a nearby house and car.  No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Civilians in the vicinity of Valledupar
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, sources speculate that the attackers were looking for sympathizers of leftist guerrillas.
weapdetail: Assault rifles and grenades
propcomment: A grocery store was destroyed and a house and vehicle were damaged
scite1: "Gunmen terrorize poor neighborhoods in northern Colombia, killing eight," Associated Press, January 14, 2001.
scite2: "Death squad kills eight in Colombian cattle town," Reuters, January 14, 2001.
scite3: "Colombia - Violence 15 people killed by death squads in Colombia," EFE News Service, January 14, 2001.

location: In a village outside of Popayan, approximately 450 kilometers southwest of Bogota
summary: 1/15/2001: Twenty suspected members of the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) clad in military uniforms stopped a bus in a village outside of Popayan, Cauca, Colombia.  The gunmen forced the passengers off the bus, killed ten of them and wounded the driver.  The remaining passengers fled.
target1: Civilians on a bus outside of Popayan
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, sources speculate that the assailants were targeting people they believed were collaborating with leftists.
weapdetail: 9mm and .38-calibre pistols
addnotes: The assailants made the passengers lie down on the ground before shooting them.  One of the victims was a former police officer.
scite1: "Rightist gunmen kill 10 as government pledges to combat militias," Associated Press, January 15, 2001.
scite2: "10 dragged off bus, executed," Daily Telegraph, January 17, 2001.
scite3: "Colombia - Massacre alleged paramilitary troops kill ten Colombian peasants," EFE News Service, January 15, 2001.

location: The village of Chengue in northern Colombia
summary: 1/17/2001: Approximately 50 suspected members of a right-wing paramilitary group killed 25 men in Chengue village, Sucre, Colombia.  The assailants entered the village at 3 am, gathered together 25 of the local male villagers, and killed them with gunfire and machetes.  The gunmen then set fire to approximately 30 homes and abducted seven of the remaining male villagers.  Witnesses report that the assailants accused the victims of collaborating with leftist guerrillas.
motive: Witnesses report that the assailants accused the victims of collaborating with leftist guerrilla groups
weapdetail: The victims were shot and hacked to death with machetes and homes were set on fire
propcomment: Approximately 30 houses and shops were set on fire
addnotes: One sources states that the victims were hacked to death with machetes while another sources states they were also shot.
scite1: "25 Colombians slain in presumed paramilitary attack," Agence France-Presse, January 17, 2001.
scite2: Michael Easterbrook, "Suspected rightists kill 25 with machetes before torching village," Associated Press, January 17, 2001.
scite3: Luis Jaime Acosta, "Update 1 - Machete massacre as Colombia tries to revive talks," Reuters, January 17, 2001.

location: The mayor's office in Jurado Public Square
summary: 1/18/2001: Henry Perea Torres, the mayor of Jurado, was dragged out of his office by gunmen in Jurado, Choco, Colombia.  The two assailants brought him outside then shot him twice in the head.  Authorities believe that the attack was perpetrated by members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).  Torres had canvassed for the return of Jurado residents following a FARC occupation in 1999.
target1: Henry Perea Torres, mayor of Jurado
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, sources note that Torres had been canvassing for the return of Jurado residents following an occupation by FARC in 1999.
weapdetail: Pistols
addnotes: Jurado residents fled following the assassination.
scite1: Ibon Villelabeitia, "Mayor killed as Colombia bids to renew peace talks," Reuters, January 18, 2001.
scite2: "Mayor murdered in Colombia," Xinhua News Agency, January 19, 2001.
scite3: "Panama shelters Colombia refugees after mayor shot," Reuters, January 26, 2001.

location: 130 miles from Bogota
summary: 1/19/2001: Suspected members of the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) killed six people in Santa Barbara, Antioquia, Colombia.  The specific motive is unknown.
target1: Civilians in the vicinity of Santa Barbara
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: No mention of weapons was made
scite1: Javier Baena, "Six dead in massacre in Colombia; U.N. calls situation 'alarming'," Associated Press, January 19, 2001.
scite2: Jared Kotler, "Colombian government failed to heed warnings of paramilitary massacre," Associated Press, January 19, 2001.
scite3: "World headlines," Dayton Daily News, January 20, 2001.

location: In Floresta, a neighborhood west of Buenos Aires
summary: 1/20/2001: Two unidentified assailants on a motorcycle threw an improvised explosive device at a mosque in Floresta, a neighborhood west of Buenos Aires, Argentina.  The device rebounded off the Islamic library, damaging the windows and gates of the building.  A police officer patrolling the area was also injured in the explosion.  The officer fired several shots at the fleeing assailants but it is unknown whether the assailants were injured.  No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: A mosque in Floresta, a neighborhood west of Buenos Aires
target2: A police officer in the vicinity of the mosque
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, authorities indicate that the incident was motivated by religious intolerance.
weapdetail: A homemade bomb
propcomment: The explosion damaged the windows and gate of the Islamic library
addnotes: It is unclear whether a library or a bookstore was damaged in the explosion.
scite1: "Bomb explodes in Argentine mosque, one injured," Reuters, January 20, 2001.
scite2: "Police officer killed in attack on Argentine mosque," Agence France-Presse, January 20, 2001.
scite3: "Police officer seriously injured in attack on mosque," Associated Press, January 20, 2001.

location: Santa Helena, in the outskirts of Medellin
summary: 1/23/2001: Teresa Gomez Pineda was kidnapped by members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) near Madellin, Antioquia, Colombia.   FARC demanded two million dollars from her family for her safe return; they were unable to pay.  She was killed sometime in June or July and buried in Santa Helena, although FARC continued to demand ransom.  An ex-FARC member alerted police to her death in November and her body was exhumed around November 22, 2001.
motive: FARC asked for a monetary amount for the safe release of the captive.
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
addnotes: It is unclear where the abduction took place.  It is also unclear how the victim was killed.
scite1: "Colombia - Guerrillas FARC accused of demanding ransom from murdered woman's family," EFE News Service, November 22, 2001.

location: On the banks of a river in Hato Nuevo, near the Venezuelan border
summary: 1/28/2001: Unidentified gunmen killed at least ten people and wounded five in Hato Nuevo, Guajira, Colombia.  The assailants opened fire on a group of people unprovoked.  No group has claimed responsibility and motive is unknown.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Sources provide different reports concerning the number of wounded and dead.
scite1: Michael Easterbrook, "Military investigates alleged failure to prevent massacre," Associated Press, January 28, 2001.
scite2: "Colombia - Massacre eleven killed in Colombian holiday resort attack," EFE News Service, January 28, 2001.
scite3: "Political & civil unrest - Colombia," Lloyd's Information Casualty Report, January 30, 2001.

location: The town of Hato Nuevo, near the Venezuelan border
summary: 1/28/2001: Unidentified gunmen attacked the town of Hato Nuevo, La Guajira department, Colombia.  The assailants killed at least ten people and wounded another five.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident and it is not clear who perpetrated the attack; the area is inhabited by both right-wing paramilitary squads and leftist guerrillas.
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, this was the second attack of it's kind in as many weeks.
addnotes: Following the incident, residents accused the army of failing to protect villagers
scite1: "World: In brief," The Washington Post, January 29, 2001.

location: The incident occurred in the airspace between San Vincente and Bogota.
summary: 01/30/2001: A hijacker briefly took control of a plane which took off from San Vicente in Colombia. He held the pilot at gunpoint but was disarmed shortly after by a passenger. He was believed to be a dissenter of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC).
target1: Flight between San Vicente and Colombia
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The hijacker used a pistol during this attack.
addnotes: The hijacker was believed to be a dissenter of Armed Revolutionary Forces of Colombia.
scite1: Martin Dayani, “Colombian Airline Hijacked,” United Press International, January 30, 2001.
scite2: Margarita Martinez, “Gunman Hijacks Plane With At Least 30 Aboard,” Associated Press, January 30, 2001.
scite3: “Hostages Freed in Colombia After Hijacker is Overpowered: Report,” Agence France Presse, January 31, 2001.

summary: 02/04/2001: A car bomb exploded in Tame, a Colombian town on the border with Venezuela, at a place close to where Transportation Minister Alvaro Canal was visiting. At least 12 houses were destroyed in the bombing, but there were no casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: At least 12 houses were destroyed.
addnotes: Colombian authorities could not confirm that the attack was directed at Canal given that the explosion occurred some blocks from where he was visiting.
scite1: “Car Bomb in Town on Border With Venezuela Causes Damage, No Casualties,” NOTIMEX, February 4, 2001.

location: 217 miles north of Bogota
summary: 2/4/2001:  A bomb attached to a motorcycle exploded in Saravena, Arauca Department, Colombia.  One man was killed in the explosion and two children were injured.  The military believes that the explosion was intended to target Reveiz Pizarro Battalion troops.  Authorities blamed the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) for the incident.
target2: Civilians in the vicinity of the motorcycle
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the military believes that the target of the attack was troops from the Reveiz Pizarro Battalion who were in the area protecting repair work conducted on a pipeline that guerrillas had blown up several days prior.
weapdetail: The explosive device was attached to a motorcycle
addnotes: While two sources report that a man died, one source only reports the two injured children.  One source states that the dead man was mistakenly identified as an assailant by earlier media reports.
scite1: "Bombs explode in northern Colombia; one dead, two children injured," Associated Press, February 4, 2001.
scite2: "Colombia - Conflict one dead, five wounded in terrorist attacks in N.E. Columbia," EFE News Service, February 4, 2001.
scite3: "Security stepped up after bombings in northeastern area," Notimex, February 4, 2001.

location: In the business centre of Quito
summary: 2/4/2001: A bomb exploded outside of an office building in Quito, Pichincha, Ecuador.  The explosion blasted a hole in the sidewalk, shook the building, and broke windows; however, no one was hurt.  The building was home to several news agencies, an oil company, and a financial institution; the intended target is unknown.  No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: An office building in Quito that housed several news agencies, a government office, and a bank.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: A crater was blown in the sidewalk and windows were broken
scite1: "Bomb hits office in Ecuador's capital, no injuries," Reuters, February 5, 2001.
scite2: "Political & civil unrest - Ecuador," Lloyd's Information Casualty Report, February 6, 2001.

summary: 02/05/2001: Suspected members of the National Liberation Army (NLA) killed retailer Eduardo Quinones Gomez, as he was trying to escape a roadblock to avoid being kidnapped. The attackers kidnapped another retailer at the same roadblock and stole a truck. No group claimed responsibility for the attacks.
target1: Eduardo Quinones Gomez and another man in Rionegro
motive: One victim was killed because he tried to escape from an attempted kidnapping.
propcomment: A truck was stolen during the attack.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 5 Feb,” Radio Cadena Nacional Television, February 5, 2001.

summary: 02/06/2001: Armed men identified as paramilitaries have kidnapped ecologist Julio Enrique Santamaria as he was making a presentation to campesinos near Tayrona National Park, Colombia. No group claimed responsibility for the kidnapping.
target1: Julio Enrique Santamaria, a Colombian ecologist
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Julio Enrique Santamaria was a former member of the 19 April Movement who had received amnesty from the government during the guerrilla group's reintegration process. He was currently involved in reforestation projects in the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta region.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities - 6 February,” Caracol Television, February 6, 2001.

summary: 02/06/2001: The National Liberation Army (NLA) kidnapped 12 people at a roadblock in La Gloria, Colombia. A swift Colombian Army response resulted in the rescue of seven of the hostages. Five of the hostages remained in the guerrillas’ captivity, including a Korean resident of Cartagena. No group claimed responsibility for the kidnappings.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities - 6 February,” Caracol Television, February 6, 2001.

location: Between Puerto Wilches and Sabanas de Torres
summary: 02/06/2001: Guerrillas attacked the Cristalina Ranch, located between the municipalities of Sabanas de Torres and Puerto Wilches, Colombia. The rebels attacked the ranch with gas cylinder bombs, killing three women and six men. Local authorities believed that the leader of the nongovernmental organization Civil Association for Peace in Colombia, Asocipaz was one of the attackers. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
gname: Civil Association for Peace in Colombia, Asocipaz
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Gas cylinder bombs were used in the attack.
scite1: Claudia Garro, “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities - 6 February,” Inravision Television Canal Uno, February 6, 2001.

location: Approximately 40 kilometers west of Medellin
summary: 2/5/2001:  Right-wing paramilitary members shot and killed five peasants in a small village near Heliconia, Antioquia, Colombia.  The military-clad assailants dragged the victims from their homes and executed them, accusing them of collaborating with rebels.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Peasants in a small village near Heliconia
motive: The assailants accused the victims of collaborating with rebels before they executed them.
weapdetail: The victims were shot "execution-style"
scite1: "Gunmen kill 14 people in Colombian twin attacks," Reuters, February 6, 2001.
scite2: "News summary EFE news round-up for February 6 (1700 GMT)," EFE News Service, February 6, 2001.

location: The Free University in eastern Cucuta
summary: 2/12/2001: Approximately ten unidentified gunmen shot and killed Ivan Villamizar as he was leaving the Free University in eastern Cucuta, Norte de Santander, Colombia.  Villamizar was a university president and a former government human rights official who investigated and denounced paramilitary massacres.  As he was leaving the university, the gunmen opened fire on his vehicle, injuring two of his bodyguards and the driver.  Villamizar attempted to flee, but was surrounded by the gunmen and killed.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Ivan Villamizar, an university president and a former government human rights official who investigated and denounced paramilitary massacres.
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, Villamizar received numerous death threats from right-wing paramilitary groups, likely stemming from his denouncement of their tactics.
addnotes: Villamizar had moved to Bogota due to death threats but had only just returned to Cucuta the year previous, believing that the threat had passed.
scite1: "Former Colombian ombudsman, humanitarian assasinated," Agence France-Presse, February 13, 2001.
scite2: Jaren Kotler, "Colombian general convicted in paramilitary massacre," Associated Press, February 13, 2001.
scite3: "Gunmen kill Colombian rights monitor," Reuters, February 12, 2001.

location: A ravine near Purace National Park
summary: 2/2/2001: Nine hikers were found shot execution-style in a ravine near Purace National Park, Cauca Department, Colombia.  The hikers had began their week-long hike on February 2 and were not heard from again.  Authorities speculate that it may have been a purely criminal act; however, the attack happened in an area of heavy guerrilla activity.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Nine hikers near the Purace National Park
motive: Specific motive is unknown; the attack may have been purely criminal in nature (the belongings of the victims were missing) or it may have been politically oriented.
weapdetail: The victims were shot execution-style
addnotes: One source states that the victims were not heard from again after February 2nd, while another says February 4th.  A third source states that the estimated time of death was Saturday, but it is unclear if this refers to February 3rd or February 11th.  In addition, it is unclear whether the hikers were kidnapped, or simply attacked.
scite1: Margarita Martinez, "In latest Colombian tragedy, nine hikers slain near national park," Associated Press, February 14, 2001.
scite2: "Nine hikers found shot dead in Colombian park," Reuters, February 14, 2001.
scite3: "Hikers shot dead in Colombia," The Independent, February 14, 2001.

summary: 2/15/2001: Raul Benoit, a U.S. journalist with Univision, escaped unharmed from an assassination attempt in Cali, Valle del Cauca, Colombia.  Benoit was leaving his car when two gunmen opened fire on him.  The gunmen and Benoit's bodyguards exchanged fire; one of the bodyguards and one of the perpetrators were wounded in the exchange.  The wounded gunman was taken into custody; it was discovered that he was a police officer.  The specific motive is unknown.
target1: Raul Benoit, a U.S. journalist with Univision
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the target had just finished an exclusive interview with the leader of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).  In addition, Benoit had been targeted in the past for presenting Colombia in a negative light.
addnotes: Benoit says that he has had to leave Colombia six times due to death threats and normally has six bodyguards with him
scite1: "TV reporter escapes apparent assassination attempt," Associated Press, February 15, 2001.
scite2: "Colombia arrests policeman in journalist attack," Reuters, February 15, 2001.
scite3: "Colombia-based US journalist escapes assassination attempt," Xinhua News Agency, February 16, 2001.

summary: 02/20/2001: Unknown perpetrators used four gas cylinders in an attack against the Jose Maria Cordova Military Academy for Cadets in Bogota, Colombia. The explosions resulted injuries to at least 20 civilians. Six city blocks sustained damage in the attack. A wall and some windows were damaged on the Academy’s campus. No group claimed responsibility for the attack, although local authorities suspected the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC).
corp1: The Jose Maria Cordova Military Academy for Cadets
target1: The Jose Maria Cordova Military Academy for Cadets in Bogota and the surrounding area
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The gas cylinders, each weighing 100 lbs and loaded with gunpowder and shrapnel, were in two parked Mazda vehicles. Through a fuse system, four cylinders were fired against the academy. Another two were defused an hour after the explosions.
propcomment: Six blocks of houses and businesses near Jose Maria Cordova Military Academy for Cadets sustained damage. An academy wall was damaged in the attack as well.
addnotes: A similar attack against the Jose Maria Cordova Military Academy for Cadets occurred on 16 April 1999. The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) militiamen were responsible for the attack in April 1999.
scite1: “About 20 civilians hurt as cylinder bombs hit Bogota military academy,” BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, February 23, 2001.

location: A highway on the outskirts of Bogota
summary: 2/22/2001: At least eight unidentified assailants kidnapped Chikao Muramatsu, vice president of a joint venture of the auto parts maker Yazaki Ciemel, as he was driving on a highway on the outskirts of Bogota, Distrito Capital, Colombia.  The kidnappers, dressed as police officers, flagged down Muramatsu's car, took custody of Muramatsu and his driver, and sped off with them.  The driver was later released.  The assailants handed Muramatsu over to the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC), who began negotiations for his release three weeks following the abduction.
target1: Chikao Muramatsu, vice president of a joint venture of the auto parts maker Yazaki Ciemel
motive: The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) is asking for a ransom for the safe return of Chikao Muramatsu.
weapdetail: There was no specific mention of weapons
addnotes: It is unknown what happened to Muramatsu; FARC did ask for a ransom payment but the amount of that demand and whether it was paid is not reported.  In addition, it is unclear whether FARC were the actual kidnappers or whether the kidnappers gave or sold Muramatsu to FARC.  If the latter, this would not constitute a terrorist event, but a purely criminal act.
scite1: "Japanese businessman kidnapped in Colombia," Kyodo News, March 9, 2001.
scite2: "Police mum on kidnap of Japanese executive," Associated Press, March 15, 2001.
scite3: "British consultants negotiating in kidnapping of Japanese," Kyodo News, March 12, 2001.

location: The Pasto airport in Narino province
summary: 3/1/2001: Two bombs exploded at the Pasto airport in Narino province, Colombia.  The first explosion occurred at the end of the landing strip, leaving a deep crater in the runway.  The second explosion occurred at the airport fire station; it demolished parts of the building and a vehicle.  The airport closed following the explosion.  There were no reports of casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the incident and the motive is unknown.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Two bombs placed at the landing strip and the fire station
propcomment: A big crater was blown into the landing strip and a good portion of the fire station was demolished, as was a vehicle in the vicinity of the fire station
addnotes: Sources state that there were no reports of causalities; however, they do not mention whether there were any reports of injuries.
scite1: "Two bombs explode at Pasto Airport in Colombia," Xinhua News Agency, March 2, 2001.
scite2: "Bomb blasts damage landing strip, fire station at Pasto Airport," Caracol, March 1, 2001.

location: The center of Socorro town, 270 kilometers northeast of Bogota
summary: 3/20/2001: Gonzalo Rodriguez Bautista was shot and killed by at least one gunman in Socorro, Santander province, Colombia.  Bautista is the brother of Nicolas Rodriguez, the leader of the National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN); other than through his brother, Bautista has no connections with guerrilla groups or activities.  The assailant fled following the shooting; however, one man named Roberto Tirado was arrested a few hours later in connection with the attack.  The motive behind the shooting is unknown.
target1: Gonzalo Rodriguez Bautista, the brother of the leader of the National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN)
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the victim was the brother of the leader of the National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN) and the attack occurred a few hours after government officials stated they expected talks to resume with the guerrilla group.
addnotes: Sources provide varying accounts concerning the number of assailants and how they fled the scene.  Reports range from one assailant to a squad of assailants and from a drive by shooting to an on-foot attack followed by an escape on a bus.
scite1: Javier Baena, "Amid peace efforts, brother of Colombia rebel leader assassinated," Associated Press, March 20, 2001.
scite2: "Colombia - Violence gunmen murder brother of Colombian rebel leader" EFE News Service, March 20, 2001.
scite3: "Colombia - Violence Colombian police arrest alleged killer of ELN chief's brother," EFE News Service, March 21, 2001.

summary: 03/03/2001: Members of the 37th Front of The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) killed two policemen and injured two more during an attack on telecommunications towers in the town of San Nepomuceno in Northern Colombia. A civilian woman was killed in the attack as well. The attack targeted a police garrison that was guarding the towers. The perpetrators did not damage the towers during the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Police garrison guarding telecommunication towers in San Nepomuceno
motive: Unknown
scite1: "FARC Attack to Hilltop Communication Facility Leaves Two Policemen, One Woman Dead,” EFE, March 03, 2001.

summary: 3/3/2001: Members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) and National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN) kidnapped ten people in Colombia.  Among the ten captives were a motorcycle racing champion and two police bodyguards.  Four of the hostages were later released.  The motive behind the abduction is unknown.
target1: Civilians, including a famous motorcycle racing champion
target2: Police officers guarding a motorcycle racing champion
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
addnotes: Four of the ten hostages were released; it is unknown what was the outcome for the remaining six hostages.  In addition, it is unclear whether there were ransom demands made.
scite1: Javier Baena, "Six killed, others kidnapped in weekend violence in Colombia ," Associated Press, March 4, 2001.

location: On Venezuela de Cartagena Avenue
summary: 3/4/2001: A bomb exploded outside of a bank in Cartagena, Bolivar province, Colombia.  The device was remote-controlled and was activated by two men driving in a vehicle in the vicinity of the bank.  No one was injured in the incident; however, the bank was damaged.  No group has claimed responsibility and the motive is unknown.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A remote-controlled bomb
propcomment: A bank was damaged in the explosion
scite1: "Wave of bomb attacks injures three in Colombia," Agence France-Presse, March 4, 2001.
scite2: Javier Baena, "Six killed, others kidnapped in weekend violence in Colombia," Associated Press, March 4, 2001.
scite3: "Sinking deeper/ Bush administration should give some serious thought to limiting aid to Colombia," The Gazette, March 9, 2001.

location: Going to Valledupar, about 30 miles south of the company mine in Loma.
summary: 3/12/2001: Unidentified gunmen killed the President and Vice President of the coal company Drummond Ltd.'s union as they traveled on a bus toward the company mine near Chiriguana, in the northern Cesar province of Colombia.  Valmore Locarno Rodriguez, the President, was killed immediately after being taken off the bus, while Victor Orcasita, the Vice President, was kidnapped and later killed.  No group claimed responsibility.
corp1: Two union executives with Drummond Ltd.
target1: Victor Orcasita and Valmore Locarno Rodriguez
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources note that Drummond Ltd. had been targeted by FARC, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, in the past to get money by extortion methods.  The company oversaw the Loma mine, which is the second most productive coal mine in Colombia.  Over 116 executives in the labor industry had been killed in 2000.  Sources also note that both paramilitary groups and guerrillas were in the area at the time of the attack.
addnotes: Drummond Ltd. was a Birmingham, Alabama based company.  It was unclear if the two victims were American or Colombian.  The two men were traveling on a bus filled with individuals who worked at the Loma mine.  When the gunmen halted the bus, they made the workers identify the two men and then watch as the men were killed and kidnapped.  It was unclear how long Orcasita was missing before he was killed.  No mention of a ransom demand or payment was made in the sources.
scite1: "Colombian gunmen kill union leaders for US coal firm," Reuters, March 13, 2001.
scite2: "President, Vice President of workers union of Drummond coal company murdered," Inravision, March 13, 2001.
scite3: "Colombian politicians decry drugs war tactics," The Scotsman, March 14, 2001.

summary: 03/19/2001: A German businessman was kidnapped by about twenty suspected leftist rebels in Tolima, Colombia. The outcome of the kidnapping was unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the kidnapping.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The German hotel manager was married to a Colombian woman and had lived in Tolima for 18 years.
scite1: "German Businessman Kidnapped in Colombia,” Deutsche Presse-Agentur, March 19, 2001.

location: The headquarters of the Latin American Economic Research Foundation (FIEL) on 637 Cordoba Avenue in the Retiro neighborhood of the Buenos Aires downtown area
summary: 03/19/2001: A homemade pamphlet bomb exploded at 4:30am outside the headquarters of the Latin American Economic Research Foundation (FIEL), a non-profit organization, in the Retiro neighborhood of Buenos Aires, Argentina.  The newly-appointed Argentinian Economic Minister used to work in the headquarters office.  An unknown group called the Rodolfo Walsh National Command claimed responsibility for the incident in the pamphlets that were strewn around the area after the explosion.  No one was injured in the explosion, although the glass windows of the FIEL headquarters were shattered.
target1: Latin American Economic Research Foundation in Buenos Aires
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources note that the newly-appointed Argentinian Economic Minister used to work at the headquarters office that was targeted in this bombing.  According the sources, the pamphlets strewn about in the explosion protested the austerity plan being implemented by the Minister, which included cuts of eight billion dollars in federal assistance, health and education programs.  This plan was an attempt to pull the country out of its current state of recession.
weapdetail: Although the type of explosive used was unclear, sources note that the bomb was homemade and placed in a shoebox filled with pamphlets protesting the austerity plan.  According to sources, these pamphlets said: "'Enough surrendering.  You are faithful to the empire of this (FIEL) foundation, an assembly line cranking out sell-outs.  Leave or we'll throw you out.  Fatherland or death.  Rodolfo Walsh National Command."
propcomment: Sources mention that the windows of the FIEL headquarters shattered in the explosion.
addnotes: One of the sources noted that an "urban commando" was responsible for the explosion, but no further details were provided.  The sources also provide a brief background on Rodolfo Walsh, the name used in the group claim.  Walsh was an author who disappeared after writing a letter on violence by dictators in 1977.
scite1: "Economic think tank targeted in bomb attack," EFE News Service, March 19, 2001.
scite2: "Small bomb blast rattles foundation of new Argentine economy chief," Agence France-Presse, March 19, 2001.
scite3: "Explosive device goes off at foundation to which leading members of Argentine economic team belongs," Telam News Agency, March 19, 2001.

location: On Street 4 in Centrol Residencial Los Vikingos in Northern Colombia, north of Bogota by 900km
summary: 03/22/2001: Unidentified gunmen shot and killed Dr. Jairo Romero Bonilla, a man who used to be the mayor of resort town Tolu, near his office in Sincelejo, Caribbean region, Colombia.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources note that two mayors of Tolu, including Romero, had been killed and that over 20 Colombian mayors had been killed in the past year.  Sources note that the area is heavily populated with paramilitaries and insurgents.
addnotes: It was unclear if Romero was killed in or near his office.  Witnesses say the gunmen arrived at the office on bicycles.  Sources note that the position of mayor had been taken from Romero after it was suggested he had mishandled funds belonging to the public.
scite1: "Former mayor of Tolu murdered by assassins," El Heraldo, March 23, 2001.
scite2: "Former mayor of Tolu murdered in Sincelejo by persons unknown," Notimex News Agency, March 23, 2001.

location: A Llorente plaza
summary: 03/24/2001: Thirty villagers were kidnapped by members of the United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia, who were armed with guns and knives, in the early morning in a plaza in Llorente, Narino province, Colombia.  It was unclear if the thirty villagers had been killed.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
target1: Villagers in the city of Llorente
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, the source notes that the suspected paramilitary members had been displaced from their base of operations due to American-supported spraying of cocoa fields in the area.
addnotes: Villagers in Llorente said that the paramilitary individuals made some of them identify other villagers who had worked with rebels in the area.
scite1: Juan Forero, "30 villagers presumed dead after paramilitary raid in Colombia," New York Times, March 31, 2001.

summary: 03/25/2001: Five people, including two women, were shot dead after being kidnapped from residences in an unnamed community of farmers in Colombia, near the Venezuelan border.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack, but the sources blamed the attack on a death squad sent by a paramilitary group.
target1: Private citizens in a community of farmers
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, death squads were known to be active in the area.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
scite1: "16 Colombians die in attacks," Orlando Sentinel, March 26, 2001.

location: In the Soledad area
summary: 04/02/2001: An unidentified gunman shot and killed Ricardo Orozco, Colombian Hospital Workers' Union vice president, as he was leaving his residence in Barranquilla, Colombia, and going to work.  Although no group claimed responsibility for the attack, sources note that Orozco was being targeted by paramilitary members of a death squad in the area due to his status as an activist.
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources note that Orozco was being targeted by members of a death squad with paramilitary connections due to his status as an activist.
weapdetail: The suspect was seen leaving the scene with a pistol.
addnotes: Sources note that the gunman was being pursued by local authorities after fleeing the scene of the shooting in a vehicle.
scite1: "Clashes in Colombia kill 35 - union leader slain," Reuters, April 2, 2001.
scite2: "Union leader assassinated in Colombia," Agence France-Presse, April 3, 2001.

summary: 04/14/2001: United Self-defense Forces of Colombia (AUC - Las Autodefensas Unidas de Colombia) militants killed 25 farmers in Alto Nayo, Colombia in an apparent political vendetta.
target1: Indiscriminate farmers in Alto Nayo, Colombia
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: The attacks were perpetuated in order to punish the villagers for aiding rebels.
weapdetail: The specific type of gun used in this incident was not reported.
scite1: “Colombian paramilitary blamed for killings of 25 civilians,” Deutsche Presse-Agentur, April 14, 2001.
scite2: “Self-Defense Groups Kill 25 Peasants in Northern Cauca Department,” Bogota Caracol Colombia Radio, April 14, 2001.

summary: 04/16/2001. The National Liberation Army (NLA) kidnapped 92 Occidental Petroleum employees in Arauca, Colombia. Seventy-three of the hostages were released the following day, 17 April and the remaining hostages were released on 19 April. An ELN commander claimed responsibility for the incident in a telephone call to foreign news correspondents, saying that they were starting a sabotage campaign against Occidental because they were pillaging the Indian people of the area.
target1: Workers of an Occidental Petroleum plant in Arauca, Colombia
motive: The ELN claimed to have kidnapped the persons because the ELN was starting a sabotage campaign against Occidental for their pillaging of the Indian people in the area.
weapdetail: The specific type of gun used in this incident was not reported.
addnotes: Seventy-three of the hostages were released the following day, 17 April and the remaining hostages were released on 19 April.
scite1: “ELN’s Pablo Beltran: Oxy Kidnapping “Temporary Political Detention,” Paris AFP to Mexico Central America and the Caribbean, April 18, 2001.
scite2: “All but 19 oil workers freed in Colombia; Kidnapping: Hostages are contract workers for a U.S. company,” Telegraph Herald, April 18, 2001.
scite3: MIPT Terrorism Knowledge Base. "TKB Incident Page: National Liberation Army (Colombia) Attacked Business Target (Apr. 16, 2001, Colombia).” Website. Available from http://www.tkb.org/Incident.jsp?incID=8324.

summary: 04/23/2001: Unidentified attackers in a white van drove up to the main office of the People's National Congress/Reform opposition party in Georgetown, Guyana, around 11:30pm and opened fire on the building, shooting at it and throwing what was thought to be a fire bomb.  No one was injured in the attack, although minor damage was done to the building.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Opposition party's main office in Georgetown
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources noted that the attack occurred less than one day before the leader of the People's National Congress/Reform oppositional party was to meet with Guyana's President to discuss ending widespread violence in the area after recent elections took place.
