weapdetail: Sources note that the building was both fired upon and bombed.  The armed gunmen were thought to have carried out the attack from a white van.  While one source says that the building was attacked with a fire bomb, another source says witnesses claimed the building was bombed by a chickpea bomb.
propcomment: Damage was done to the building's storeroom by fire, thought to be started by the bomb.
scite1: Bert Wilkinson, "Opposition party's headquarters attacked in Guyana," Associated Press, April 24, 2001.
scite2: "Tension after main opposition party's HQ reportedly attacked," Cana News Agency, April 24, 2001.

summary: 04/25/2001: Approximately 250 militants from Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)attacked the Alto de San Juan village, Colombia. Fifteen people died as a result the incident where FARC fighters and members of the Peasant Self-Defense Groups of Cordoba and Uraba (ACCU) clashed. Residents also stated that FARC fighters took a large number of cattle and some horses owned by local people during the incident.
target1: Civilians from the Alto de San Juan village, Colombia
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The specific type of gun used in this incident was not reported.
scite1: “FARC Attack Town in Uraba,” Medell Colombiano, April 27, 2001.
scite2: “Colombian Paramilitary activities,” Medellin el Colombiano, April 27, 2001.

summary: 04/28/2001: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels killed 21 people in the village of San Pedro de Uraba, Colombia, for alleged collaboration with rightist paramilitary forces.
target1: Indiscriminate civilians in San Pedro de Uraba, Colombia
motive: FARC reportedly carried out the attack against the village for its alleged collaboration with rightist paramilitary forces.
weapdetail: The specific type of gun used in this incident was not reported.
scite1: “At least 30 people killed in leftist rebel attacks in Columbia,” Deutsche Presse-Agentur, April 28, 2001.
scite2: “Bogota TV Highlights 301730,” Bogota Inravision Television Canal Uno, April 30, 2001.

location: South of Bogota by 230 miles
summary: 05/01/2001: Two unidentified gunmen on motorcycles shot and killed Hector Polania, who was previously a Conservative Party politician, and wounded one of his bodyguards as they traveled on a highway in Pitalito, Huila department, Colombia.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack and no mention of property damage was made.
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, the source notes that the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) were responsible for violence in the area, including a previous assassination of a congressman.  The source also notes that Polania had escaped a previous kidnapping attempt two years previously.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided, although the source does say the two gunmen were on a white motorcycle at the time of the shooting.
scite1: "Former ruling party politician killed by gunmen in Colombia," Associated Press, May 2, 2001.

summary: 05/04/2001: Four people were killed and at least twenty-five more were wounded when a bomb comprised of 110 pounds of explosives and placed in a Chevy pickup truck detonated in the parking lot of the Hotel Torre de Cali in Cali, Valle del Cauca department, Colombia around 7pm.  Among those guests injured at the hotel were the coach and several members of the Once Caldas professional soccer team.  Severe damage was done to the first floor of the hotel, twenty stories of the hotel had their windows blown out, several cars in the area were badly damaged, and buildings four blocks from the explosion had windows broken.  Witnesses saw a vehicle being pushed into the hotel parking lot by two men shortly before the explosion.  One source reported that the National Liberation Army (ELN) of Colombia claimed responsibility for the attack in a fax sent to a radio station, but this was not confirmed among the other sources.
target1: Hotel Torre de Cali and its guests
target2: Citizens and property in the vicinity of the explosion
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, one source speculated that if the ELN was responsible, it was due to frustration over the inability to declare peace with the government because of the actions of militias in the area.  Other sources speculate that as Cali was the site of a big soccer tournament and the Once Caldas were currently guests of the hotel, the bombing was meant to target them.  Sources also speculated that the target might have been the police station across the street from the hotel.
weapdetail: One of the sources describes the bomb as being comprised of 110 pounds of dynamite and placed in a Chevy pickup truck in the parking lot.
propcomment: The first floor of the hotel was destroyed and 20 stories of the hotel had their windows blown out.  Vehicles in the vicinity were set on fire by the explosion, and buildings up to four blocks away had broken windows.
addnotes: One of the sources mentions that the ELN claimed responsibility, but this claim was not confirmed by the other sources.  Witnesses in the vicinity of the explosion saw a vehicle being pushed into the hotel's parking lot by two men shortly before the explosion.  The Hotel Torre de Cali was the tallest building in Cali.  Reports conflicted as to the number injured, with an earlier report saying eight people, while the two later reports said twenty-five and thirty-people were injured.
scite1: "Car bomb in Colombia hotel parking lot kills four," Associated Press, May 4, 2001.
scite2: "Cali car-bomb kills at least four," EFE News Service, May 5, 2001.
scite3: Phil Stewart, "Car bomb rips through Colombia hotel, 32 injured," Reuters, May 5, 2001.

summary: 5/14/2001: At least 190 workers were kidnapped by at least 80 armed members of the United Self-defense Forces of Colombia (AUC) in Villanueva, in the province of Casanare, Colombia, under suspicion of being spies.  The workers were taken off the buses they were traveling on towards their homes after leaving the farms they worked on.  All but twenty-six of the workers were released the following day, while the remaining hostages were released after two days of captivity.  All were uninjured.  The AUC claimed responsibility for the attack over the Caracol radio station.
corp1: Workers on their way home from local farms
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: The AUC claimed that they were investigating all of the workers under suspicion of spying.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
addnotes: One of the sources says that 190 people were kidnapped while another says that 210 people were kidnapped.  This was the largest mass-abduction ever perpetrated in Colombia.
scite1: Jose Ramos, "Colombian paramilitaries kidnap 190 farm workers," Agence France-Presse, May 17, 2001.
scite2: Carlos Osorio, "Colombian paramilitaries release all hostages," Agence France-Presse, May 18, 2001.
scite3: Eoin Callan and James Wilson, "Hostages set free in Colombia," Financial Times, May 18, 2001.

location: The National Election Board offices in Lima
summary: 05/16/2001: At least six people, including a mother, her infant child, and three police officers, were wounded when a bomb exploded outside of the National Election Board offices in Lima, Lima region, Peru around 10am.  The bomb had been left in a backpack outside of the offices, and had detonated after police had picked it up, carried it some distance from the building, and then noticed smoke was coming from the backpack.  Conflicting reports emerged regarding the organization responsible for the attack, as pamphlets were supposedly left at the scene claiming that the Shining Path organization was responsible.  This claim was refuted by at least one individual, purportedly a Shining Path member named Comrade Juana, when she called into a local radio station.  Sources reported damage to the windows and door of a store near the explosion.
target1: The National Election Board office and upcoming elections
target2: At least one store damaged in the explosion
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources note that the attack occurred on the anniversary of the day when the Shining Path began their war against the government of Peru twenty-one years earlier.  Sources also note that the area was due to have elections soon.
weapdetail: The sources describe the bomb as being in a backpack, and emitting smoke shortly before it detonated.  No other detail was provided.
propcomment: At least one store near the explosion had damage done to its windows and front door.
addnotes: The sources conflicted as to the number of people injured in the explosion.  Some of the sources said seven people were wounded, but the most current source said six were injured.
scite1: "Bomb blast in Peru injures seven," Agence France-Presse, May 17, 2001.
scite2: "Bomb explodes near headquarters of Peru's elections board, injuring seven," The Canadian Press, May 16, 2001.
scite3: "Bomb explosion injures six in Peru," Channelnewsasia, May 18, 2001.

location: Lleras square in Medellin's El Poblado neighborhood
summary: 05/17/2001: Eight people were killed and at least 137 were injured when a car bomb consisting of 66 pounds of dynamite was detonated remotely in Lleras square, a crowded business area, in El Poblado, Medellin state, Colombia around 10pm.  One source estimated the damage to the area's stores and cars to be around $400,000.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack, although authorities thought that this attack might have been due to a fight between rival gangs in the area.  Witnesses to the bombing saw four people, two men and two women, exiting the vehicle shortly before it exploded.
corp1: The Lleras square businesses and patrons
target1: Businesses and patrons in the crowded Lleras square area
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources noted that there was an ongoing war between a local drug gang and a group of paramilitary members.
weapdetail: Sources describe the bomb as containing 66 pounds of dynamite, remotely triggered after being left in a car.
propcomment: One source says that the damage done to the area's cars and stores was at least $400,000.
addnotes: Authorities in the area increased security after the attack.
scite1: "Car bomb blast kills seven in Colombia," Agence France-Presse, May 18, 2001.
scite2: Margarita Martinez, "Government beefs up security in Colombian city following deadly bombing," Associated Press, May 19, 2001.
scite3: Ibon Villelabeitia, "Gang feud seen behind deadly Colombian car bomb," Reuters, May 18, 2001.

summary: 05/21/2001: An MK-82 bomb attached to around 500 pounds of TNT and four devices to detonate the TNT was found buried under fruit in a Chevy truck that was left outside the headquarters of Voz communist newspaper in Bogota, Distrito Capital department, Colombia.  The bomb was deactivated by police, although authorities said that the bomb would not have detonated the way it was set up.  No one was injured and no physical damage was done.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
corp1: Citizens and property in the vicinity of the explosion
target1: Citizens and property near the Chevy truck with the bomb
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources note that several other bombs had been detonated in the area recently, killing and injuring many.  One of the sources also notes that the head of the Voz newspaper had been elected to head a group tasked with ending violence in the area.
weapdetail: The bomb was an MK-82, a bomb used by the United States military's airplanes.  The bomb was attached to around 500 pounds of TNT explosives and four detonators.  The bomb was left in a Chevy pick-up truck, buried under fruit.  Authorities said that the bomb would not have detonated even though it was rigged as it was, as it was only meant to detonate when dropped from an airplane.
addnotes: Authorities in the area increased security after the bomb was found and defused.
scite1: Jared Kotler, "Colombia says bomb in Bogota aimed to scare, not explode," Associated Press, May 22, 2001.
scite2: Phil Stewart, "Fear sweeps Colombia as car bombs back in vogue," Reuters, May 22, 2001.
scite3: "Colombia police deactivate car bomb in Bogota," Xinhua News Agency, May 22, 2001.

location: The incident occurred at the National University of Colombia
summary: 05/25/2001: Two bombs exploded 10 minutes apart from each other in front of Bogotá’s National University during rush hour, killing 4 people and injuring about 20 others. The authorities were hesitating between leftist guerilla armies, drug traffickers, or a growing rightist paramilitary.
target1: Inhabitants of Bogota, in front of Bogota's National University
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Bombs kill 4, injure more than 20 in Bogota,” Contra Costa Times, May 26, 2001
scite2: “Bombs Kill 4 in Colombian Capital,” The Washington Post, May 26, 2001

location: The mountains in northeast Colombia
summary: 05/28/2001: At least nine bodies, thought to belong to local farmers, were found in the mountains in northeast Colombia.  The bodies had all been decapitated.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident, though sources noted that paramilitary groups were active in the area.
motive: Although the specific motive for this attack was unknown, sources noted that paramilitary groups were active in the area and responsible for the killing of many citizens.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
addnotes: It was unclear whether these individuals had been kidnapped prior to their killing.  The sources suggest that these beheaded individuals might have been local farmers recently kidnapped, but this was just speculation.
scite1: "Nine Colombian farmers found decapitated in northern countryside," Associated Press, May 28, 2001.
scite2: "Decapitated bodies found," Belfast News Letter, May 30, 2001.
scite3: "Nine Colombian farmers slain in northern countryside, officials say," The Canadian Press, May 28, 2001.

summary: 05/30/2001: Civilians in unspecified locations of Cordoba Department, Colombia were attacked by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC). The assailants burned houses and decapitated twenty four individuals.
target1: Civilians living in Cordoba Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The assailants used some sort of a sharp object to decapitate the victims.
propcomment: Many houses were burned and destroyed during the attack.
scite1: Santiago, Gustavo, "Colombia: FARC Reportedly Massacre 24 Peasants in Cordoba," Bogota Caracol Colombia Radio, May 31, 2001.

summary: 06/15/2001: At least 16 people were injured when a car bomb exploded in San Martin, Meta State, in southeast Colombia. No one was killed in the explosion which also caused enormous material damage in the municipality. Police said the car, containing 100 kilograms of dynamite, was parked close to the San Martin police station. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A witness said two men parked the car in a street near the police station and abandoned it shortly before the bomb went off. The car contained 100 kilograms of dynamite.
propcomment: The blast caused damage to many public buildings, the police station, two schools, some artistic and cultural buildings as well as the local mayor's office and about 100 houses.
addnotes: The attack may have been one of two related incidents (cf. 200106150002). The car bomb explosion was reminiscent of terrorist attacks in other Colombian cities a month earlier which left 12 people dead and 200 injured.
scite1: “At Least 16 Injured in Car Bomb Blast in Colombia,” Xinhua General News Service, June 16, 2001.

summary: 06/15/2001: A car bomb exploded in the city of Barrancas located on the north coast of Colombia. There were no casualties, but the explosion caused important material damage to nearby buildings. The vehicle, loaded with explosives, was abandoned in a neighborhood of the city and was activated through remote control. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Civilian neighborhood in the city of Barrancas
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The vehicle, loaded with explosives, was abandoned and activated through remote control.
propcomment: The blast caused serious material damage to nearby buildings.
addnotes: The attack may have been one of two related incidents (cf. 200106150001). The car bomb explosion was reminiscent of terrorist attacks in other Colombian cities a month earlier which left 12 people dead and 200 injured.
scite1: “At Least 16 Injured in Car Bomb Blast in Colombia,” Xinhua General News Service, June 16, 2001.

location: Between Pereira and San Jose del Palmar, in the state of Risaralda
summary: 6/25/2001: Armed gunmen, thought to be members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC), kidnapped Hernan Mejia, the Colombian Soccer Federation's Vice President and organizer of the America Cup Colombia 2011 competition, outside Pereira, Risaralda state, Colombia.  Hernan was released unharmed several days later.  Before his release, the Federation was discussing cancelling the tournament, but after Hernan's release it was thought that the competition would continue.
motive: Although the specific motive for this attack was unknown, FARC was active in the area in their continued conflict with the government.
weapdetail: Although sources said the men were armed, it was unclear what type of weapons they carried.
addnotes: One of the sources mentions that 20 other people were kidnapped at the same time but this was not confirmed by the other sources.
scite1: "Colombian Soccer Federation vice president kidnapped," Xinhua News Agency, June 26, 2001.
scite2: Yadira Ferrer, "Americas Cup on hold, soccer official in rebel hands," Inter Press Service, June 27, 2001.
scite3: "FARC's release of football official raises hopes of cup reprieve," Caracol Radio website, June 28, 2001.

summary: 06/26/2001: A dynamite attack staged by suspected guerrillas of the 10th Front of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)on an electric tower in Cano La Pava, at Kilometer 89 of the Cano Limon-Covenas pipeline in Arauca Department, Colombia, left 250,000 residents of Arauca Department (the municipalities of Arauca, Arauquita, Saravena, Tame, Puerto Rondon, Fortul, and Cravo Norte) without electricity. The explosion melted the cables between Towers 286 and 287 of the 230-kw line, which is part of the national network between the Los Palos station in Bucaramanga and Arauca.
target1: An electric tower in Cano La Pava, Arauca Department, at Kilometer 89 of the Cano Limon-Covenas pipeline, where the oil pipeline runs parallel to the power line.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bomb was made of dynamite.
propcomment: The explosion melted the cables between Towers 286 and 287 of the 230-kw line, which is part of the national network between the Los Palos station in Bucaramanga and Arauca. This left without electricity some 250,000 residents of Arauca Department (including the municipalities of Arauca, Arauquita, Saravena, Tame, Puerto Rondon, Fortul, and Cravo Norte.)
addnotes: This attack may have also adversely affected the Cano Limon oil complex, even though production previously had been paralyzed due to the guerrilla attacks.
scite1: “Colombia: Electrical Towers Dynamited in Arauca, Antioquia,” El Tiempo, June 28, 2001.

summary: 06/27/2001: A dynamite attack was staged on five electrical towers in northern Medellin in Antioquia Department, Colombia. The attack left without electricity parts of Medellin and Rionegro municipalities.
target1: Five electrical towers in northern Medellin in Antioquia Department
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The explosion was caused by a dynamite attack.
propcomment: Five electricity towers were blown up, which left parts of Medellin and Rionegro without electric power.
addnotes: Guerillas had blown up over 600 electricity towers since 1999. Most of the attacks on the power infrastructure and the pipelines were staged by the Army of National Liberation.
scite1: “Colombia: Electrical Towers Dynamited in Arauca, Antioquia,” El Tiempo, June 28, 2001.

summary: 07/06/2001: Unidentified gunmen on a motorcycle shot and killed Jose Dubiel Vasquez, the director of news for the Voice of the Jungle Radio program, as he was leaving the radio station in Florencia, Caqueta state, Colombia.  Although no group claimed responsibility for the attack, sources noted that Vasquez was the second official from the radio station to be killed in less than a year.
corp1: Voice of the Jungle Radio program
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources note that Vasquez was the second official from the radio station to be killed in less than a year.  Furthermore, the killing of journalists in the area was common.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
addnotes: One of the sources said that a colleague was with Vasquez at the time of the attack, but was not injured.  This claim was not confirmed by the other source.  The Voice of the Jungle Radio program was associated with Radio Caracol.
scite1: "Radio news director killed in southern Colombia," Associated Press, July 7, 2001.
scite2: "Colombian radio journalist assassinated," Xinhua News Agency, July 7, 2001.

summary: 11/07/2001: Mireya Mejia Araujo, a commissioner for peace in the Department of Cesar, was kidnapped by members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC), as she drove through a rural area outside of La Nevadita, Cesar Department, Colombia.  The group later made demands, which included $150,000 in exchange for Castro's release.  The government claimed they would not pay the ransom, but did engage in negotiations with FARC.
motive: The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) demanded a ransom of $150,000.  They had several other demands, including that they not be considered terrorists any longer by the government.  They were in the midst of peace talks with the government at the time of the kidnapping.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
addnotes: The hostage was released on November 29, 2001.
scite1: Luis Jaime Acosta, "Colombian FARC rebels kidnap peace commissioner," Reuters, November 9, 2001.
scite2: "Peace counselor kidnapped in Colombia," Amarillo.com, July 11, 2001.
scite3: "FARC make 105,000-dollar ransom demand for niece of Araujo Noguera," El Espectador website, November 15, 2001.

summary: 07/15/2001: Militants belonging to the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)kidnapped Alan Jara a former governor of the Meta Department while he was riding in a UN vehicle in Lejanias.
target1: Alan Jara, the former Governor of Meta District
motive: The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)believed that Alan Jara had been a right-wing paramilitary leader.
addnotes: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) spokesman, Carlos Antonio Lozada, demanded that a popular trial be held for the governor whom FARC believed was responsible for murders and massacres in the Meta Department.
scite1: "Top Colombian rebel group admits kidnapping ex-governor," Agence France Presse, July 19, 2001.
scite2: "Colombian Rebels Kidnap Former Governor," CanWest Interactive, July 17, 2001.
scite3: "FARC's Eastern Bloc Admits Kidnaping of ex-Meta Governor," Inravision Television Canal, July 19, 2001.

summary: 07/17/2001: Eduardo Estrada Gutirrez, the president of the Association for the Development of Communications and Culture was assassinated at the El Binomio restaurant in San Pablo, Colombia by a paid assassin. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Eduardo Estrada Gutirrez, the president of the Association for the Development of Communications and Culture
motive: Unknown
scite1: "President of ADECOSAN Assassinated," El Espectador, July 17, 2001.
scite2: "President of communications and culture association assassinated," British Broadcasting Corporation, July 18, 2001.

summary: 07/18/2001: German Technical Cooperation Agency workers Hurlich Kuenzel, Thomas Kuenzel and Reiner Bruchmann, were kidnapped by members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)outside of Silvia, Colombia. A spokesman from FARC said that the Germans would not be released until there was an end to aerial sprayings of chemicals on indian and peasant plots in the Cauca Department.
target1: Hurlich Kuenzel, Thomas Kuenzel and Reiner Bruchmann, German Technical Cooperation Agency workers
motive: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)wanted to end aerial sprayings of chemicals on Indian and peasant plots in Cauca Department.
scite1: "Three German nationals kidnapped in Colombia," Agence France Presse, July 19, 2001.
scite2: "Three Germans Kidnapped by Suspected Rebels in Colombia," Xinhua News Agency, July 19, 2001.
scite3: "FARC Reportedly Conditions Germans' Release to Spraying Suspension," Bogota Caracol Television, July 20, 2001.

summary: 07/23/2001: Jose Vladimir Acero Delgado was kidnapped outside his ranch in Tachira State, Venezuela by four assailants. He was taken into the jungle and was able to escape 18 hours later when his abductors fell asleep.
target1: Jose Vladimir Acero Delgado, a Venezuelan ranch owner in Tachira State
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Venezuelan Business Owner Taken In Another Tachira State Kidnapping," La Nacion, July 23, 2001.
scite2: "Most Recent Kidnap Victim in Venezuela's Tachira State Escapes," La Nacion, July 24, 2001.

summary: 07/25/2001: A home-made bomb exploded in a confessional injuring a woman and damaging the church in Caracas, Venezuela. No group claimed responsibility for the attack. Two more devices were found after the attack but they did not go off.
target1: Church of San Francisco in central Caracas
target2: A Civilian attending confessions at the Church of San Francisco in central Caracas
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Home-made bomb explodes inside church in Caracas, one injured," Deutsche Presse Agentur, July 25, 2001.
scite2: "Home-made bomb explodes in confessional, woman injured," EFE, July 25, 2001.

summary: 07/27/2001: Members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)kidnapped 16 people in a raid on a luxury residential building in Neiva, Colombia. Six were released shortly thereafter.
target1: Residents of a luxury housing building in the southern city of Neiva
motive: FARC rebels kidnapped the civilians for ransom.
addnotes: 6 of the 16 hostages were freed within 24 hours of the kidnapping.  3 of the victims were the wife and two children of Colombian senator Jairo Lozada Perdomo.
scite1: "Colombian Guerrillas Kidnap 15 People," Xinhua News Agency, July 27, 2001.
scite2: "Leftist rebels release six kidnap victims in Colombia," Deutsche Presse Agentur, July 27, 2001.
scite3: Michael Easterbrook, "Rebels carry 10 kidnap victims to demilitarized zone for ransom, police say," The Associated Press, July 28, 2001.

location: This incident occurred on a highway connecting Medellin and Bogota.
summary: 08/00/2001: A bridge was destroyed in a bombing by members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) on highway connecting Bogota and Medellin, Colombia. No casualties were reported in connection with this incident.
target1: Bridge on the Bogota - Medellin highway in Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: A bridge was destroyed in the attack.
addnotes: ELN's acts during 2001 were widely seen as a response to president Andres Pastrana's decision to suspend peace talks with the movement.
scite1: “Colombian guerrillas target electricity supply,” United Press International, August 13, 2001.

location: This incident occurred near Remedios.
summary: 08/00/2001: The National Liberation Army (ELN) bombed a portion of the OCENSA pipeline near the municipality of Remedios, in northwest Antioquia Department, Colombia. No casualties were reported in connection with this incident.
target1: Portion of the OCENSA pipeline near Remedios, Antioquia Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: A portion of pipeline was destroyed in the attack.
addnotes: ELN's acts during 2001 were widely seen as a response to president Andres Pastrana's decision to suspend peace talks with the movement.
scite1: “Colombian guerrillas target electricity supply,” United Press International, August 13, 2001.

location: This incident occurred near San Pablo.
summary: 08/00/2001: Over sixty peace activists were kidnapped by armed paramilitaries from the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) near San Pablo in Bolivar Department, Colombia. The victims included nationals of 11 countries. They sought to deliver the goods to a zone controlled by the National Liberation Army (ELN). No injuries were reported in connection with this incident.
target1: Group of peace activists near San Pablo, Bolivar Department, Colombia
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Possibly to prevent the re-supplying of an area dominated by the National Liberation Army (ELN).
scite1: Brian Denny, “Paramilitaries kidnap 60 foreigners,” Morning Star, August 9, 2001.
scite2: “International Affairs,” PAP News Wire, August 9, 2001.

summary: 08/03/2001: A bomb was found and defused in the Caracas home of former Venezuelan president Carlos Andres Perez.
target1: Former Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez
motive: According to reports, officials claimed that this bombing was part of a growing conspiracy to destabilize President Hugo Chavez's government.
scite1: Alexandra Olson, “Bomb Threats Alarm Venezuelans,” Associated Press Online, August 4, 2001.
scite2: Vincent K. Willis, “AP Top News at 5 a.m. EDT Saturday, Aug. 4, 2001,” Associated Press Online, August 4, 2001.

summary: 08/05/2001: An unknown number of explosives were placed at a branch of the state-owned Filanbanco in Quito, Ecuador by unidentified perpetrators. Of six bombs placed in four branches throughout the country, only three exploded, causing minor property damage and no injuries.
motive: The attack may have been related to the fact that Filanbanco had been recently shut down due to bankruptcy.
propcomment: The bank sustained minor damage.
scite1: “Police confirm bomb attacks against bankrupt bank in Ecuador,” Deutsche Presse-Agentur, August 7, 2001.

summary: 08/05/2001: An unknown number of explosives were placed at a branch of the state-owned Filanbanco in Guayaquil, Ecuador by unidentified perpetrators. Of six bombs placed in four branches throughout the country, only three exploded, causing minor property damage and no injuries.
motive: The attack may have been related to the fact that Filanbanco had been recently shut down due to bankruptcy.
propcomment: The bank sustained minor damage.
scite1: “Police confirm bomb attacks against bankrupt bank in Ecuador,” Deutsche Presse-Agentur, August 7, 2001.

summary: 08/05/2001: An unknown number of explosives were placed at a branch of the state-owned Filanbanco in Portoviejo, Ecuador by unidentified perpetrators. Of six bombs placed in four branches throughout the country, only three exploded, causing minor property damage and no injuries.
motive: The attack may have been related to the fact that Filanbanco had been recently shut down due to bankruptcy.
propcomment: The bank sustained minor damage.
scite1: “Police confirm bomb attacks against bankrupt bank in Ecuador,” Deutsche Presse-Agentur, August 7, 2001.

summary: 08/05/2001: Approximately 25,000 people were left without telephone service after a group of unidentified armed men blew up two Telecom exchange boxes in the Lz Esperanza neighborhood of Barrancabermeja, Santander Department, Colombia. No casualties resulted from the attack.
target1: Two telephone exchange boxes in the La Esperanza of Barrancabermeja, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Two telephone exchange boxes were destroyed.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities -- 6 Aug,” FBIS, August 7, 2001.

summary: 08/05/2001: Approximately 25,000 people were left without telephone service after a group of unidentified armed men blew up a Telecom exchange box in the Primero de Mayo neighborhood of Barrancabermeja, Santander Department, Colombia. No casualties resulted from the attack.
target1: Telephone exchange box in the neighborhood of Primo de Mayo in Barrancabermeja, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: A telephone exchange box was destroyed.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities -- 6 Aug,” FBIS, August 7, 2001.

summary: 08/05/2001: Approximately 25,000 people were left without telephone service after a group of unidentified armed men blew up a Telecom exchange box in the Alcazar neighborhood of Barrancabermeja, Santander Department, Colombia. No casualties resulted from the attack.

summary: 08/05/2001: Argemiro Medina Amaya, the Community Action Board President of San Pablo, Colombia, was shot and killed in a raid by the United Self Defense Forces of Colombia (AUC).
target1: Community Action Board president of San Pablo, Colombia, Argemiro Medina Amaya
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities -- DDMM,” FBIS, August 8, 2001.

summary: 08/06/2001: Major Jhon Fredy Rios, a police commander, was shot and wounded from a passing taxi in a presumed United Self Defense Forces of Colombia (AUC) attack as he was walking along the El Recreo neighborhood of Barrancabermeja, Colombia dressed in civilian clothes. A civilian was also injured in this attack.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: It was suspected that the attack was a reprisal for the continued operations against the AUC.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 9 Aug,” FBIS, August 10, 2001.

summary: 08/06/2007: Eight members of the Ejercito Revolucionario del Pueblo (ERP) kidnapped six people from Cordoba Corregimiento, Sucre department, Colombia, using a red Ford 350 truck driven by Santiago Cuello Chamorro, who was intimidated into helping the rebels.
motive: Rebels from the ERP faction usually perpetrated holdups in farms and carried out kidnappings in order to later negotiate the hostages with larger insurgent groups like the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (cf. 200108060007-09). The victims included: Nestor Barrios Romero, Elder Barreto Acuna, Jaime Sierra Martinez, Nurys Bolivar de Vasquez, and Alvaro Polanco Benavidez.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities -- DDMM,” FBIS, August 8, 2001.
scite2: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities -- 6 Aug,” FBIS, August 7, 2001.

summary: 08/06/2007: Eight members of the Ejercito Revolucionario del Pueblo (ERP) kidnapped three people from Arboleda Corregimiento, Sucre department, Colombia, using a red Ford 350 truck driven by Santiago Cuello Chamorro, who was intimidated into helping the rebels.
motive: Rebels from the ERP faction usually perpetrated holdups in farms and carried out kidnappings in order to later negotiate the hostages with larger insurgent groups like the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (cf. 200108060007-09). The victims included: Nestor Barrios Romero, Elder Barreto Acuna, Jaime Sierra Martinez, Nurys Bolivar de Vasquez, and Alvaro Polanco Benavidez.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities -- DDMM,” FBIS, August 8, 2001.
scite2: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities -- 6 Aug,” FBIS, August 7, 2001.

motive: Rebels from the ERP faction usually perpetrated holdups in farms and carried out kidnappings in order to later negotiate the hostages with larger insurgent groups like the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (cf. 200108060007-09). The victims included: Nestor Barrios Romero, Elder Barreto Acuna, Jaime Sierra Martinez, Nurys Bolivar de Vasquez, and Alvaro Polanco Benavidez.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities -- DDMM,” FBIS, August 8, 2001.

location: This incident occurred at a roadblock near Canaveral, Colombia.
summary: 08/07/2001: Two civilians were kidnapped at a roadblock near Canavera, Antioguia department in Colombia. The incident was a presumed Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) attack.
target1: Two civilians on a road near Canaveral, Colombia
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities -- DDMM,” FBIS, August 8, 2001.

location: This incident occurred on the road between Yarumal and Angostura in Antioquia department, Colombia.
summary: 08/07/2001: Three people were kidnapped by members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) at a roadblock between the towns of Yarumall and Angostura in Antioquia department Colombia. The hostages were local residents on a business trip to Medellin, Colombia.
target1: Three civilians on a business trip while traveling in Antioquia department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities -- DDMM,” FBIS, August 8, 2001.

summary: 08/08/2001: A bombing attack by the National Liberation Army (ELN) in San Francisco, Colombia killed three children, and wounded 35 others. ELN members also fired on a police station and nearby homes.
target2: Police station in San Francisco, Colombia
motive: The attack came a few hours after the ELN announced it would no longer negotiate with President Andres Pastrana's government.
propcomment: 27 homes collapsed in the explosion.
addnotes: Another attack was launched by the National Liberation Army on Granada, Antioquia department, Colombia, the same day. This was one of two related attacks (cf 200108080006).
scite1: “World Datelines,” Deseret News (Salt Lake City), August 9, 2001.
scite2: “Three dead, 35 injured as Colombia's ELN resumes warfare,” Agence France Presse, August 9, 2001.
scite3: “AFP World News Summary for Thursday, August 9 (since 1300 GMT),” Agence France Presse, August 9, 2001.

summary: 08/08/2001: An ambush was launched by Shining Path (Sendero Luminoso) on a police patrol in Pangoa district in Satipo province, Peru. Four policemen were killed and three wounded.
target1: A police in Pangoa district in Satipo province, Peru
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Shining Path (Sendero Luminos) activity in Peru had been relatively dormant since the capture of top rebel leaders in 1992.
scite1: “World Datelines,” Deseret News (Salt Lake City), August 9, 2001.
scite2: “World Briefs,” The Houston Chronicle, August 9, 2001.
scite3: “Police and suspected rebels clash in Peruvian jungle, leaving at least 16 dead, The Associated Press, August 8, 2001.

location: This incident took place along the highway between Gramolte and Cucuta, Norte de Santander Department, Colombia.
summary: 08/09/2001: A car bomb placed by the National Liberation Army (ELN) on August 8, 2001 was found along the highway between Gramolte and Cucuta, Norte de Santander Department, Colombia. The army was unable to defuse the bomb due to a surrounding minefield. A group of citizens, angered by the traffic jam that the vehicle was causing on the highway, decided to move it, causing the device to explode. Two people were killed and four were wounded in this incident.
target1: Civilians traveling on the highway between Gramolte and Cucuta, Norte de Santander Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Colombian President Andres Pastrana Arango suspended talks with the ELN on August 7, 2001.
scite1: “ELN Car Bomb Kills Two, Injures Four in Campoalegre,” Radio Cadena Nacional, August 9, 2001.

summary: 08/10/2001: A bomb was found and defused in a garden of a residence next to the Gladys de Freites Elementary School, in Catia, Sucre District, Venezuela. The Tupamaro Revolutionary Movement was presumed responsible. No injuries or property damage were reported.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Venezuela: Press review 10 Aug 01,” BBC Monitoring Latin America – Political, August 11, 2001.

summary: 08/10/2001: Three businessmen were kidnapped by members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) in Curumani, Cesar Department, Colombia. They were released August 14, 2001.
target1: Three Colombian Businessmen in Curumani, Cesar Department, Colombia
motive: This attack was in retaliation against the break off of peace negotiations with the Colombian government.
scite1: “Colombia's ELN rebels kidnap nine people, block major roadways,” Agence France Presse, August 15, 2001.

summary: 08/10/2001: Four people, including United Workers Federation (CUT)) Bolivar Department President Julio Carrascal, were kidnapped on the western junction highway at Maria La Baja by 30 members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) in northern Bolivar Department, Colombia. The fate of the victims was not known.
motive: This attack was in retaliation against the break off of peace negotiations with the Colombian government.
scite1: “Deadly days in Colombia following break down of peace talks,” Agence France Presse, August 11, 2001.
scite2: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 10 Aug,” FBIS, August 10, 2001.

summary: 08/10/2001: Three people were kidnapped by the National Liberation Army (ELN) in Norte de Santander Department, Colombia. The fate of the victims was not known.
target1: Civilians in Norte de Santander Department, Colombia
motive: This attack was in retaliation against the break off of peace negotiations with the Colombian government.
scite1: “Deadly days in Colombia following break down of peace talks,” Agence France Presse, August 11, 2001.

summary: 08/10/2001: Three farmers were shot and killed in a United Self Defense Forces of Colombia (AUC) attack in Algeciras, Huila Department, Colombia.
target1: Three farmers in Algeciras, Huila Department, Colombia
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: The farmers were accused of aiding leftist rebels.
scite1: “Deadly days in Colombia following break down of peace talks,” Agence France Presse, August 11, 2001.
scite2: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 10 Aug,” FBIS, August 10, 2001.

summary: 08/10/2001: Five farmers were shot and killed by a United Self Defense Forces of Colombia (AUC) member in Pitalito, Huila Department, Colombia.
target1: Five farmers in Pitalito, Huila Department, Colombia
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: The farmers were accused of aiding leftist rebels.
scite1: “Deadly days in Colombia following break down of peace talks,” Agence France Presse, August 11, 2001.
scite2: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 10 Aug,” FBIS, August 10, 2001.

location: This incident occurred near Bucaramanga along the road to Cucuta.
summary: 08/10/2001: Five vehicles, two buses of the inter-municipal service, two trailers, and a truck, were torched by 30 members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) on the Bucaramanga-Cucuta Highway, Colombia. Drivers and passengers of the vehicles were beaten and gasoline was poured on some by the insurgents. One bus driver suffered burns.
target1: Civilians on the Bucaramanga-Cucuta Highway, in Santander Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Five vehicles, two buses of the inter-municipal service, two trailers, and a truck, were torched.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 10 Aug,” FBIS, August 10, 2001.

location: This incident occurred near Arauquita, Colombia.
summary: 08/12/2001: A bombing by unidentified leftist guerrillas destroyed a portion of oil pipeline owned by Occidental Petroleum near Arauquita, Arauca Department, Colombia. No injuries were reported in connection with this incident.
target1: Portion of Oil Pipeline near Arauquita, Arauca Department, Colombia
motive: To attack oil facilities and affect the petroleum royalties, which provide a significant income for the Colombian government.
propcomment: A portion of the oil pipeline was destroyed.
scite1: “Arauquita Journal; Pipeline Goes ‘Boom!’ Local Economies Go Bust,” The New York Times, August 16, 2001.

summary: 08/12/2001: A police patrol was attacked by Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) members in Las Flores, La Guajira Department, Colombia. Five policemen were kidnapped and six were wounded in this incident. Two, Deputy Lieutenant Jaime Vizcaino Ortiz and patrolman Pedro Jose Figueredo Sierra, were killed in the course of the attack. The five were released on August 21, 2001.
target1: Police Patrol in Las Flores, La Guajira Department, Colombia.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The men released were are patrolmen Rodolfo Bermejo Teheran, 29, from Sabanalarga, Atlantico; Cipriano Mora Lopez, 25, from Riohacha; Leaxir Portela Villamizar, 26, from Santa Ana Magdalena; agents Nelson Noriega Mercado, 35, from Cienaga Magdalena; and Martin Oriol Hinestroza Rios, from Quibdo, Choco. Deputy Lieutenant Jaime Vizcaino Ortiz and patrolman Pedro Jose Figueredo Sierra, were killed in the course of the attack.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 14 Aug,” FBIS, August 14, 2001.
scite2: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 15 Aug,” FBIS, August 15, 2001.
scite3: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 21 Aug,” FBIS, August 21, 2001.

summary: 08/13/2001: Five electricity pylons were bombed by members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) in Medellin, Colombia. The explosions caused a blackout in the city. No injuries were reported in connection with this incident.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Five electricity pylons were destroyed.
addnotes: This was one of two related attacks (cf. 200108130010-11). While a specific motive was unknown, this attack was widely seen as a response to Resident Andres Pastrana's decision to suspend peace talks with the movement.
scite1: “Colombian guerrillas target electricity supply,” United Press International, August 13, 2001.
scite2: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 14 Aug,” FBIS, August 14, 2001.
scite3: “Terrorist Attacks Cause Blackouts, Affect Subway Transportation in Medellin," Caracol Colombia Radio, August 13, 2001.

summary: 08/13/2001: Four electricity pylons were bombed by members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) in Bello, Antioquia Department, Colombia. The explosions caused a blackout in the city. No injuries were reported in connection with this incident.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Five electricity pylons were destroyed.
addnotes: This was one of two related attacks (cf. 200108130010-11). While a specific motive was unknown, this attack was widely seen as a response to Resident Andres Pastrana's decision to suspend peace talks with the movement.
scite1: “Colombian guerrillas target electricity supply,” United Press International, August 13, 2001.
scite2: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 14 Aug,” FBIS, August 14, 2001.
scite3: “Terrorist Attacks Cause Blackouts, Affect Subway Transportation in Medellin," Caracol Colombia Radio, August 13, 2001.

location: This incident took place between Pailitas and Pelaya in Cesar Department, Colombia.
summary: 08/13/2001: Three tractor trailers were set ablaze by members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) between Pailitas and Pelaya in Cesar Department, Colombia. No injuries were reported in connection with this incident.
target1: Three Tractor Trailers near Pailitas in Cesar Department
motive: The attack was likely in response to the recent suspension of peace talks between the ELN and the Colombian government.
propcomment: Three tractor trailers were set ablaze in the incident.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 14 Aug," FBIS, August 14, 2001.

summary: 08/14/2001: Eighteen people were kidnapped by the National Liberation Army (ELN) in Curumani, Cesar Department, Colombia. The ELN released 14 of the victims when police and army units arrived on the scene. The fate of the remaining four was not reported. No casualties were reported in connection with this incident.
motive: The attack was likely in response to the recent suspension of peace talks between the ELN and the Colombian government.
scite1: “Colombia's ELN rebels kidnap nine people, block major roadways,” Agence France Presse, August 15, 2001.
scite2: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 15 Aug,” FBIS, August 15, 2001.

summary: 08/14/2001: Two automatic teller machines were blown up by the National Liberation Army (ELN) in Medellin, Antioquia Department, Colombia. No casualties were caused in the blast.
target1: Two Automatic Teller Machines in Medellin, Colombia
motive: The attack was likely in response to the recent suspension of peace talks between the ELN and the Colombian government.
propcomment: Two ATM's were targeted in the explosions.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 15 Aug,” FBIS, August 15, 2001.

location: This incident occurred on the Magdalena River near Bocas de Sogamoso in Colombia.
summary: 08/14/2001: A boat belonging to the San Pablo Fluvial Transportation Company with 15 occupants was stopped by 20 armed men of the National Liberation Army (ELN) near Bocas de Sogamoso. The guerrillas hijacked the boat and took with them the pilot and his assistant, who were later released. The boat was left in an area 40 minutes from the Barrancabermeja harbor where oil is shipped. Explosives were then placed in the boat and which was later was found along the Magdalena River, in Santander Department, Colombia. The explosives were defused and no casualties resulted from this attack.
target1: Boat belonging to the San Pablo Fluvial Transportation Company
target2: Captain and Assistant of the Boat
target3: Barrancabermeja Harbor
motive: The incident was part of the offensive the ELN was carrying out as a reaction to the arrival of troops in southern Bolivar Department.
addnotes: The fifteen total passengers were kept on the boat for approximately 20 minutes, then all the passengers except for the captain and his assistant were released. The captain and assistant were released at a later point in time.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 15 Aug,” FBIS, August 15, 2001.
scite2: “Boat-bomb Defused in Colombia,” Xinhua General News Service, August 16, 2001.
scite3: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 16 Aug,” FBIS, August 16, 2001.

location: This incident took place at the 40-km point on the highway to the sea between Cali and Buenaventura in Valle del Cauca Department.
summary: 08/14/2001: A roadblock was set up and two buses were burned by 80 members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) at the 40-km point on the highway to the sea between Cali and Buenaventura, in Valle del Cauca Department, Colombia.
target1: Vehicles in Valle del Cauca Department, Venezuela
motive: The attack was likely in response to the recent suspension of peace talks between the ELN and the Colombian government.
propcomment: Several vehicles were burned in the attack.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 15 Aug,” FBIS, August 15, 2001.
scite2: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 15 Aug,” FBIS, August 15, 2001.

summary: 08/14/2001: Approximately 100 members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) forced out the passengers on a Peralonso Company bus on the Gramalote-Villa Caro road, Norte de Santander Department, Colombia and placed explosives in the vehicle. Authorities found and defused the bomb the next day. No injuries resulted from this incident.
target2: Civilians in Gramolte, Norte de Santander, Colombia
motive: The attack was in response to the recent suspension of peace talks between the ELN and the Colombian government.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 15 Aug,” FBIS, August 15, 2001.
scite2: “Boat-bomb Defused in Colombia,” Xinhua General News Service, August 16, 2001.
scite3: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 16 Aug,” FBIS, August 16, 2001.

summary: 08/14/2001: In Aguachica, Cesar Department, Colombia, the National Liberation Army (ELN) set two trucks on fire and blew out the tires of four vehicles, which hindered traffic for hours along the La Paz road. No injuries were reported in connection with this incident.
target1: Vehicles on the La Paz Road, Cesar Department
motive: The attack was in response to the recent suspension of peace talks between the ELN and the Colombian government.
propcomment: Two trucks were burnt and four other vehicles had their tires shot out.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 15 Aug,” FBIS, August 15, 2001.

summary: 08/14/2001: Five people were kidnapped by the National Liberation Army (ELN) at a fake police checkpoint in Godo, located between Dabeiba and Mutata Municipalities on the Bogota-Medellin highway, in Antioquia Department, Colombia. The fate of the victims was not known.
target1: Civilians in Godo, Antioquia Department, Colombia
motive: The attack was in response to the recent suspension of peace talks between the ELN and the Colombian government.
scite1: “Colombia's ELN rebels kidnap nine people, block major roadways,” Agence France Presse, August 15, 2001.
scite2: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 15 Aug,” FBIS, August 15, 2001.

summary: 08/14/2001: Members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) targeted vehicles a roadblock in El Ventarron, San Luis Municipality, on the Medellin-Bogota highway, where two trailers were set on fire and the tires of 20 vehicles were blown out. The rebels conducted some investigations, seeking alleged enemies and potential kidnap victims. No injuries were reported in connection with this attack.
target1: Civilians traveling on the Medellin-Bogota Highway in Antioquia Department, Colombia
target2: Civilian Vehicles traveling on the Medellin-Bogota Highway in Antioquia Department, Colombia
motive: The attack was likely in response to the recent suspension of peace talks between the ELN and the Colombian government.
propcomment: Two trailers were set on fire and the tires of 20 vehicles were shot out.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 15 Aug,” FBIS, August 15, 2001.

location: This incident was described as occurring in a village near Amalfi, Colombia.
summary: 08/15/2001: Six rural workers were killed by the United Self Defense Forces of Colombia (AUC) near Amalfi, Antioquia Department, Colombia. The victims were accusing of supporting leftist rebels and were selected from a list the AUC members possessed.
target1: Civilians in a village near Amalfi in the Antioquia Department, Colombia
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: The victims were accused of supporting leftist guerrillas.
scite1: “Six dead after attack by paramilitaries in Colombia," Agence France Presse, August 15, 2001.
scite2: “Six Farmers Murdered in Colombia,” Xinhua General News Service, August 16, 2001.

summary: 08/15/2001: An act of sabotage by suspected Shining Path (Sendero Luminoso) members on two electric pylons left Ayacucho, Cangallo and Huanta, Peru without power. The electricity towers toppled after giant bolts holding them in place on concrete platforms were removed.
target1: Two Electricity Pylons Managed by Electrocentro in Ayacucho, Peru
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Two electricity pylons were toppled in the incident.
scite1: “Suspected leftist rebels blamed for blackout in Andean city,” The Associated Press, August 16, 2001.

summary: 08/16/2001: 12 people were shot and killed in the village of Santo Tomas in Antioquia Department, Colombia in a presumed United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) attack by 50 members of the group. Those killed were accused of working with leftist rebels. The gunmen also shot farm animals and set fire to homes.
target1: Civilians in Santo Toma, Antioquia Department, Colombia
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Those killed by the AUC were said to be cooperating with the administration.
propcomment: Livestock was shot and an unspecified number of homes were burned in the attack.
scite1: Michael Easterbrook, “Presumed paramilitary gunmen kill 12 people in Colombian village, police say,” The Associated Press, August 18, 2001.
scite2: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 17 Aug 01,” FBIS, August 17, 2001.

location: 31 miles outside Rio de Janeiro
summary: 08/16/2001: Unidentified gunmen shot and killed Mario Coelho de Almeida Filho, a local journalist and editor of A Verdade magazine, outside his home in Mage, Brazil.  Although no group claimed responsibility, authorities believed that Filho was killed due to his pending court testimony against the local mayor, claiming she was involved in fraud as a government official.
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources describe how Filho was supposed to testify the next day about government fraud perpetrated by the local mayor.
weapdetail: One of the sources says Filho was shot eight times.
addnotes: The sources suggest that this assassination was related to the impending trial, and that it was possible that the mayor's aides were behind the killing.
scite1: "Brazil-Press RSF requests investigation of Brazilian reporter's murder," EFE News, August 21, 2001.
scite2: Mark Fitzgerald, "Pan-Am Highway. (Mario Coelho de Almeida Filho murdered)," VNU Media, September 3, 2001.

summary: 08/17/2001: A family of six people were kidnapped by National Liberation Army (ELN) members from a home in La Buitrera Corregimiento, near Cali, Colombia, and rescued three hours later by Colombian Army forces. The release was possible after one of the victims who escaped from the guerrillas alerted the authorities.
target1: Civilians in in La Buitrera Corregimiento, Colombia
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 17 Aug 01,” FBIS, August 17, 2001.

location: The victim's body was found in a car on a trail between Puerto Colombia Municipality and Tubara Municipalities, in Atlantico Department, Colombia.
summary: 08/18/2001: Ariel Porras Moreno was killed by members of the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) between Puerto Colombia and Tubara Municipalities, in Atlantico Department, Colombia. The body was found inside a car abandoned on a trail. Moreno was choked to death with an electric cable and the AUC logo was spray painted on his body.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 20 Aug 01,” FBIS, August 20, 2001.

location: The incident occurred on the Bogota-Medellin road near La Dorada, Caldas Department, Colombia
summary: 08/18/2001: A German man, Ralph Leroy, was kidnapped by the National Liberation Army (ELN) while driving on the Bogota-Medellin road toward the rural town of La Dorada, Colombia. Leroy was rescued early on August 22, 2001 in a military operation in the town of Sonson in Antioquia Department
motive: Unknown
scite1: “International News,” Associated Press Worldstream, August 20, 2001.
scite2: “German Hostage Rescued by Colombian Army,” Xinhua General News Service, August 23, 2001.

summary: 08/19/2001: Police found and defused a bomb placed by unknown perpetrators in the underground parking garage of a theater in Caracas, Venezuela. The incident came before the National Ballet of Georgia was to perform.
target1: Civilians at the Performance of the Georgia National Ballet in Caracas, Venezuela
motive: Unknown
addnotes: This incident was part of a number of unexplained bombings in Caracas.
scite1: “Rising Violence in Venezuela,” Associated Press Online, August 21, 2001.

summary: 08/19/2001: Alvaro Alberto Agudelo Usuga, a 43-year-old municipal judge of the Medellin circuit, was kidnapped by National Liberation Army (ELN) members in a rural area of Mesopotamia, in La Union Municipality, in eastern Antioquia Department, Colombia.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 20 Aug 01,” FBIS, August 20, 2001.

summary: 08/19/2001: Two electricity pylons were bombed by the National Liberation Army (ELN) in Aratoca Municipality, Santander Department, Colombia. The guerrillas placed explosives at the bases of the pylons but they were not completely toppled. Electric power service was not affected because the lines were not damaged.
target1: Two Electricity Pylons in Aratoca Municipality, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Some damage occurred to the pylons but they were not brought down in the explosion.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 20 Aug 01,” FBIS, August 20, 2001.

location: The incident occurred in the outskirts of Florencia.
summary: 08/20/2001: Members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC)  kidnapped five family members in Florencia, Caqueta Department, Colombia. The family was rescued in a military operation on August 21, 2001.
target1: Five Family Members in Florencia Caqueta Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
ransomnote: One of the people who had to collect the money demanded by the kidnappers warned the military, which immediately proceeded to carry out the rescue operation, according to the military report.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 22 Aug,” FBIS, August 22, 2001.

location: The incident occurred on the Venadillo to Ibague road in Tolima Department, Colombia.
summary: 08/20/2001: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) and Ejercito Revolucionario del Pueblo (ERP) members kidnapped twenty people at a false checkpoint on the Venadillo to Ibague road in Tolima Department, Colombia.
target1: Civilians on the Venadillo to Ibague road in Tolima Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 20 Aug 01,” FBIS, August 20, 2001.

location: The incident occurred on a farm near Tucata, Colombia.
summary: 08/20/2001: A regional prosecutor from Cali, Winston Tobar, was kidnapped  on a farm near Tocata along the Cali-Buenaventura Highway by members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Columbia (FARC) in Valle Department, Colombia. He was released on August 24, 2001.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 24 Aug 01, FBIS, August 25, 2001.

location: The incident occurred on a road near Santa Isabel, Tolima Department, Colombia.
summary: 08/20/2001: Members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) kidnapped six people at a road block near Santa Isabel in Tolima Department, Colombia.
target1: Civilians on a Road near Santa Isabel, Tolima Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Police said the number of confirmed victims was six, although media reports spoke of as many as 30 people being taken hostage.
scite1: “Rebels snare hostages in Colombian roadblock,” The Associated Press, August 20, 2001.

location: The incident occurred against the bridge on the Lisgaura Creek three kilometers away from the San Andres urban area on the San Andres-Malaga road.
summary: 08/22/2001: The bridge over Lisgaura Creek near San Andres in Santander Department, Colombia was targeted in an explosion from a combined National Liberation Army (ELN) and Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) attack. No injuries were reported.
target1: Bridge over Lisgaura Creek near San Andres in Santander Department, Colombia
motive: The guerrillas were attempting to take over the San Andres Municipality.
weapdetail: Two 20 pound cooking gas cylinders and several bundles of explosives, which were later defused by authorities, and two cooking gas tanks rigged with 50 pounds of explosives, which successfully detonated, were used in the attack.
propcomment: The explosion destroyed one of the pillars of the bridge and left a 70-cm hole.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 24 Aug 01, FBIS, August 25, 2001.

summary: 08/22/2001: Members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) raided the town of San Juan de Arama Municipality in Meta Department, Colombia. The day care center, the church, the notary's office, and 20 houses were completely destroyed. No injuries were reported.
target1: Property in San Juan de Arama Municipality
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Cylinder bombs were used in the attack.
propcomment: The city's day care center, the church, the notary's office, and 20 houses were completely destroyed.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 22 Aug,” FBIS, August 22, 2001.

summary: 08/23/2001: A bomb was detonated in a Corfinsura (National and South American Financial Corporation) office by suspected National Liberation Army (ELN) members in Itagui Municipality, Antioquia Department, Colombia. No injuries were reported.
target1: Corfinsura Office in Itagui Municipality, Colombia
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Terrorist Attacks in Medellin Area Cause 'Considerable' Damage,” El Colombiano, August 23, 2001.

summary: 08/23/2001: A bomb was detonated in a gambling company by suspected National Liberation Army (ELN) members in Rionegro Municipality, Colombia. No injuries were reported.

motive: Unknown
scite1: “Terrorist Attacks in Medellin Area Cause 'Considerable' Damage,” El Colombiano, August 23, 2001.

motive: Unknown
scite1: “Terrorist Attacks in Medellin Area Cause 'Considerable' Damage,” El Colombiano, August 23, 2001.

motive: Unknown
scite1: “Terrorist Attacks in Medellin Area Cause 'Considerable' Damage,” El Colombiano, August 23, 2001.

motive: Unknown

motive: Unknown
scite1: “Terrorist Attacks in Medellin Area Cause 'Considerable' Damage,” El Colombiano, August 23, 2001.

summary: 08/23/2001: A bomb was detonated in an office in a suspected attack by the National Liberation Army (ELN) in Medellin, Antioquia Department, Colombia. No injuries were reported.

motive: Unknown
scite1: “Terrorist Attacks in Medellin Area Cause 'Considerable' Damage,” El Colombiano, August 23, 2001.

location: The incident occurred near the El Rodeo neighborhood
summary: 08/23/2001: Explosives were detonated in a Medellin Public Enterprises electric pylon in the El Rodeo-Itagui area, Colombia in a suspected attack by the National Liberation Army (ELN). No injuries were reported.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Terrorist Attacks in Medellin Area Cause 'Considerable' Damage,” El Colombiano, August 23, 2001.
scite2: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 23 August,” FBIS, August 23, 2001.
