summary: 08/23/2001: Ten people were kidnapped by the United Self Defense Forces of Columbia (AUC) in Carmen de Bolivar Municipality, Bolivar Department, Colombia.
target1: Civilians in Carmen de Bolivar Municipality, Bolivar Department, Colombia
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 23 August,” FBIS, August 23, 2001.

summary: 08/23/2001: A car bomb planted by the National Liberation Army (ELN) outside a police station in Marinilla, Colombia killed one and wounded 20. The car bomb, containing an estimated 175 pounds of explosives, destroyed a police station, a girls' high school, a government office and a funeral home.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The bomb destroyed a police station, a girls' high school, a government office and a funeral home.
scite1: “World Briefs,” The Houston Chronicle, August 24, 2001.
scite2: “21 dead, 25 wounded in attacks around,” Agence France Presse, August 24, 2001.
scite3: “1 dead, 17 injured in bombing in Colombian province,” Deutsche Presse Agentur, August 24, 2001.

location: In the Laureles area of Medellin
summary: 08/23/2001: At least ten people were injured when a car bomb exploded outside the Radio Caracol office in Medellin, Antioquia department, Colombia around 9:00pm.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident.  The damage was described as serious.
targsubtype2_txt: Public Area (garden, parking lot, garage, beach, public building, camp)
target2: Citizens and property in the vicinity of the explosion
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources described how the National Liberation Army (ELN) had been active in the area.
weapdetail: The bomb was in a car and was described as powerful.
propcomment: Sources describe the damage as serious, and authorities say a hole five feet in diameter was left at the site of the explosion.
scite1: "Bomb explodes in Colombia's third-largest city," Reuters, August 23, 2001.
scite2: "New explosion leaves another 10 wounded in Colombia," Agence France-Presse, August 24, 2001.

summary: 08/23/2001: A bomb exploded behind the offices of Radio Caracol in Medellin, Colombia in an attack by the National Liberation Army (ELN). 35 people were wounded.
target1: Offices of Radio Caracol in Medellin, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Several buildings were partially destroyed, while many others suffered lesser damage. The blast took place close to a local radio station, causing significant damage to the installations.
scite1: “21 dead, 25 wounded in attacks around, Agence France Presse, August 24, 2001.
scite2: Martin Dayani, “Blast rocks Colombia's second city,” United Press International, August 24, 2001.

summary: 08/24/2001: A car bomb placed by in front of the State house by suspected members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) exploded in Cucuta, Colombia. No injuries occurred but departmental government offices and several businesses were damaged in the explosion.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The bomb exploded on the street in front of the State house, destroying its gates and damaging nearby businesses.
scite1: “Car Bombs Explode in Colombia,” Xinhua General News Service, August 24, 2001.
scite2: “AFX World news update - Eighteen killed during clashes in Indian Kashmir,” AFX European Focus, August 24, 2001.
scite3: Javier Baena, “Rebel bombing campaign spreads to eastern capital,” Associated Press Worldstream, August 24, 2001.

summary: 08/25/2001: About 450 members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Columbia (FARC) in a strike on Santa Maria, Huila Department, attacked the Santa Juana de Arco School, the police station, the National Registry building, and the municipal court using gas cylinders, other explosives, and M-60 machine guns. Houses were destroyed and various items looted. Three soldiers were wounded but no other injuries were reported.
motive: Jose Zacarandai, a Tolima Indian who sells perishable goods, was the target of the guerrilla action.
weapdetail: Gas cylinder bombs and other explosives were thrown, and M-60 machine guns were used in the attack.
propcomment: Various buildings and homes were destroyed and a number of items were looted.
scite1: “FARC Attacks Santa Maria, Huila; Police Station Partially Destroyed,” Caracol Colombia Radio, August 26, 2001.

summary: 08/25/2001: Amauris Esther Cantillo, the wife of politician Humberto Munoz, the vice-president of the Democratic Alternative Movement, was kidnapped from her home by six unidentified armed men in Campo de la Cruz Municipality, Atlantico Department, Colombia.
target2: Humberto Munoz, the vice-president of the Democratic Alternative Movement
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 27 Aug,” FBIS, August 28, 2001.

summary: 08/28/2001: Six people were killed and six people wounded in an attack by at least 20 men of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) on Puerto Libertador Municipality, Cordoba Department, Colombia
target1: Puerto Libertador Municipality in Cordoba Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 28 Aug,” FBIS, August 28, 2001.

summary: 08/28/2001: Orlando Beltran of the Liberal Party was kidnapped at gunpoint from his vehicle in Huila Department, Columbia by members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian opposition lawmaker kidnapped in south,” Agence France Presse, August 29, 2001.
scite2: Colombian lawmaker kidnapped as bad weather slows offensive,” Agence France Presse, August 29, 2001.
scite3: “Colombian Congress threatens to strike over FARC kidnappings,” BBC Monitoring Latin America – Political, August 30, 2001.

location: The incident occurred 7 km from Puerres.
summary: 08/28/2001: A portion of the Trans-Andean Pipeline was destroyed by a Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) attack near Puerres, southern Narino Department, Colombia. No injuries were caused.
target1: Portion of the Trans-Andean Pipeline near Puerras, Narino Department, Colombia
motive: To negatively affect oil production and revenue.
propcomment: A portion of oil pipeline was destroyed.
addnotes: Oil production provided a significant revenue source for the Colombian government.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 30 Aug,” FBIS, August 30, 2001.

summary: 08/28/2001: An explosive device was found and defused on a railway from the Cerrejon coal mine to Puerto Bolivar near La Lima in Guajira Department, Colombia. No perpetrators were identified.
target1: Railway from the Cerrejon coal mine to Puerto Bolivar in Guajira Department, Colombia
target2: Railroad infrastructure of the coal complex
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 28 Aug,” FBIS, August 28, 2001.

location: The incident occurred on the San Pablo-Simiti road, 6 km away from San Pablo.
summary: 08/29/2001: Two car bombs were planted by National Liberation Front (ELN) members on the San Pablo-Simiti road, 6 km away from San Pablo, in southern Bolivar Department, Colombia. The vehicles were marked with the message "car-bomb" by the ELN. The bombs were found and detonated by the security services.
target1: Civilians on the San Pablo-Simiti road in southern Bolivar Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A car bomb was used in the attack.
propcomment: The vehicles used in the car bombs were stolen.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 30 Aug,” FBIS, August 30, 2001.
scite2: “Colombia's Police Detonate Two Car Bombs,” Xinhua General News Service, August 31, 2001.

summary: 08/29/2001: Five people were killed by the United Self Defense Forces (AUC) in Caramanta, Antioquia Department, Colombia. No further information was available.
target1: Civilians in Caramanta, Antioquia Department, Colombia
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 29 Aug,” FBIS, August 29, 2001.

summary: 08/29/2001: A bomb exploded in an army hotel in the Providencia area of Santiago, Chile. The bomb did not injure anyone, but did cause damage to the hotels entrance and front windows. No perpetrators were identified.
target1: Hotel owned by the Chilean Army in Santiago, Chile
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The bomb caused damage to the hotels entrance and front windows.
scite1: “Bomb Goes Off at Chilean Army Hotel; No Injuries Reported,” Television Nacional de Chile Imagen Internacional, August 29, 2001.
scite2: “Bomb explodes in Providencia hotel,” Santiago Times, August 31, 2001.

location: The incident occurred on the Tibu-Cucuta road in Norte de Santander Department.
summary: 08/29/2001: The Maria Yamile bridge over the Nuevo Presidente River on the Tibu-Cucuta road was destroyed in a bombing by the National Liberation Army (ELN) in Norte de Santander Department, Colombia. No injuries were reported.
target1: Maria Yamile bridge over the Nuevo Presidente River in Norte de Santander Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: A bridge was destroyed in the attack.
addnotes: This was the third time in the last 15 months that this bridge was bombed by the ELN.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 29 Aug,” FBIS, August 29, 2001.

summary: 08/29/2001: Ten people were kidnapped and three trucks stolen at a National Liberation Army (ELN) checkpoint at Caracolicito on the border between Magdalena and Cesar Departments, Colombia.
target1: Civilians on the highway between Magdalena Department and Cesar Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Three trucks with food items were stolen.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 29 Aug,” FBIS, August 29, 2001.

location: The incident occurred in the outskirts of Puerto Rico.
summary: 08/30/2001: Jose Lizardo Rojas, the mayor of Puerto Rico, Colombia, was shot and killed by armed men on the outskirts of the town in Caqueta Department, Colombia. The incident was blamed on the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).
motive: Unknown
scite1: Jose Ramos, “US delegation visits Colombia amid surge of violence,” Agence France Presse, August 31, 2001.
scite2: “Hired Assassins Murder Puerto Rico Mayor,” Radio Cadena Nacional, August 31, 2001.

summary: 08/30/2001: Seven civilians were kidnapped and killed by suspected members of the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) in Narino Department, Colombia. The victims’ bodies were dumped in a river.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Unknown
scite1: Jose Ramos, “US delegation visits Colombia amid surge of violence,” Agence France Presse, August 31, 2001.

summary: 08/30/2001: A group of 150 Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) members attacked a police station in Sativa Norte, in Boyaca Department, Colombia. One officer was killed. No further information was available.
target1: Police Station in Sativa Norte, Boyaca Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The police station sustained minor damage.
scite1: Jose Ramos, “US delegation visits Colombia amid surge of violence,” Agence France Presse, August 31, 2001.

summary: 08/30/2001: Two bombs placed by the National Liberation Army (ELN) on a bus and on a vehicle were found and defused near a road exit and detonated by the Colombian security services in Santiago, Norte de Santander Department, Colombia.
target1: Civilians on a road in Santiago, Norte de Santander Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Two car bombs were used in this attack.
propcomment: Two vehicles were stolen and were likely damaged in the controlled detonation of the explosives.
scite1: “Colombia's Police Detonate Two Car Bombs,” Xinhua General News Service, August 31, 2001.
scite2: “FARC Casualties High in Fighting Yesterday,” El Tiempo, August 31, 2001.

location: The incident occurred on the Bucaramanga-Barrancabermeja highway in Santander Department, Colombia
summary: 08/31/2001: On the Bucaramanga-Barrancabermeja highway, the National Liberation Army (ELN) set up a roadblock, burned two vehicles, and blew up a stretch of the pipeline in Santander Department, Colombia. An army unit arrived which drove off the perpetrators. No injuries were reported.
target1: Two vehicles on the Bucaramanga-Barrancabermeja highway in Santander Department, Colombia
target2: Section of pipeline along the Bucaramanga-Barrancabermeja highway in Santander Department, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Two vehicles were burned and a section of pipeline blown up in the incident.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities 31 Aug,” FBIS, August 31, 2001.

location: North of Bogota
summary: 09/01/2001: An unidentified gunman shot and killed Libardo Rodriguez Bautista, the brother of the leader of the National Liberation Army (ELN), as he walked in Giron, Santander state, Colombia.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack, although sources suggested that this was related to the previous killings and kidnappings of the other siblings of Nicolas Rodriguez Bautista, the ELN leader.
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources speculated that this attack was related to the killings and kidnappings of the ELN leader's other siblings.  Sources also speculated that a rival terrorist organization could be behind the attack.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
scite1: "Gunman assassinates a brother of rebel army chief in Colombia," Associated Press, September 2, 2001.
scite2: "Brother of ELN rebel leader killed in Colombia, two others dead," Agence France-Presse, September 3, 2001.

location: 50 miles outside of Bogota
summary: 9/02/2001: Armed members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) kidnapped Ramiro Carranza, an official with the Administrative Department of Security's Alien Affairs Department, from his home in Puente Quetame, Colombia.  Although FARC made no official claim of responsibility, it was thought that this kidnapping could have been related to ongoing peace talks between FARC and the Colombian government.
motive: Although the specific motive for the kidnapping was unknown, sources thought the attack could have been related to ongoing peace talks between FARC and the Colombian government.
weapdetail: The guns were described as powerful.
scite1: "Suspected rebels kidnap Colombian administrator," Reuters, September 3, 2001.
scite2: "Top Colombian security official kidnapped as peace talks resume," Agence France-Presse, September 4, 2001.
scite3: "Alien Affairs security chief Ramiro Carranza kidnapped," Caracol Colombia Radio website, September 3, 2001.

summary: 09/03/2001:  Mortar shells containing cyanide were launched at a Colombian police station in San Adolfo.  The attack killed 4 and injured six.
motive: To influence voters in legislative election.
weapdetail: Cyanide
scite1: Richter, Paul. "Rebel's Arsenal Fuel Urban War Fears." Los Angeles Times, March 8, 2002.
scite2: "Colombia Links 'Gas' Attacks to IRA." BBC, September 5, 2001.
scite3: "Colombian guerillas used chemicals in attack on police station," Agence France Presse, August 21, 2002.

summary: 09/06/2001: Two unidentified men assassinated Jairo Rojas Pulido, a member of the Chamber of Representatives for the Cundinamarca Department in his building's parking lot in northern Bogota. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Jairo Rojas Pulido, a member of the Chamber of Representatives
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Jairo Rojas Pulido, a member of the Conservative Party, had received death threats a few days prior to his assassination.
scite1: “Colombia: House Representative Rojas Pulido ‘Assassinated,’” Radio Cadena Nacional, September 6, 2001.

summary: 09/14/2001: A car bomb planted by suspected leftist rebels caused heavy property damage but no casualties in Valledupar, Colombia. The explosion caused damage to residences and a commercial warehouse over a three-block area. The Renault sedan used in the attack was packed with 100 pounds of explosives. While, no group claimed responsibility for the attack, Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) were suspected.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: 100 pounds of explosives were packed into a Renault made car.
propcomment: A three block area of the town was badly damaged.  A warehouse facility as well as several residences were destroyed.
addnotes: Colombian state police blamed the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC), but did not provide a possible motive for the attack.
scite1: "Car Bomb Rocks Colombian City," Associated Press Online, September 14, 2001

location: The gas pipeline explosion took place four kilometers outside of the town of Los Palmitos.
summary: 09/14/2001: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)guerrillas, Fronts 35 and 27, were suspected to have blown up the gas pipeline that served the Montes de Maria region in the center of Bolivar Department, Colombia. The blast left 16,000 users in Bolivar Department without natural gas for seventy-two hours. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Natural gas pipeline belonging to the Surtigas company
motive: Unknown
propcomment: A section of natural gas pipeline was damaged cutting off supply of natural gas to 16,000 people for 3 days.
scite1: "Colombia: FARC Blow Up Pipeline in Bolivar Department," Colombia Radio, September 14, 2001.

summary: 09/16/2001: 11 Colombian workers were killed and two injured in a rural area in the Falan Municipality, Colombia. The civilians were killed during a raid by alleged members of the United Self-defense Forces of Colombia (AUC - Las Autodefensas Unidas de Colombia) . No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The Colombian United Self Defense Groups attack was the paramilitary organizations first attack in the Tolima Department.
scite1: "Colombia: Authorities Report ‘At Least 11 Peasants’ Slain by Paramilitary Forces,” Agence France Presse, September 16, 2001.

location: This incident occurred at a gas pipeline in north-eastern region of Colombia.
summary: 09/16/2001: Suspected members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)’s (FARC) 41st Front sabotaged a major gas pipeline in the northeastern region of Colombia, causing about $2.9 million in damage. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Natural gas pipeline supplying central Colombia and the capital city, Bogota
motive: Unknown
propcomment: A natural gas pipeline supplying Bogota and the surrounding area was sabotaged.
scite1: "Colombia: FARC Attack Forces Natural Gas Rationing in Central Region,” Colombia Radio, September 18, 2001.

summary: 09/19/2001: A right-wing military group was accused of killing a Roman Catholic nun and human rights advocate, Yolanda Ceron, in Tumaco.
target1: Yolanda Ceron, a Roman Catholic nun and human rights advocate
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The London-based human rights organization, Amnesty International, accused a right-wing paramilitary group that has previously targeted human rights workers in that region of Colombia.
scite1: "Right-wing Group Accused of Killing Nun,” Calgary Herald, September 21, 2001.

summary: 09/19/2001: Unidentified gunmen shot and killed Jesus David Corzo, an official with the Attorney General's Technical Investigations Force, and wounded his mother as they walked in a neighborhood in Cucuta, Norte de Santander province, Colombia.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack, and the gunmen abandoned the truck they were driving shortly after the shooting.  Nine years later, a National Human Rights and International Humanitarian Law prosecutor indicted Jorge Ivan Laverde, also known as the Iguana, for the murder.
motive: The specific motive for the attack was not known, but Corzo was an official in the government.
weapdetail: The gunmen shot at Corzo and his mother from a pickup truck.
scite1: "Colombian Attorney General's office figure gunned down," EFE News Service, September 21, 2001.
scite2: "Accuse 'The Iguana' for murder of former director of CTI - Cucuta," El Espectador website, April 7, 2010.

location: This incident occurred on a road between Medellin to Bogota.
summary: 09/23/2001: A Slovak missionary, Pavol Sucholak, and two others were kidnapped by leftist rebels in the northeast of Colombia while traveling on a bus from Medellin to Bogota. No group claimed responsibility for the kidnapping. The outcome of the kidnapping has remained unknown.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Reports indicated that leftist rebels were behind the abduction of the missionary.
scite1: "Slovak Missionary, Czech Priest Kidnapped in Colombia,” CTK, September 24, 2001.

location: In the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta mountains
summary: 9/24/2001: Colombian Inspector General Consuelo Araujo Noguera was found shot dead after she and a dozen others were kidnapped  at a roadblock by members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) near Valledupar, Cesar province, Colombia.  The other individuals kidnapped were released.  Although FARC did not claim responsibility for the incident, authorities believed this was a response to ongoing peace talks between the rebel group and the Colombian government.
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, authorities speculated that this kidnapping and killing was a response to ongoing peace talks between the rebel group and the Colombian government.
weapdetail: Araujo was shot in the head and died.
scite1: Scott Wilson, "Colombian guerrillas kill popular official; Death puts peace efforts in doubt," Washington Post, October 1, 2001.
scite2: "Consuelo Araujo Noguera Colombian culture minister who brought vallenato, the country's accordion music, to international attention," Daily Telegraph (London), October 3, 2001.

location: This incident occurred at an electrical power station near Iquira.
summary: 09/27/2001: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)members were suspected of kidnapping a Russian technician in Huila Province at an electrical power station near the town of Iquira. They also kidnapped four other Colombian workers whom they subsequently released. The victims were employees of Sgem World of Colombia, which carries out maintenance work at electricity facilities in Huila Province. FARC did not claim responsibility for the kidnappings.
target1: Russian technician working in Huila, Colombia.
target3: Employees of Sgem World of Colombia
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The kidnappers released the four Colombia captives soon after taking them hostage.  Reports on the incident do not indicate when, if ever, the Russian technician was released.
scite1: "Russian Kidnapped in Colombia by Suspected Leftist Rebels,” Deutsche Presse-Agentur, September 27, 2001.

summary: 09/27/2001: A letter bomb addressed to the US ambassador in Chile was sent through a private courier service to the US Embassy in Santiago.  Police responded to the scene after infrared scanners at the US Embassy detected an explosive device inside the letter. Chilean police successfully defused the device before the bomb exploded. Chilean Interior Minister, Jose Miguel Insulza, said that there was advance warning of the attack, but did not mention specific groups that may have been responsible. No group claimed responsibility for the letter bomb.
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Letter Bomb Found at US Embassy in Chile,” El Mercurio, September 28, 2001.

location: To the north of Bogota
summary: 10/02/2001: Two unidentified gunmen shot Ricardo Cifuentes, director for a presidential candidate's campaign, in Duitama, Boyaca department, Colombia.  Cifuentes survived the shooting, as the bullet entered his jaw.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: Although the specific motive for the assassination attempt was not known, sources speculated that the strict stance the presidential candidate that Cifuentes worked for took on guerrillas in the area could have incited rebel violence.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
scite1: "Former intelligence chief escapes assassination bid," Associated Press, October 4, 2001.
scite2: "Ex-general working on hard-liner's presidential campaign shot," Associated Press, October 3, 2001.

location: A highway near Rondonopolis
summary: 10/03/2001: Thirteen journalists were taken hostage by Terena Indians who had barricaded a highway outside Rondonopolis, Brazil in protest of a land deal that the Brazilian government made to the Indians but did not fulfill.  Four of the hostages were released shortly after their capture, another two journalists escaped a day after their capture, and the remaining seven journalists were released two days after their capture, once the government had agreed to give the Indians they lands they had been promised.  No one was injured.
corp1: Journalists covering the Indian standoff with the Brazilian government
motive: The Terena Indians took the journalists hostages in order to negotiate with the Brazilian government to receive the land the government had promised to give them but never did.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
scite1: Alex Bellos, "Brazilians hold journalists hostage in land dispute," The Guardian (London), October 4, 2001.
scite2: "Indians demanding land release reporters," Associated Press, October 5, 2001.
scite3: "Indians release hostage on government promise of land in 30 days," Associated Press, October 5, 2001.

summary: 10/07/2001: Members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) kidnapped at least six people at a roadblock outside Barbacoas, Narino Department, Colombia.  Among those kidnapped were two plain-clothes police officers.  Three days later, authorities reported that the two police officers had been shot and killed by FARC and said they would be reporting this incident to human rights agencies internationally.
target1: Victor Hugo Gallego and Jairo Libardo Gustin Garcia
target2: At least four citizens at a roadblock
motive: Although the specific motive for this attack was unknown, sources note that FARC and the Colombian government had signed a peace deal just days before this incident.
weapdetail: The police officers were reportedly shot with rifles after their hands were tied behind their backs.
addnotes: The bodies of the policemen had not been recovered at the time of the report.  One of the sources says that four others were kidnapped with the officers, while another says that 100 cars and 500 people were kidnapped.  The source reporting the high number of people kidnapped said they were released three days later, while the other source says nothing about the release of the other hostages.
scite1: "Six people kidnapped in Colombia," Agence France-Presse, October 8, 2001.
scite2: Alvaro Miguel Mina and Lili Gallor, "FARC reportedly kill two policemen kidnapped at rebel checkpoint," Caracol Colombia Radio website, October 10, 2001.

location: Great Marsh lagoon near the areas of Riohacha and Santa Marta
summary: 10/07/2001: At least six fisherman were found dead at Great Marsh lagoon, Magdalena department, Colombia, after having been among eighteen fisherman kidnapped four days before by suspected paramilitary members.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack, but the United Self Defence Units of Colombia (AUC) had been engaging in violent attacks in the area around this time.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Although the specific motive for this attack was not known, sources detailed the many attacks the AUC had been involved in right around the time of this attack.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
addnotes: One of the sources says that six bodies were found while another says that seventeen of the eighteen people originally kidnapped were found dead.  Neither article said what happened to the remaining hostages.
scite1: Carlos Gonzalez, "Colombian peasants 'killed by vigilantes,'" The Independent (London), October 12, 2001.
scite2: Martin Hodgson, "Rightwing militias accused of new Colombian massacres," The Guardian (London), October 12, 2001.

location: In Bogota's north area
summary: 10/08/2001: Armed members of the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) fired upon the vehicle carrying Luis Alfredo Colmenares, Liberal Party congressman and former governor, from a motorcycle as they traveled in Bogota, Capital District, Colombia.  Colmenares was killed in the attack.  The AUC later claimed responsibility for the attack, claiming this was yet one more killing of a politician who was associated with rebels.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: In a communique they sent out, the AUC claimed that their recent spate of killings of politicians was motivated by the fact that the politicians they targeted were involved with rebel groups such as FARC and the ELN.
weapdetail: The gunmen were on a motorcycle.  No further weapon details were provided.
propcomment: It was not clear if the vehicle Colmenares was traveling in was damaged in the shooting.
scite1: "World; In brief," Washington Post, October 9, 2001.
scite2: "Colombian Pol killed in Bogota," Associated Press, October 8, 2001.
scite3: "Far-right Colombian group admits to killings," Morning Star, October 16, 2001.

location: 155 miles south of Bogota, in the valley of the Cauca river
summary: 10/10/2001: At least twenty-four men were killed by suspected members of a death squad outside the village of Buga, Valle del Cauca department, Colombia.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack, although sources note that the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) were active in the area.
motive: Although the specific motive for this attack was unknown, sources note that violence in the area, especially violence perpetrated by the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC), was increasing.
weapdetail: The sources say the farmers were massacred by a death squad, but no weapon detail was provided.
addnotes: One of the sources says that 24 bodies were found while another says that 30 were found.
scite1: "Colombian peasants 'killed by vigilantes,'" The Independent (London), October 12, 2001.
scite2: "Peasants massacred," Herald Sun (Australia), October 13, 2001.

location: Near rebel territory
summary: 10/11/2001: Unidentified assailants killed Luis Elias Marin, the mayor of Cartagena del Chaira, his driver, and three others near Montanitas, Colombia.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack, although sources noted that the Mayor and his companions were close to territory inhabited by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).
motive: Although the specific motive for this attack was not known, sources noted that violence in the area by rebel groups had been increasing, and was specifically targeting government officials, as well as citizens.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
scite1: "Violence erupts in Colombia; Village massacre claims at least 24," Houston Chronicle, October 12, 2001.
scite2: "Colombian paramilitaries accused of carrying out scattered massacres," Associated Press, October 12, 2001.
scite3: Amira Abultaif, "55 shot to death in Colombian massacres," Reuters, October 12, 2001.

location: A one-street village, approximately 150 miles southwest of Bogota
summary: 10/10/2001: Members of United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) stormed a small village in Colombia, killing 24 villagers.  Contrary to previous massacres committed by the AUC, the uniformed assailants appeared to have no method of victim-selection; instead of targeting suspected guerrilla collaborators, the attackers appeared to kill indiscriminately.  The bodies were left in two piles; one pile was for the younger victims and one was for the older.  Specific motive is unknown.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the attack was a typical attack targeting civilians in a key area for transportation that is commonly used by guerrillas.
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
scite1: Scott Wilson, "Colombian Rightists Kill 24 Villagers; Massacre May Be Largest This Year," The Washington Post, October 12, 2001.

location: A residence in Florencia
summary: 11/10/2001: At least a dozen members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) attacked the home of Luis Almario, a representative with the Popular Party, with guns and grenades in Florencia, Caqueta province, Colombia.  A student and security guard in the vicinity of the attack were killed, but Almario and his family escaped unharmed.  FARC did not claim responsibility for the attack.
motive: Although the specific motive for this attack was unknown, the source notes that rebels have targeted officials in the area recently and in the past.
weapdetail: The house was fired upon and grenades were thrown at it.
propcomment: No details were provided on the amount of damage done to the home and surrounding area.
scite1: "Leftist rebels attack Colombian lawmaker's house, killing two people," Associated Press, November 10, 2001.

summary: 11/10/2011: Members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) kidnapped Gianluigi Ravotti, an Italian man working for Ansaldo Energy, on a road near Guadalupe, Antioquia province, Colombia.  The group did not claim responsibility for the incident.
motive: Although the specific motive for this incident was unknown, sources note that the ELN and other rebel organizations were continuing their acts of violence in the area.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
addnotes: The hostage was released on April 27, 2002.
scite1: Michael Easterbrook, "Gunmen massacre 12 men Colombia," Associated Press, November 11, 2001.
scite2: "Presumed leftist rebels abduct an Italian man in Colombia and free another," Associated Press, November 11, 2001.

location: El Choco village
summary: 11/10/2001: Members of the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) shot and killed twelve male villagers in El Choco, Colombia.  The men were accused of working for the National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN).  The AUC did not claim responsibility for the attack.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: According to the source, the AUC members had a list of villagers they believed to be working for the ELN, and those were the men they killed.
weapdetail: The villagers were shot in the heads outside their homes.  No further weapon details were provided.
scite1: Michael Easterbrook, "Gunmen massacre 12 men Colombia," Associated Press, November 11, 2001.

summary: 11/10/2001: Rebels kidnapped and killed a worker for an aid program with support from the United States in Colombia.  Although no group claimed responsibility for the attack, sources claim that the rebels claimed the worker was working with the military.
target1: A worker with an aid program
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, it was thought that aid workers who were working to fulfill the goals of the United States to rid Colombia of drugs were being targeted.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
scite1: Jared Kotler, "Guerrillas attacks, aid delays plague U.S.-backed drug war in Colombia," Associated Press, November 10, 2001.
scite2: Jeremy McDermott, "Aid workers victims of war against drug trade," Scotland on Sunday, November 11, 2001.

location: Between Medellin and Manizales
summary: 10/14/2001: Unidentified gunmen shot and killed four employees at the Marmato restaurant in Manizales, Caldas department, Colombia.  Although no group claimed responsibility for the attack and the motive was unknown, authorities claimed the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) could be responsible.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: The specific motive for the attack was not known.  Authorities claimed the AUC could be responsible as they were active in the area.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
scite1: "Alleged paramilitary members kill four in restaurant," EFE News Service, October 14, 2001.

location: A residence in Pailitas, near Valledupar and 311 miles from Bogota
summary: 10/16/2001: Unidentified gunmen shot and killed Jorge Eliecer Meneses, Liberal Party member and former congressman, after kidnapping him and his brother from Meneses' ranch in Pailitas, Cesar province, Colombia.  His brother was later released.  Although no group claimed responsibility for the attack, authorities believed that the United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) was responsible as they claimed responsibility for similar attacks that occurred shortly before this one.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Although the specific motive for this attack was unknown, sources note that the AUC was responsible for similar attacks that occurred only shortly before this one.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
addnotes: One source says that both Meneses and his brother were kidnapped, and then Meneses was killed while his brother was released.  The other source says that Meneses was killed at his home and makes no mention of a kidnapping.
scite1: "Former Colombian congressman killed," Associated Press, October 17, 2001.
scite2: "Former congressman murdered in northeastern Colombia," EFE News Service, October 17, 2001.

summary: 10/18/2001: A bomb exploded in front of a McDonald’s in Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro state, Brazil. No one was injured. The front of the restaurant received minor damage. No one has claimed responsibility for the blast.
target1: Restaurant in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The windows of the restaurant were broken.

summary: 10/20/2001: Ten peasants were killed when gunmen suspected to have paramilitary ties shot them in Alejandria, Antioquia province, Colombia.  The gunmen claimed the peasants were working with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).  No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: Authorities said that the peasants were shot because they were suspected of working with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).  Sources also described the ongoing violence perpetrated by rebel groups in the area, despite attempts at peace talks between the Colombian government and rebel leaders.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
scite1: Michael Easterbrook, "Massacres, bombings by Colombia's armed groups leaves at least 30 dead," Associated Press, October 21, 2001.

location: 130 miles northwest of Bogota
summary: 10/21/2001: A bomb hidden in a hot dog cart exploded outside of an apartment building in Penol, Antioquia Department, Colombia.  Five people were killed and another two were injured in the explosion; a good portion of the building was also destroyed.  The specific target is unknown; however, there were several police families living in the building.  Authorities believe that the National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN) is responsible for the incident.
target1: Civilians living in a building in Penol
target2: Police officers and their families living in a building in Penol
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: An explosive device hidden in a hot dog cart
propcomment: The explosion destroyed a portion of the apartment building
addnotes: One of the fatalities was a 9-month-old baby.
scite1: "Colombian group kills at least 30," The Washington Times, October 22, 2001.
scite2: "Explosion blamed on Colombian rebels kills baby and four others," Associated Press, October 21, 2001.

location: 340 miles north of Bogota
summary: 10/27/2001: Suspected members of United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) shot and killed five people in Chiriguana, Cesar Department, Colombia.  The assailants, dressed in civilian clothing, forced the victims from their homes and executed them in front of their family members.  Specific motive is unknown.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Specific motive is unknown, however, sources note that AUC often kills civilians that they suspect are aiding leftist guerrillas.
scite1: "Gunmen kill nine farmers in Colombian massacre," Associated Press, October 27, 2001.
scite2: "Gunmen execute nine peasants in Colombia," Associated Press, October 27, 2001.

location: A road running from Quibdo to Medellin, on the outskirts of Quibdo
summary: 10/28/2001: Members of National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN) kidnapped Jeremy Parks, a British tourist, outside of Quibdo, Choco Department, Colombia.  Parks was on a passenger bus traveling to Medellin when they encountered an ELN roadblock.  The assailants forced Parks off the bus and took him captive.  Several hours later, the ELN and a military patrol exchanged fire; Parks was killed.  The ELN claims that the army shot him.  Specific motive behind the kidnapping is unknown.
target1: Jeremy Parks, a British tourist traveling to Medellin
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Authorities originally suspected that Parks was a member of ELN, since there was no missing persons report released for him.  The ELN often kidnaps people for ransom money.

scite2: Jason Webb, "British backpacker killed after kidnapped by rebels," Reuters, October 30, 2001.
scite3: Andrew Selsky, "Mystery surrounds death of foreigner killed in firefight with Colombian troops," Associated Press, October 29, 2001.

summary: 11/1/2001: Carlos Arturo Pinto, a special prosecutor, was shot and killed in Cucuta, Norte de Santander Department, Colombia.  Two gunmen on a motorcycle killed Pinto as he left his home.  Pinto was investigating leftist guerrillas and a paramilitary group at the time of the assassination; he had been called in to replace another prosecutor that had been assassinated a few months prior.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident and specific motive is unknown.
target1: Carlos Arturo Pinto, a special prosecutor with the Judicial and Investigating Police Force
motive: Unknown

summary: 11/10/2001: Rebels kidnapped a worker for a program providing aid in the area with the support of the United States in Colombia.  The worker was questioned and made to undergo Russian Roulette.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: A worker with an aid program
motive: Although the specific motive was not known, it was thought that aid workers were being targeted as they were helping rid Colombia of drugs.

summary: 11/10/2001: Suspected rebels kidnapped a scientist who specialized in turning plant life into food and other usable materials in Colombia.  The rebels then tied up the scientist to a tree.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources describe the ongoing violence perpetrated by rebels against civilians and others in Colombia.

summary: 11/11/2001: A breakaway faction of Popular Liberation Army (EPL) kidnapped at least 15 musicians near El Tarra, Norte de Santander Department, Colombia.  The musicians belonged to a popular band led by Alfredo Guteirrez.  The assailants called Guteirrez and demanded that the military begin withdrawing from five cities or they would kill the musicians one by one.  The musicians were released on November 28, 2001, following the intervention of the Red Cross and the ombudsman.
target1: Musicians belong to a popular band
motive: The assailants demanded the demilitarization of five cities in Norte de Santander Department.
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made.
addnotes: Two sources state that 15 musicians were kidnapped while one source states that 19 were released.

summary: 11/11/2001: Alfredo Gutierrez , a well-known Colombian folk singer and one other person were kidnapped by the National Liberation Army (NLA) in Norte de Santander Department. They were released later the same day.

summary: 11/15/2001: Four hooded gunmen burst into the Buenaventura, Colombia home of a veteran newspaper and radio reporter, Heriberto Cardenas, and shot him to death as he and his family members watched television. As a result of the attack his nephew was also killed and his brother was injured.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “News reporter assassinated in Colombia,” Associated Press Worldstream, November 15, 2001.

location: This incident took place in the mountains of Antioquia Department, Colombia.
summary: 11/18/2001: The United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) kidnapped six mayors in the mountains of Antioquia Department, Colombia. The kidnapped were engaged in a meeting to negotiate with the National Liberation Army (ELN). The AUC said they would not allow the mayors to negotiate grass-roots truces with the ELN. The victims were released on November 20, 2001.
target1: Mayors negotiating with the ELN in the Antioquia Department
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: The incident took place to warn the government officials against negotiating with the National Liberation Army (ELN).

location: At Guandalay on the road linking the villages of Río Negro, Las Cruces, Media Naranja and Quebraditas in Corinto district, approximately 600 kilometers southwest of Bogota.
summary: 11/18/2001: Members of United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) set up a false checkpoint near Corinto, Cauca Department, Colombia.  They stopped a bus carrying 30 passengers; 12 of the passengers were on a list carried by the assailants.  The gunmen opened fire on the passengers, killing at least ten people and wounding another three, while calling them guerrilla collaborators.
target1: Civilians on a bus near Corinto
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: The assailants stated that the victims were guerrilla collaborators

summary: 11/16/2001: A letter containing anthrax spores was delivered to Antonio Banfi at Calvo Mackenna Hospital in Santiago city, Santiago province, Chile.  Banfi became suspicious of the letter when he noticed that the postmark was from Zurich but the return address was from Florida.  The envelope contained white powder and papers; the powder was confirmed to be anthrax.  Banfi and twelve other people that were with him when he opened the envelope were treated by antibiotics; none of them showed symptoms.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident and the motive is unknown.
target2: Antonio Banfi and others in the vicinity of the letter
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) laced letter
addnotes: It is unclear if the hospital was the target or a private business was the target.  It is also unclear if the envelope was addressed to Antonio Banfi.
scite1: "Anthrax spores found on mail sent to Chile from Zurich," Associated Press, November 23, 2001.
scite2: "Chile says anthrax case confirmed in letter," Reuters, November 19, 2001
scite3: "Anthrax-laden letter appears in Chile: official," Agence France-Presse, November 19, 2001.

location: On a rural highway just outside of Lejanias, in southern Meta
summary: 11/21/2001: Four suspected members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) killed Leonardo Morena, the mayor of Lejanias, in Meta Department, Colombia.  Morena was driving home outside of Lejanias when gunmen shot him.  Specific motive is unknown; however, Lejanias lies just outside of the guerrilla-occupied demilitarized zone.
target1: Leonardo Moreno, the mayor of Lejanias
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, Lejanias sits just outside of the guerrilla-occupied demilitarized zone.

location: Zancon, a rural area hamlet in Tierralta,  558 miles north of Bogota
summary: 11/22/2001:  Members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) killed six peasants living in Zancon, Cordoba Department, Colombia.  The assailants accused the victims of collaborating with the rival group, United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC).  This was one of two small hamlets in the area that the rebels targeted that day.

summary: 11/24/2001: At least three indigenous people were shot and killed near Rio Sucio, Caldas Department, Colombia.  One of the three victims was Luis Angel Charua, the founder of Valbuena's National Organization of Indigenous Peoples of Colombia (ONIC); he had recently made a plea to the United Nations to play an active role in preventing the extinction of indigenous people caught in the crossfire of the Colombian guerrilla war.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, authorities suspect the involvement of United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC).
target1: Indigenous people, including Luis Angel Charua, the founder of Valbuena's National Organization of Indigenous Peoples of Colombia (ONIC)
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, one of the victims was a prominent indigenous activist who had recently made a plea to the United Nations to intervene in the guerrilla war in order to protect indigenous folks who were caught in the crossfire
addnotes: One source states that three people were killed at the same location; a second source states that four people were killed at two different locations.
scite1: "Rightist gunmen said to kill Colombian India leader," Retuers, November 25, 2001.
scite2: "Colombia - violence.  Two Indian leaders, two others, murdered in Colombia," EFE News Service, November 25, 2001.

The assailants accused the victims of collaborating with the rival group, United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC).  This was one of two small hamlets in the area that the rebels targeted that day.

summary: 11/28/2001: Suspected members of United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) killed at least seven men in Montebello village, Antioquia Department, Colombia.  The assailants pulled the victims from their homes and shot them.  Specific motive is unknown.
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the AUC typically kills civilians that they believe are collaborating with the rebels.

location: The incident began in Cartagena and ended in Maria La Baja
summary: 11/30/2001: Members of United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) kidnapped Aury Sara Marrugo, the president of Workers Trade Union, and his bodyguard in Cartagena, Bolivar department, Colombia.  The AUC stated that they were putting Sara on trial for suspected involvement with the rival group National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN).  The bodies of Sara and his bodyguard were found in Maria Baja on December 5, 2001; both had been shot.
target1: Aury Sara Marrugo, the president of the Workers Trade Union
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)

summary: 12/01/2001: A group of armed men attacked a bus on a road between Sogamoso and Labranzagrande in Bocaya, Colombia. 15 people were killed. It was not known who was responsible for the attack.
target1: Passengers on a bus on a road between Sogamoso and Labranzagrande in Bocaya, Colombia
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The six attackers rode motorcycles when the attack occurred.  Local paramilitaries and guerrillas elements were suspected as responsible for the attack however a specific group was not identified.
scite1: “Columbia:  Attack on Bus Leaves 15 Dead," Bogota Caracol Colombia Radio, December 1, 2001.

location: In western Caldas
summary: 12/3/2001: Members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) attacked the town of San Lorenzo, Caldas, Colombia.  The assailants killed a 14-year-old girl and injured three people.  They also set fire to 30 houses.  The motive behind the attack is unknown.
target1: Civilians and civilian property in the town of San Lorenzo
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: 30 house were set on fire and villagers were injured of killed; however, there was no mention of specific weapons.

summary: 12/3/2001: Two unidentified gunmen shot and killed Judge Javier Cote Laurenz as he was leaving his house in Santa Marta, Magdalena, Colombia.  The judge had been responsible for the prosecution of paramilitaries and was currently handling a case that involved the son of Adan Rojas, a suspected paramilitary leader.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the judge was involved in a case involving the son of a suspected paramilitary leader
addnotes: It is unclear whether this incident was perpetrated by paramilitaries or common criminals.
scite1: "At least 20 killed in Colombia fighting," Agence France Presse, December 4, 2001.
scite2: "Judge murdered in Santa Marta," El Espectador, December 4, 2001.

location: The incident occurred around the El Kilometro 40 hamlet, Tibu jurisdiction
summary: 12/3/2001: Approximately 200 members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) raided "El Kilometro 40" hamlet, the home of coca leaf pickers, near La Gabarra, Norte de Santander, Colombia.  The assailants blew up 15 houses with tanks filled with dynamite and gasoline.  Six of the workers were killed in the attack; at least one was tortured before being burned alive.  Another three workers were reported missing.  Sources report that the murdered workers refused to give their coca leaves to the assailants.
target1: Coca leaf pickers at "El Kilometro 40" hamlet
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, sources indicate that the attack was part of an attempt by FARC to reclaim that area.
weapdetail: The assailants threw tanks full of dynamite and gasoline at 15 homes.  They also killed six workers.  At least one of the workers had been tortured; his fingers were cut off and bullets had been placed in his nostrils.
propcomment: 15 houses were destroyed
addnotes: Sources report that the murder victims were killed because they refused to turn over their coca leaves to the assailants.  Although police report this was an attack intended to regain territory, it might have been motivated by drugs.
scite1: "FARC Raid in La Gabarra Leaves Six Dead, Three Missing," Bucaramanga Vanguardia Liberal, December 4, 2001.
scite2: "Apparently 24 AUC Members Killed in La Gabarra near 'El Km 40,'" Cucuta La Opinion, December 6, 2001.
scite3: "AUC-FARC Clashes Continue in La Gabarra," Bucaramanga Vanguardia Liberal, December 5, 2001.

summary: 12/08/2001: Colombian soldiers foiled a Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)kidnapping operation at a fake checkpoint along a highway in Acacias, Colombia. Five FARC rebels, and one Colombian soldier were killed in the subsequent firefight that ensued after the kidnapping attempt.
target1: Civilians stopped at a fake checkpoint on a highway in Acacias, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Fire was set to a truck and multiple cars were shot
scite1: “Colombian Army Foils Massive Kidnapping Attempt," Caracol Colombia Radio, December 8, 2001.

summary: 12/09/2001: A low-intensity bomb exploded outside a lottery office in Itagui, Colombia. No one was hurt in the attack, though significant damage occurred to the lottery building. Another building was bombed in Medellin at the time of this attack.
motive: Police suspected the attacks had to do with non-payment of "protection" (extortion) money by lottery businessmen to criminals operating in the region.
propcomment: Damage to windowpanes and the facade of the building.
scite1: “Low-Power Bombs Explode in Itagui, Medellin Lottery Centers; No One Hurt, Only Property Damage," Mexico City NOTIMEX, December 9, 2001.

summary: 12/09/2001: A bomb exploded outside a lottery office in Medellin, Colombia. No one was hurt in the attack, though significant damage occurred to the lottery building. Another building was bombed in Itagui at the time of this attack.
motive: Police suspected that the attacks had to do with non-payment of "protection" (extortion) money by lottery businessmen to criminals operating in the region.
propcomment: Damage to windowpanes and the facade of the building.
scite1: “Low-Power Bombs Explode in Itagui, Medellin Lottery Centers; No One Hurt, Only Property Damage," Mexico City NOTIMEX, December 9, 2001.

summary: 12/09/2001: Twenty-three people were kidnapped by Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels at a hotel resort in Jardin, Colombia. Four of the hostages were killed, and one hotel employee who refused to go along with the rebels was killed. The hostages were taken towards the mountains of the Antioquia region.
target1: Civilians at the Marando Hotel resort in Jardin, Colombia
motive: It was suspected that civilians at the Marando Hotel were targeted due to the likelihood that they would be able to pay high ransoms.
addnotes: FARC later released 15 of the hostages but kept six others.  However, Roberto Sierra, Mayor of Jardin, told local news media that the FARC at the time of the incident had still held 11 people.  The final outcome of the kidnapping was not reported.
scite1: “Colombia:  FARC Kills One in Massive Kidnapping," Caracol Colombia Radio, December 9, 2001.
scite2: “Hostage shot in kidnap," Herald Sun, December 11, 2001.
scite3: “Four kidnap victims killed by Colombian guerrillas," Agence France Presse, December 10, 2001.

location: Along the Caribbean Highway between Riohacha and Santa Marta
summary: 12/10/2001: Members of National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN) set up a checkpoint and abducted 12 people along the Caribbean highway between Riohacha and Santa Marta, La Guajira, Colombia.  The assailants also stole at least 15 vehicles.  Some time later, the ELN members released most, if not all, of the captives, along with the stolen vehicles.  Authorities state that the rebel group is trying to gain control of the highway.
target1: Civilians traveling on the Caribbean Highway
motive: The assailants released a statement claiming that they were "going to clear that area of highway robbers, car thieves, private armies and other organizations using the ELN's name to perpetrate all kinds of crimes against the civilian population."  Authorities state that the ELN is trying to gain control of the highway.
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made.
addnotes: One source states that all of the abductees were released, while other sources state that some abductees were still missing.
scite1: "Bogota TV Highlights 8. [15] Video Report," Bogota Caracol Television, December 10, 2001.
scite2: "ELN Kidnaps Twelve at Illegal Checkpoint in La Guajira," Barranquilla El Heraldo, December 11, 2001.
scite3: "ELN Kidnaps Twelve at Illegal Checkpoint in La Guajira," Barranquilla El Heraldo, December 11, 2001.

summary: 12/10/2001: Members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) attacked Sonson, Antioquia Department, Colombia.  The rebels killed  two people and abducted another two people.  The assailants also fought with the police and raided private homes.  According to sources, the two murder victims, Gloria Carmona Vargas and Samuel de Jesus Gallego Carmona, were killed because they were related to a volunteer soldier.  The motive behind the abduction is unknown.
target1: Gloria Carmona Vargas and Samuel de Jesus Gallego Carmona
motive: The victims were killed because they were related to a volunteer soldier.
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made.

summary: 12/12/2001: Members of People's Revolutionary Army (ERP) set up an illegal checkpoint along the Cauca River near Magangue, Sucre, Colombia.  The rebels stopped a canoe traveling along the river and abducted nine of the passengers.  Three people were released the next day.  Specific motive is unknown.

motive: Unknown

summary: 12/12/2001: Five suspected members of the National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN) kidnapped Adriana Urbano de Moncayo near Buesaco, Narino department, Colombia.  Moncayo was married to Jose Maria Moncayo, the mayor of Buersaco, who asked for her safe return.  Her driver was also kidnapped alongside her but he was later released. location: Along the Cauca River, at Playa Alta, five minutes from Guaranda
summary: 12/12/2001: Members of People's Revolutionary Army (ERP) set up an illegal checkpoint along the Cauca River near Guaranda, Sucre, Colombia.  The rebels kidnapped two peasants in the area.  Specific motive is unknown.

weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made.
addnotes: This incident happened just hours after the same group kidnapped another nine people in the same area.

summary: 12/15/2001: Unidentified attackers entered the village of Samana Colombia with a list of names and killed 15 peasants. The incident took place just hours before scheduled local elections. It was not certain who was responsible for the attack.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: During the incident telecommunication towers in the city were destroyed.
