summary: 12/17/2001: The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)attacked a prison in Florencia, Colombia. An estimated 200 rebels took part in the attack. They attacked the prison in a bold bid to free jailed comrades, but were repelled by guards and government forces. Three inmates were killed, while five other inmates were wounded in the attack. Five guards were also wounded in the attack. Nine inmates escaped through a hole that the rebels had blasted in the prison wall.
motive: FARC rebels attacked the Florencia Prison to free FARC prisoners.
addnotes: At the time of the attack the Florencia prison held 1,100 inmates, many of them were convicted or accused members of FARC.
scite1: “FARC Attack Prison in Florencia," El Tiempo, December 18, 2001.
scite2: “Rebels Attack Colombian Prison," Associated Press, December 18, 2001.
scite3: “Guards repel attack by hundreds of guerrillas on Colombia jail," Associated Press, December 18, 2001.

location: This incident occurred outside of Ocana.
summary: 12/18/2001: National Liberation Army (NLA) rebels kidnapped six people at a fake checkpoint outside of Ocana, Colombia. The incident came less than 24 hours after a unilaterally declared "Christmas Truce" by the ELN. In an subsequent rescue operation two of those kidnapped were rescued, and two ELN rebels were killed. It was not certain if the four other hostages were released.
target1: Civilians at a fake checkpoint outside of Ocana, Colombia
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Kidnapped in the incident were Giovany Rozo, Gerardo Ardila, Alfonso Mejia, his 10-year old daughter, and two others.
scite1: “ELN not honoring truce, kidnaps six people," Caracol Colombia Radio, December 18, 2001.

summary: 01/03/2002: Inhabitants of Cauca, Colombia tried to prevent a Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)takeover of their town by protesting. The guerrillas destroyed the police post, the priest's home, a school, and 20 houses. An Indian and a law school student was murdered while helping a wounded policeman.
target3: Civilians in Cauca, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The guerrillas destroyed the police post, the priest's home, a school, and 20 houses.
scite1: “Efforts to Repel FARC Fail,” Caracol Television, January 3, 2002.

location: The incident occurred in the Granada in the San Civente del Caguan district.
summary: 01/12/2002: Eight civilians and five soldiers were wounded by a car-bomb explosion in Granada, Colombia, near the Demilitarized Zone [DMZ]. A United Nations envoy was meeting with the FARC [Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)]. The explosion took place in front of the facilities housing the 21st Vargas Battalion, where troops were concentrating prior to entering the DMZ.
target1: Colombian troop barracks of the 21st Vargas Battalion near the Demilitarized Zone
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A car bomb was used in the attack.
propcomment: A car bomb exploded in front of the facilities housing the 21st Vargas Battalion.
scite1: “Car Bomb Explodes Near Colombian Demilitarized Zone; 13 Wounded,” AFP to Mexico Central America and the Caribbean, January 12, 2002.

summary: 01/15/2002: A bomb exploded next to a power transmission line in Restrepo, Colombia. Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels were suspected in the attack. Another transmission line was also attacked.
target1: Colombia Electrical Authority transmission lines in Restrepo
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities,” Caracol Colombia Radio, January 16, 2002.
scite2: “FARC Stages Multiple Attacks in Various Parts of Country,” Bogota El Tiempo, January 16, 2002.

summary: 01/15/2002: A bomb exploded next to a power transmission line in Guayabetal, Colombia. Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels were suspected in the attack. Another transmission line was also attacked.
target1: Colombia Electrical Authority transmission lines in Guayabetal
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities,” Caracol Colombia Radio, January 16, 2002.
scite2: “FARC Stages Multiple Attacks in Various Parts of Country,” Bogota El Tiempo, January 16, 2002.

summary: 01/15/2002: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels attacked a police station in Guayata, Colombia. No one was killed or injured in the attack. The police station sustained minor damages.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities,” Caracol Colombia Radio, January 16, 2002.

summary: 01/16/2002: Unknown assailants attacked a market center in Santa Marta, Colombia. Two people were killed, and two others injured in the attack.
target2: Civilians in the Santa Marta Market
motive: Unknown
addnotes: Killed in the attack were Yolanda Palacio, 38, and Jairo Palma Miranda, 32. The injured were German Lopez, 33 and Gerardo Mozo, 31. This was the third attack on the same establishment.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities,” Caracol Colombia Radio, January 16, 2002.
scite2: “FARC Stages Multiple Attacks in Various Parts of Country,” Bogota El Tiempo, January 16, 2002.

location: This attack occurred on a road outside the city of Buenaventura.
summary: 01/16/2002: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels kidnapped a woman along a road outside of Buenaventura, Colombia. The outcome of the kidnapping was unknown.
motive: FARC rebels kidnapped the woman for ransom.
addnotes: Fernandez Jimenez was an economist working in the transportation sector in Cali. Investigators stated she was pursued on the highway, and when she took refuge on her farm she was dragged out and taken toward the mountains. On January 8, 2002, a trucker Julian Astudillo Alzate, 22, was kidnapped in the same area.
scite1: “Colombian Guerrilla, Paramilitary Activities,” Caracol Colombia Radio, January 16, 2002.

location: The incident occurred in the Usme neighborhood
summary: 01/17/2002: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels destroyed a power line in Usme, outside of Bogota, Colombia. No one was injured in the attack.
target1: Colombia Electrical Authority transmission lines in Usme
motive: Unknown
scite1: "FARC Dynamites Electrical Pylons Near Bogota,” Paris AFP, January 17, 2002.

summary: 01/17/2002: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels simultaneously bombed and destroyed two power lines in Casanare Department in Colombia. No one was injured in the attack.
target1: Colombia Electrical Authority transmission lines in Casnare
motive: Unknown
scite1: "FARC Dynamites Electrical Pylons Near Bogota,” Paris AFP, January 17, 2002.

location: This attack occurred along the border of Cauca Department, near Caqueta and Huila
summary: 01/18/2002: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels attacked a Colombian Defense Forces helicopter who had overseen a poppy fumigation effort along the border of Cauca with Caqueta and Huila. Five soldiers were killed in the attack.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The dead were identified as Carlos Alberto Parra Guarin, Jaime Alexander Morera Castro, Ramon Angulo Mosquera, Luis Fernando Sanchez Triana and Carlos Andres Morera Castro.
scite1: “FARC Attacks Leave 15 Soldiers Dead in Valle del Cauca,” El Tiempo, January 20, 2002.

summary: 01/19/2002: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels attacked a military patrol in Pichinde Corregimiento, Colombia. 11 soldiers were killed in the attack.
target1: Third Brigade of the Colombian Army
motive: Unknown
addnotes: At the time of the attack the military had attempted to neutralize a possible attack on Pichinde and nearby El Saladito corregimiento.
scite1: “FARC Attacks Leave 15 Soldiers Dead in Valle del Cauca,” El Tiempo, January 20, 2002.

summary: 01/19/2002: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels detonated a truck-bomb which targeted Army Gaula soldiers in Puente Amarillo, Colombia. Several homes were destroyed. It was not certain how many died or were injured in the attack.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Several nearby homes were destroyed in the attack.
addnotes: At the time of the attack the military had searched for Adid Nader Elias Elkhoure and two others kidnapped by FARC Front No. 30 on January 18, 2002.
scite1: “FARC Attacks Leave 15 Soldiers Dead in Valle del Cauca,” El Tiempo, January 20, 2002.

summary: 01/20/2002: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels attacked various buildings which included the police station in Aguas Blancas, Colombia. The rebels used gas tanks for explosive devices. Two were killed and 10 others injured in the attack.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Several nearby homes were damaged in the attack.
scite1: “FARC Attacks Force Towns To Ration Electricity,” El Tiempo, January 22, 2002.

summary: 01/20/2002: Unidentified assailants, suspected to be Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels indiscriminately attacked the Main Square of Quipile, Colombia. Two people were killed, and one person was seriously injured in the attack.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “FARC Attacks Force Towns To Ration Electricity,” El Tiempo, January 22, 2002.

summary: 01/20/2002: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels torched a gasoline tanker along a road in Guaduas, Colombia. One person was injured in the attack.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The gasoline tanker was stolen several hours before it was destroyed.
scite1: “FARC Attacks Force Towns To Ration Electricity,” El Tiempo, January 22, 2002.

summary: 01/20/2002: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels destroyed an electricity transformer line in Guaduas, Colombia. No one was injured in the attack.
target1: Colombia Electrical transmission lines in Guaduas
motive: Unknown
scite1: “FARC Attacks Force Towns To Ration Electricity,” El Tiempo, January 22, 2002.

location: This attack occurred along a road between Cumaral and Paretebueno
summary: 01/22/2002: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels kidnapped an undetermined number of people along a highway between Cumaral and Paretebueno, Colombia. In addition to the kidnapping they torched several cars in the attack.
target1: Civilians along a highway between Cumaral and Paretebueno, Colombia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Several cars were destroyed in the operation
addnotes: The incident came a day after the signing of an agreement between FARC and the Colombian government. According to witnesses, members of the FARC's 53d Front, blocked the road and took away an unknown number of people.
scite1: “FARC Break Accord, Carry Out Massive Kidnapping,” Caracol Colombia Radio, January 22, 2002.

summary: 01/25/2002: A bomb planted in a bicycle exploded in Bogota, Colombia. Five people were killed in the attack and 28 people were injured. FARC rebels were blamed for the attack.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: An explosive device consisting of 4.5 pounds of explosives and 4.5 pounds of shrapnel and a time fuse, placed inside of a bicycle basket, was used in the attack
scite1: “Bogota in State of Alert Over Terrorist Attack,” El Tiempo, January 26, 2002.
scite2: “Child, 4 police officers killed in Bogota bombing,” Chicago Tribune, January 26, 2002.
scite3: "COLOMBIA PINS BOMBING ON FARC,” Orlando Sentinel, January 26, 2002.

location: Turbo town, 600 miles northwest of Bogota
summary: 1/26/2002: Unidentified assailants threw a grenade in Turbo, Antioquia, Colombia.  Eight people were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility.  The area is a contested area for military, paramilitary, and guerrillas.
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, sources note that the attack occurred in an area that is contested between military, paramilitary, and guerrillas.
scite1: "Sixteen wounded in two grenade attacks in Colombia," Agence France Presse, January 27, 2002.

summary: 01/28/2002: A car bomb exploded in Cucuta, Colombia. One person was injured in the attack, and significant damage occurred to a nearby bank building. National Liberation Army (NLA) rebels were blamed for the attack.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Colombian Authorities Blame ELN for Car Bomb Explosion in Cucuta,” Radio Cadena Nacional, January 28, 2002.

summary: 1/28/2002:  Members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) killed seven people in a rural area of Huila province, Colombia.  The assailants forced their way into a family residence, shot four family members, and decapitated a servant.  They proceeded to shoot two more people who were riding by on a motorcycle at the time of the attack.  Before fleeing, the assailants set fire to several surrounding houses.  Authorities speculate the attack may have been related to a recent closure of a route regularly used by FARC.
target1: Civilians living in a rural area of Huila province
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, authorities speculate that the attack may have been connected to a recent closure of a route used by FARC members.
weapdetail: Six people were shot, while the head of a seventh victim was cut off.
propcomment: Several houses were set on fire
addnotes: One of the victims was an eight-year-old girl
scite1: "Army - FARC kills seven peasant - four from one family," EFE News Service, January 28, 2002.
scite2: "Eight Girls Among FARC Casualties in Huila," Bogota El Espectador, January 30, 2002.

summary: 01/30/2002: Thirteen people were injured in a bomb attack in Arauca, Colombia. The bomb was thrown from a moving dump truck. It was suspected the intended target was a nearby military garrison and not the residential area that was struck by the blast.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “New Terrorist Attack Leaves 13 Wounded in Arauca,” Caracol Colombia Radio, January 30, 2002.

location: On 39th street at 22nd Avenue, in Le Soledad neighborhood
summary: 1/30/2002: An improvised explosive device exploded outside of the headquarters of Caracol Television in Bogota, Distrito Capital, Colombia.  The device consisted of 30 kilograms of dynamite wired to an electrical system hidden in a stolen jeep.  No one was injured in the explosion, but the surrounding area was badly damaged.  No group has claimed responsibility for the incident, although authorities suspect the involvement of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the defense minister stated that it was an assault on freedom of the press.
weapdetail: 30 kilograms of dynamite wired to an electrical system
propcomment: The explosion did heavy damage to the surrounding buildings
scite1: "Car bomb blasts Bogota," CNN, January 30, 2002.
scite2: "Colombia: Defence minister condemns car bomb attack on Caracol TV," Caracol Colombia, January 30, 2002.
scite3: "Car bombs kill six in Colombia as terror wave continues," Associated Press, January 30, 2002.

summary: 02/01/2002: A car bomb inside of a taxi exploded in Cucuta, Colombia, causing property damage, but no casualties. Police attributed the attack to the National Liberation Army (NLA).
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A car bomb consisting of a 40lb. gas cylinder and a wooden box containing 30kg of ammonal, placed inside of a taxi cab, was used in the attack
propcomment: A dump truck and SUV were destroyed.
scite1: "Colombia: Another Car Bomb Explodes in Cucuta," Bogota Radio Cadena Nacional, February 1, 2002.
scite2: "Highlights: Colombian Guerrilla/Paramilitary Activities 1 Feb 02," Colombia -- FBIS Report,  February 1, 2002

summary: 02/04/2002: In El Dorado, Colombia, seven officers in the Colombian Army were killed when a bomb exploded in a house that they were searching. The bomb was apparently planted by the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC).
target1: Armed Forces in El Dorado,  Colombia
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The report stated that 22 soldiers were missing and presumed dead; however, it is unknown if that is in relation to this incident or another story altogether.
scite1: Dayani, Martin, “Colombian Troops Die in Blasts,” The New York Times Company, February 6, 2002.

location: The mayor's office in Argelia
summary: 5/3/2002: Members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) kidnapped Mayor Jorge Ivan Cardona from his office in Argelia, Antioquia, Colombia.  The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown.
target1: Mayor Jorge Ivan Cardona from Argelia
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
addnotes: The town of Argelia does not have a police force.
scite1: "Mayor of Argelia Kidnapped," Bogota Radio Cadena Nacional, May 3, 2002.

summary: 02/06/2002: In Sincelejo, Colombia, an investigator employed by the Prosecutor's office was killed by gunfire from an individual on a motorcycle. A woman walking nearby was also wounded by the gunfire.
target1: Investigator for the Technical Investigation Group
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Colombia: Chengue Massacre Investigator Killed," Bogota El Tiempo, February 7, 2002.
scite2: "Highlights: Colombian Guerrilla/Paramilitary Activities 7 Feb 02," Colombia -- FBIS Report, February 7, 2002.

location: Between the municipalities of Abrego and Gramalote
summary: 02/09/2002: Near the towns of Abrego and Gramalote in the Norte de Santander Department of Colombia, dynamite explosions were used by the National Liberation Army (NLA) to destroy electricity towers, leaving five municipalities without power.
target1: Electrical towers in the Norte de Santander Department
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) commonly target electricity towers in Colombia.
scite1: "Colombia: ELN Rebels Destroy 5 More Electricity Towers," Bogota Radio Cadena Nacional, February 9, 2002.

summary: 02/10/2002: An explosive device exploded outside of the Ganadero Bank in Arauca, Colombia, causing damage to four city blocks, but no casualties. Police found an unknown number of additional explosives that they defused without causing additional damage, as well as insignias belonging to the National Liberation Army (NLA).
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Colombia: Bomb Causes 'Huge' Property Damage in Arauca; No One Hurt", Bogota Radio Cadena Nacional, February 10, 2002.

summary: 02/11/2002: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels attacked the town of Salgar, Colombia, by dynamiting a farm and cutting power to the town, frightening residents.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: An unspecified explosive device was used in the attack
propcomment: A farm was damaged.
scite1: “Highlights: Colombian Guerilla/Paramilitary Activities 12 Feb 02,” Colombia – FBIS Report, February 12, 2002.

summary: 02/13/2002: Suspected guerillas on a motorcycle hurled a hand grenade in the industrial sector of Samana, Colombia, injuring one person and causing property damage.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The explosion caused property damage.
scite1: “Highlights: Colombian Guerilla/Paramilitary Activities 15 Feb 02,” Colombia – FBIS Report, February 15, 2002.
scite2: “Highlights: Colombia Regional Press 15 Feb 02,” Colombia – FBIS Report, February 15, 2002.

summary: 02/13/2002: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels attacked a power plant in Albania, Colombia, knocking out power to three towns for five hours. Only 2 of the 5 gas cylinders used in the attack had exploded; no one was hurt.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Only two of the five gas cylinders planted at the plant exploded.
propcomment: The explosion damaged the pipeline.
scite1: “Highlights: Colombian Guerilla/Paramilitary Activities 14 Feb 02,” Colombia – FBIS Report, February 14, 2002.

summary: 02/15/2002: Two bombs exploded simultaneously in a Cumana supermarket in the market square of Riohacha, Colombia. No one was hurt, but $73 million worth of damage was caused to ten nearby stores. Police did not know whether guerillas or criminals were responsible for the attack.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Forty kg of dynamite were used in the attack.
propcomment: The explosions damaged 10 stores.
scite1: “Two Bombs in Riohacha Cause Property Damage Worth 800 Million Pesos; No One Hurt,” Caracol Television, February 15, 2002.
scite2: “Highlights: Colombian Guerrilla/Paramilitary Activities 18 Feb 02,” Colombia – FBIS Report, February 18, 2002.

location: The hijacked airplane landed on a road near Hobo, Colombia.
summary: 02/20/2002: Suspected Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) guerrillas hijacked a domestic airliner and forced it to land near the town of Hobo, Colombia. They then kidnapped Senator Jorge Eduardo Gechem Turbay from the plane.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The Aires plane's other 29 passengers and crew were freed unharmed on the ground. The response of the Colombian government to the kidnapping of the senator was to withdraw from peace talks with the FARC and to initiate a military campaign of retaking the FARC's government-recognized safe haven.
scite1: “Suspected Leftist Guerrillas Hijack Plane, Seize Senator,” The Star Phoenix, February 21, 2002.
scite2: Scott Wilson, “Colombian Army Ordered Into Haven As Rebel Talks End,” The Washington Post, February 21, 2002.

summary: 1/23/2002: Two unidentified gunmen on a motorcycle shot Marcos Ayala near his office in Cali, Valle del Cauca, Colombia.  He died later from his injuries while in hospital.  Ayala was a photographer for the newspaper El Caleno; he specialized in social and sporting events while the newspaper specialized in crime reporting.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident and the motive behind the attack is unknown.
target1: Marco Ayala, a photographer for the newspaper El Caleno
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Newspaper photographer killed in Colombia," Xinhua General News Service, January 24, 2002.
scite2: "Colombia journalist dies two days after being shot," Associated Press, February 2, 2002.
scite3: "Gunman kills Colombia newspaper photographer," Reuters News, January 23, 2002.

summary: 02/22/2002: As part of a series of nationwide infrastructure attacks, Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) rebels attacked a power station in Altamira, in the Huila Department of Colombia. The attack cut power in the Huila as well as the Caquetá Departments. One worker at the station was killed as a result of the blast.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The power station in Altamira was destroyed.
addnotes: This attack was part of a coordinated nationwide infrastructure attack by the FARC (cf. 200202220001; 200202230002; 200202270001-02; 200202280003). The explosion resulted in loss of electricity in neighboring towns.
scite1: "FARC fights back with attacks on infrastructure across Colombia," Agence France Presse, February 22, 2002.
scite2: "Colombia's FARC launches a series of attacks against infrastructure; one dead," AFX, February 22, 2002.
scite3: "Guerilla's bomb gas pipeline," Business News America, February 22, 2002.

location: This incident occurred on the road between Florencia and Neiva.
summary: 02/23/2002: As part of a series of nationwide infrastructure attacks by the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC), two bridges were destroyed on the road connecting the towns of Florencia, in Caqueta Department, and Neiva, in Huila Department.
target1: Two bridges connecting Florencia and Neiva
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Two bridges were destroyed in the attack.
addnotes: This attack was part of a coordinated nationwide infrastructure attack by the FARC (cf. 200202220001; 200202230002; 200202270001-02; 200202280003). The government authorized a Hercules transport plane to make five flights a day from Bogota to Florencia to bring in supplies.
scite1: "Conflict Colombia: Rebels attack leave countryside in darkness," Inter Presse Service, February 27, 2002.
scite2: "Colombia war seen more as Terrorism," The Associated Press, March 2, 2002.
scite3: "Colombian military to expand crackdown, as rebels strike power lines," Agence France Presse, March 1, 2002.

summary: 02/23/2002:  FARC rebels introduced an unknown agent into the Pitalito water treatment plan.  No injuries were reported in the incident.
motive: Unknown.
weapdetail: Unknown.
scite1: “Colombian Experts Warn of Intensification of FARC Terrorist Actions,” Bogota Cambio- internet version, February 25, 2002.
scite2: “Colombia: Article Explains How “Theaters of Operation” Work,” Bogota Cambio-internet version, March 4, 2002.
scite3: “Colombian Water Treatment Plant Poisoned,” Xinhua General News Service, February 23, 2002.

summary: 2/24/2002: Approximately five members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) killed at least five residents of La Macarena, a town located within an area that used to be rebel-controlled in Meta department, Colombia.  The government had ceded the area to FARC as a good faith gesture when peace negotiations had begun several years prior; however, the government had canceled the peace negotiations the week before and were moving military into the area to reclaim it.  Residents stated that FARC began attacking villagers because they no longer had reason to feel responsible for their well being.
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the rebels moved into the area and began killing civilians after the government stated they were going to reclaim the demilitarized area.  Local people report that some of the killings were related to land disputes.  They also stated that the rebels no longer felt responsible for the well being of the villagers.
addnotes: The assailants stated "We killed them because they are our enemies"
scite1: "18 dead, serious damage as Colombia rebels strike," New Zealand Press Association, February 26, 2002.
scite2: "Colombian rebels go on killing rampage," The New York Times, February 27, 2002.
scite3: "Killings by rebels shatter peace in farm town, Colombians say," The Houston Chronicle, February 27, 2002.

location: The victims were kidnapped while traveling from Florencia to San Vicente del Caguan.
summary: 02/25/2002: Presidential candidate Senator Ingrid Betancourt and campaign manager Clara Rojas were kidnapped by Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) members while traveling from Florencia to the town of San Vicente del Caguan, Colombia. Three civilians traveling with the Senator were set free and no injuries were reported. The outcome of the kidnapping was not known.
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Guerillas abduct former senator," Irish News, February 25, 2002.
scite2: "Leftists kidnap would-be leader," The Journal (Newcastle, UK), February 25, 2002.
scite3: "Colombia pres candidate seized: she's kidnapped by leftist guerillas," Philadelphia Daily News, February 25, 2002.

summary: 02/27/2002: As part of a series of nationwide infrastructure attacks, Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) members blew up the power substation in the city of Arauca, Colombia, which resulted in wide-scale power outages and water service disruptions throughout the country.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The losses caused by the attack on the substation were approximately 12 billion pesos ($5 million), and the authorities are preparing a contingency plan to overcome this critical situation. Authorities estimated that it would take at least 30 days to repair the damage. The water supply service was also affected by the attack since the water pumps depend on electricity to operate.
scite1: Yadira Ferrer, “Conflict-Colombia: Rebels attack leave countryside in the dark,” Inter Press Service, February 27, 2002.
scite2: “Colombia: Terrorist Attacks on Electrical Infrastructure Affect 15 Municipalities,” Bogota Caracol Colombia Radio, February 28, 2002.
scite3: “FARC bombs Colombia into darkness,” Xinhua General News Service, March 1, 2002.

summary: 02/23/2002: As part of a series of nationwide infrastructure attacks by the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC), telecommunications towers and electricity pylons were targeted in Florencia, Caquetá Department, Colombia. As a result of the attack, the city was without power and communication was cut off between Florencia and the rest of the country.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Several electrical pylons and telecommunications towers were destroyed.
addnotes: This attack was part of a coordinated nationwide infrastructure attack by the FARC (cf. 200202220001; 200202230002; 200202270001-02; 200202280003). Several other electrical pylons were destroyed in the Caquetá department as well as other regions throughout the country.
scite1: "Conflict Colombia: Rebels attack leave countryside in darkness," Inter Presse Service, February 27, 2002.
scite2: "Colombia war seen more as Terrorism," The Associated Press, March 2, 2002.
scite3: "Colombian military to expand crackdown, as rebels strike power lines," Agence France Presse, March 1, 2002.

summary: 02/28/2002: As part of a series of nationwide attacks by Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) guerillas, nearly 100 Colombian towns in the departments of Caqueta, Huila, Meta, Narino, Arauca and Boyaca provinces suffered electricity outages and many other towns have suffered from attacks on their telephone communication systems. It was not clear from reports which specific pylons and telecommunications systems targeted by the FARC caused which aspects of the damage.
motive: Unknown
scite1: "FARC Bombs Colombia into Darkness," Xinhua General News, March 1, 2002.
scite2: "Colombia's infrastructure under siege, Guerilla attacks causes power outages," Electric Utility Week, March 4, 2002.
scite3: "Colombia: Terrorist Attacks on Electrical Infrastructure Affect 15 Municipalities," Bogata Caracol Colombia, February 28, 2002.

location: The Pan-American Highway; the Pereira-Belen de Umbria section
summary: 3/29/2002: Suspected members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) set up an illegal road block near Belen de Umbria, Risaralda Department, Colombia.  The rebels took at least two civilians hostage.  Specific motive is unknown.
target1: Civilians stopped at a road block near Belen de Umbria
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
addnotes: One source states that there were 20 assailants while another states there were 80.  In addition, one source states that two people were kidnapped while a second source states that three people were kidnapped.
scite1: "Six kidnapped - 14 dead in Colombia violence," Agence France Presse, March 31, 2002.
scite2: "ELN FARC kidnap seven - torch three vehicles in two illegal roadblocks in Risaralda department," Pereira El Diario del Otun, April 1, 2002.
scite3: "No guerrilla truce during Holy Week," Bogota Radio Cadena Nacional, March 30, 2002.

location: 35 miles north of Bogota
summary: 3/1/2002: Three bodies were discovered near Zipacon, Cundinamarca Department, Colombia.  The bodies were identified as Senator Martha Catalina Daniels, Ana Maria Medina, and the senator's driver, Carlos Lozano.  The three victims had been shot and their bodies bore signs of torture.  The husband of Ana Maria Medina had been kidnapped by Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC)  a year previous and Senator Daniels had been negotiating his release.  The three had left the Senator's residence on March 1, 2002 and their bodies were found on March 3, 2002.  Authorities suspect that FARC is responsible for the killing.
target2: The driver and the friend of the Senator, Carlos Lozano and Ana Maria Medina
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the senator had been trying to negotiate the release of Medina's husband, who was also a politician.  Sources also indicate that FARC may have been threatening the Senator, due to her husband's involvement in corruption.
weapdetail: The victims had been shot in the head and were bruised, possibly indicating torture.
addnotes: It is unclear whether the victim's had been killed while trying to negotiate the release of hostages or were killed due to their ties to corruption.
scite1: "Changes dateline from BOGOTA; Colombian senator friend and driver killed and dumped in ravine," Associated Press, March 3, 2002.
scite2: "Colombian rebels kill 3 including senator," CNN, March 3, 2002.
scite3: Neil Pyper, "Senator Murdered as Concern Increases that Elections Could be Threatened," World Markets Analysis, March 4, 2002.

location: On the road to the airport
summary: 4/3/2002:  Suspected members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) kidnapped the mayor of Cravo Norte, Arauca Department, Colombia.  Mayor Ernesto Espitia was in a taxi on the way to the airport when assailants abducted him.  No ransom demands were made.
target1: Ernesto Espitia, mayor of Cravo Norte
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, sources note that politicians are often kidnapped in order to intimidate or collect ransom
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
scite1: "Colombia bombs military rebels - claims dozens killed; two mayors kidnapped," Associated Press, April 3, 2002.
scite2: "U.N. Calls for End to Kidnappings in Colombia," Xinhua General News Service, April 6, 2002.
scite3: "Suspected Colombian rebels kidnap two mayors, three councilmen," EFE News Service, April 4, 2002.

location: On the road connecting Santa Barbara and Monte Bello
summary: 4/3/2002: Suspected members of United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) kidnapped a union leader near Santa Barbara, Nariño Department, Colombia.  Paramilitaries set up an illegal checkpoint on the road between Santa Barbara and Monte Bello; they abducted Alfredo Zapata from a bus of cement factory employees.  His body was found on April 4, 2002.
target1: Alfredo Zapata, a union leader for the Sole Union of Construction Material Industry
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, several unions have called strikes in Colombia to protest paramilitary kidnappings and violence.
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
scite1: "Colombian oil workers call off two-week strike," Agence France Presse, April 5, 2002.
scite2: "Unionist Murdered," Bogota El Espectador, April 5, 2002.

summary: 03/05/2002: The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)bombed two electrical towers in the central Columbian province of Meta, leaving tens of thousands without electricity. No injuries as a result of the explosion were reported.
target1: Electric Pylons in the Meta Province
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: An unspecified explosive device was used in the attack
propcomment: The FARC bombed power grid and a 115-kw pylon in the incident.
scite1: “FARC Attacks Mesetas, Former DMZ Town,” Radio Cadena Nacional, March 6, 2002.
scite2: “FARC Attack Leaves 11 Municipalities in Meta without Electricity,” Caracol Television, March 5, 2002.
scite3: “Colombian rebels attack electrical supply, leave 13 towns in dark,” Deutsche Presse-Agentur, March 5, 2002.

summary: 03/12/2002: A car bomb explosion killed five people, three civilians and two soldiers, in downtown Puerto Lleras in the Meta Department in southern Colombia. The Colombian military implicated Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)urban forces in the attack, although no official claim of responsibility was made.
target1: Indiscriminate civilians in downtown Puerto Lleras in the Meta Department in southern Colombia
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: An unspecified bomb implanted in an automobile was used in the incident.
propcomment: An automobile was destroyed in the incident.
scite1: “Car Bomb Explosion in Puerto Lleras Kills Five, Injures Three,” Caracol Television, March 12, 2002.
scite2: “Car Bomb Kills Four in Southern Colombia,” Xinhua General News Service, March 13, 2002.
scite3: “FARC Blamed For Lethal Colombian Car Bomb Attack,” Deutsche Presse-Agentur, March 12, 2002.

summary: 03/16/2002: Colombian archbishop, Isaias Duarte Cancino, was shot dead by two unidentified men with pistols in Cali after administering a wedding procession. Monsignor Cancino was an outspoken and influential political critic of Colombia’s Leftist guerrilla groups and drug lords, going so far as to excommunicate large numbers of the National Liberation Army (NLA) and the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) (FARC). No one claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Archbishop Monsignor Isaias Duarte Cancino in Cali, Columbia
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Unspecified weapons were used in the incident
scite2: Emma Wilson and Juan O. Tamayo, “Cleric's Murder Linked To Drug Lords; Traffickers Well-Known As Ruthless,” The Miami Herald, March 18. 2002.
scite3: Jeremy Mcdermott, “Colombia's Outspoken Archbishop Shot Dead at Church,” The Scotsman, March 18, 2002.

summary: 03/20/2002: A car bomb exploded near the United States Embassy in Lima, Peru, that killed nine people, injured thirty-two, and caused heavy damage to the surrounding buildings and cars. The United States State Department reported no American casualties, injuries, or damage to the embassy’s infrastructure. No one officially claimed responsibility for the attack, but U.S. and Peruvian intelligence agencies suspected the involvement of the Shining Path (Sendero Luminoso). It was believed that the bombing was meant to coincide with President Bush’s upcoming March 23, 2002 visit to Lima.
target1: Indiscriminate civilians in downtown Lima, Peru
target2: United States Embassy in Lima, Peru
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: An unspecified bomb implanted in an automobile was used in the incident.
propcomment: The explosion caused heavy damage to the surrounding buildings and cars, but no monetary damage estimate was reported.
scite1: Michelle Mittelstadt and Richard Whittle, “Shining Path Rebels Suspected In Lima Car Bombing,” The Dallas Morning News, March 22, 2002.
scite2: Alejandro Reyes, Gustavo Sanchez, and Daniel Titinger, “Further Details on Car-Bomb Explosion Near US Embassy,” El Comercio, March 21, 2002.
scite3: John J. Lumpkin, “U.S. intelligence suspects Shining Path movement in Peru bombing,” Associated Press Worldstream, March 21, 2002.

summary: 3/18/2002: Members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) attacked the village of Mapiripan in Meta Department, Colombia.  The rebels fired homemade mortars at the village, causing 1500 residents to flee.  FARC believed that the villagers had collaborated with right-wing paramilitaries.
motive: The rebels believed that the villagers had been collaborating with right-wing paramilitaries
weapdetail: Homemade mortars, gas cylinder bombs
propcomment: Homemade mortars were fired at the village
addnotes: There is no mention of the number of dead or injured.
scite1: "Colombian Cops: 1500 flee rebels," Associated Press, March 26, 2002.
scite2: "New displacement from Mapiripan - Meta department - 1500 flee attack," Bogota Radio Cadena Nacional, March 26, 2002.

location: Between La Estrella and Barro Blanco
summary: 3/28/2002: Suspected members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) set up an illegal road block near San Clemente, Risaralda Department, Colombia.  The rebels took eight people hostage, releasing four, and lit two tractor trailers on fire.  Specific motive is unknown.
target1: Civilians stopped at a road block near San Clemente
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
addnotes: One source states that four people were kidnapped, while a second source states that eight people were kidnapped but four were released.

scite2: "ELN FARC kidnap seven - torch three vehicles in two illegal roadblocks in Risaralda department," Pereira El Diario del Otun, April 1, 2002.
scite3: "No guerrilla truce during Holy Week," Bogota Radio Cadena Nacional, March 30, 2002.

location: Near the border with Colombia
summary: 3/30/2002: A bomb exploded in front of a discotheque in Puerto Carreno, Vichada Department, Colombia.  At least two soldiers were killed in the explosion and 14 civilians were injured.  Authorities suspect that members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) were responsible for the incident.
target2: Soldiers in the area of the disco
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the incident occurred during increased attacks by Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC)
addnotes: Sources provided different reports of the number killed and injured.  Estimates on fatalities ranged from two to six, and estimates on injuries ranged from 14 to 30.
scite1: "Easter brings no break in fighting in Colombia," Agence France Presse, April 1, 2002.
scite2: Easterbrook, Michael, "Colombian church leaders still outspoken after killing of archbishop," Associated Press, March 31, 2002.
scite3: "No guerrilla truce during Holy Week," Bogota Radio Cadena Nacional, March 30, 2002.

summary: 4/3/2002:  Suspected members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) kidnapped the mayor of Saravena, Arauca Department, Colombia.  Mayor Jose Trinidad Sierra, along with three councilmen, were abducted by armed assailants.  No ransom demands were made.
target1: Jose Trinidad Sierra, mayor of Saravena, and councilors Sebastian Vera Alvarado y Saravena, Alvaro Salinas Rodriguez and Fernando Serrano
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, sources note that politicians are often kidnapped in order to intimidate or collect ransom
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
scite1: "Colombia bombs military rebels - claims dozens killed; two mayors kidnapped," Associated Press, April 3, 2002.
scite2: "U.N. Calls for End to Kidnappings in Colombia," Xinhua General News Service, April 6, 2002.
scite3: "Suspected Colombian rebels kidnap two mayors, three councilmen," EFE News Service, April 4, 2002.

summary: 5/4/2002: Approximately 100 members from Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) attacked the town of Rovira, Tolima Department, Colombia.  The assailants detonated explosive devices at the police station, a bank, and various other public buildings and private homes.  They also planted mines on access roads leading into Rovira.  A soldier and a police officer were killed in the attack and two civilians were wounded.
target1: Various buildings and businesses, including a bank, a telecommunication company, and other stores
target3: Private homes and civilians in Rovira
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Various private and public buildings were destroyed
addnotes: One less-credible source states that the incident was perpetrated in order to rob a bank.
scite1: "Two killed in FARC attack on Colombian town," EFE News Service, May 4, 2002.
scite2: "FARC guerrillas attack Rovira - Tolima; One policeman dead," Medellin El Colombiano, May 6, 2002.

location: In the restaurant and nightclub district of Villavicencio, 113 kilometers southeast of Bogota
summary: 4/7/2002: A car bomb exploded in the busy entertainment district of Villavicencio, Meta department, Colombia.  A smaller device exploded first, drawing a crowd; it was followed by a powerful car bomb that damaged nearby buildings.  At least twelve people were killed and at least another 70 were injured.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, authorities speculate that Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) were involved.
target2: Businesses located in the entertainment district, including a radio station.
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, polls open on May 26 and one of the candidates has promised to crack down on rebel activity.
weapdetail: A car packed with 110 pounds of explosives
propcomment: Cars and buildings were damaged
addnotes: One source states that 70 people were injured while another source states that 100 were injured.
scite1: Jose Ramos, "Colombia car bomb kills 12, injures 100; gunmen kill another priest," Agence France Presse, April 7, 2002.
scite2: Ibon Villelabeitia, "Car bomb kills 12 in Colombia," Reuters, April 7, 2002.

summary: 4/9/2002: An improvised explosive device detonated outside of a bookstore in Bogota, Distrito Capital, Colombia.  The device consisted of explosives packed into a gas cylinder.  At least one person was injured in the attack.  Authorities blame the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) for the incident.  This was one of several bombs that were attributed to FARC that day.
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, authorities note that the incident occurred on the same day that Jorge Eliecer Gaitan was assassinated in 1948.  They believe that the incident was a commemoration.
weapdetail: Explosives packed into a gas cylinder
scite1: "Three bombs explode in Bogota - rebels blamed," Reuters News, April 10, 2002.
scite2: "Colombia: Five low-powered bombs go off in Bogota - 4 injured," Bogota Radio Cadena Nacional, April 9, 2002/

Authorities blame the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) for the failed attempt.  This was one of several bombs that were attributed to FARC that day.

summary: 04/14/2002: A car-bomb exploded along Colombian Presidential Candidate Alvaro Uribe Velez's campaign route in Barranquilla as he traveled to the Port Authority headquarters. The bomb destroyed Uribe's armored car and a bus. Uribe was not killed. There were 3 civilian causalties and approximately 20 injured. There were no claims of responsibility, though the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)is suspected.
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Colombia's presidential candidate Alvaro Uribe emerges unscathed from terrorist attack," Caracas Globovision Television, 04/14/2002.

scite3: "Political candidate survives Colombian bridge explosion," The Globe and Mail, 04/15/2002.

location: The mayor's office in Chiscas, north of Tunja
summary: 4/17/2002: Members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) kidnapped Mayor Reynaldo Davila Rincon, from his office in Chiscas, Boyaca Department, Colombia.  Specific motive is unknown; however, it is suspected that he will be forced to participate in an trial for allowing municipal elections to occur when FARC prohibited them.
target1: Reynaldo Davila Rincon, mayor of Chiscas
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, it is suspected that the mayor will be forced to participate in an trial for allowing municipal elections to occur when FARC prohibited them.
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
scite1: "Chiascas Mayor Kidnapped," Bogota El Tiempo, April 22, 2002.

location: On the Popayan-Pasto road between Timbio and Rosas, 390 kilometers from Bogota
summary: 4/19/2002: Members of National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN) kidnapped at least six people near Rosas town in Cauca Department, Colombia.  The rebels set up a roadblock and stopped several vehicles, kidnapping Jesus Salazar, the mayor of Rosas, and at least five other people.  Specific motive is unknown; however, several days before the kidnapping, Salazar had led a march requesting that the rebels leave Rosas town alone.  The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown.

target2: Civilians stopped at a roadblock near Rosas town

scite3: "Seven kidnapped by ELN between Cauca and Narino Departments," Bogota El Tiempo, April 22, 2002.

location: The helicopter departed Cali and was somewhere between Cauca and Narino Departments when the incident occurred.
summary: 4/19/2002: Members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) hijacked a private helicopter and its four passengers after it departed from Cali, Valle del Cauca Department, Colombia.  The helicopter was traveling from Canada to Bolivia and was carrying two Canadians, an Ecuadoran, and a French citizen.  The motive behind the incident is unknown, as is the outcome of the kidnapping.
target1: Two Canadians, an Ecuadoran, and a French citizen who were traveling by helicopter from Canada to Bolivia
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
addnotes: Media reports that more than two weeks following the kidnapping, authorities still had not received demands for the release of the abductees.  The missing people were Guilles Pregent, Pierre Gallipon, and Jay Rideni.  The name of the Ecuadoran is unknown.
scite1: "Authorities report more kidnaps by FARC - helicopter hijacked by FARC," El Espectador, May 4, 2002.
scite2: "2 Canadians among 4 hostages taken by Colombian rebels," Reuters News, May 03, 2002.
scite3: "FARC hijacked helicopter with four foreigners aboard: general," Agence France Presse, May 3, 2002.

location: Pan-American Highway on the Boyaca-Cundinamarca Border
summary: 4/23/2002: Ten uniformed members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) set up an illegal checkpoint on the Pan-American Highway on the  border between Boyaca and Cundinamarca Departments in Colombia.  The guerrillas burned a car and a bus and kidnapped Cesar Cabana, a former interior secretary.  The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown.
target1: Cesar Cabana, a former interior secretary, and two vehicles
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Two vehicles were lit on fire
propcomment: A bus and a car were lit on fire
scite1: "FARC blocks Pan-American highway on the Boyaca-Cundinamarca border," Bogota Caracol Radio, April 23, 2002.

location: Montesol plantation near the town of Turbo, in the Uraba region of northwest Colombia, 600 kilometers northwest of Bogota
summary: 4/26/2002: Suspected members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) attacked the Montesol plantation near the town of Turbo, Antioquia Department, Colombia.  Nine farm workers were shot and killed and another 18 were wounded in the attack.  The assailants carried a list of names; they forced workers who were named on the list to leave the plantation, then executed them.  Specific motive is unknown.
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, sources speculate that the attack was related to plantation workers' support of a conservative presidential candidate
scite1: "Rebels blamed for killings of farm worders in Colombia," EFE News Service, April 26, 2002.
scite2: "FARC guerrillas likely responsible for deaths of nine banana farmers," Agence France Presse, April 26, 2002.
scite3: "Nine peasants massacred in Uraba," Bogota Radio Cadena Nacional, April 26, 2002.

summary: 5/31/2002: Members of National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN) kidnapped two merchants on the Medellin-Bogota highway, Antioquia Department, Colombia.  The motive behind the kidnapping is unknown.

summary: 5/31/2002: Members of National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN) stopped several vehicles and abducted four people in Antioquia Department, Colombia.  The motive behind the kidnapping is unknown.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
addnotes: The motive behind the kidnapping is unknown.  It may have been financially motivated.

summary: 05/01/2002: A package bomb exploded in front of a restaurant in Pereira, Colombia killing a woman and her young son. Authorities believed that either the Ejercito de Liberación Nacional (ELN) or the Urban Militias of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)were responsible for the attack. The bomb exploded when the mother attempted to defuse the package, which contained 2 kilograms of ammonium nitrate. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bomb was placed in a package.
addnotes: Although members of the Ejercito de Liberación Nacional (ELN) were the primary suspects, authorities also believed that Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) could have perpetrated the bombing.
scite1: "Colombia: FARC-Paramilitary Confrontations Leave 60 Wounded in Choco,” El Tiempo, May 3, 2002

summary: 05/01/2002: A bicycle bomb exploded killing two civilians and injuring two Colombian soldiers in Colombia's Calamar Municipality. The commander of Mobile Brigade No. 7, Colonel Jairo Rodriguez blamed the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)for the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target2: Two Colombian soldiers stationed in Calamar Municipality
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Apparently some kind of bomb was planted on bicycle and it exploded.
addnotes: Colombian Colonel, Jairo Rodriquez, accused the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC), but he offered no evidence to support his claim.
scite1: "Colombia: FARC-Paramilitary Confrontations Leave 60 Wounded in Choco,” El Tiempo, May 3, 2002

location: Between San Vincente del Caguan and Florencia
summary: 05/01/2002: Suspected members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)abducted nine unarmed and out of uniform Colombian soldiers while they were traveling overland from San Vicente del Caguan to Florencia in Colombia. On May 12, 2002 Colombian General Luis Alberto Ardila Silva reported that all nine soldiers had been killed by FARC's 14th and Teofilo Forero fronts. General Silva also disclosed that Colombian troops had captured the two guerrillas responsible for the kidnappings and murders. No group claimed responsibility for the kidnappings and murders.
target1: Colombian soldiers travelling between San Vincente del Caguan and Florencia
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The names of the victims were Oscar Mario Salazar Saavedra, Alfredo Chivaco Murcia, Juan de la Cruz Cardona Cumaco, Darwin Polania Bastidas, John Jairo Bautista Puentes, Carlos Artunduaga Fierro, Jose Maria Calderon Rodriquez, Milton Correa Torres, and Freddy Devia Meneses.
scite1: “May 1, FARC Kidnapping, FARC Reportedly Murder Nine Soldiers in Captivity,” Radio Cadena Nacional, May 12, 2002

summary: 05/02/2002: Suspected members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)threw a gas cylinder mortar bomb at a church in Bojaya, Colombia. The force of the explosion destroyed the church and nearby mud huts. 119 people were killed and another 80 were injured in the explosion. The church bombing appeared to be a mistaken target as the FARC was battling paramilitary forces in the region for several days prior to the incident. The Colombian government blamed the FARC, but the United Nations also held paramilitary forces and the Government of Colombia responsible for the incident along with the FARC.
target1: A Church in the town of Bojaya
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bomb was described as a gas cylinder mortar bomb. One source claimed it was an Ulster-style bomb that FARC acquired from the Irish Republican Army.
propcomment: The church and near by huts were said to be destroyed
addnotes: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) and the Colombian paramilitary forces, one source called them the Peasant Self-Defense Groups of Cordoba and Uraba, were reportedly fighting in the Choco Department region since April 29, 2002. The incident appeared to have been a mistaken bombing by the FARC. The FARC made statements that they did not mean to hit the church and claimed to just be fighting the paramilitary forces.
scite1: “UN Report Blames FARC, AUC, Colombian Government for Bojaya Massacre,” El Tiempo, May 21, 2002.
scite2: “Colombia: Death Toll Reaches 100 in FARC-Paramilitary Clashes,” El Tiempo, May 3, 2002.
scite3: “Colombia Shoots Down Copter That Aided Paramilitary Fighters,” The New York Times, May 7, 2002.

summary: 05/02/2002: Suspected members of the National Liberation Army (NLA) blocked automobile traffic on the Molino Viejo Bridge in Barbosa, Colombia. The group then burned two buses and a tractor-trailer. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
target2: Civilians riding in two buses and the owner of a tractor trailer
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The sources state that the perpetrators blocked the bridge and then burned the 3 vehicles.
propcomment: 2 buses, 1 tractor-trailer burned
scite1: “Colombia: Death Toll Reaches 100 in FARC-Paramilitary Clashes,” El Tiempo, May 3, 2002.
scite2: “FARC-Paramilitary Confrontations Leave 60 Wounded in Choco,” El Tiempo, May 3, 2002.
scite3: “Highlights: Colombian Guerrilla/Paramilitary Activities,” Caracol Colombia Radio, May 2, 2002.

location: On the El Cerrejon Railroad between the El Cerrejon mine and Puerto Bolivar
summary: 05/02/2002: The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)used dynamite to bomb a train, derailing 14 cars transporting 5,000 tons of coal, on the El Cerrejon Railroad in Guajira Department, Colombia. The train that was attacked was formerly owned by the US firm Exxon Mobil, but at the time of the incident was owned by the CZN consortium formed by BHP Billiton of Australia and Glencore International of Switzerland. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
corp1: BHP Billiton of Australia and Glencore Interantional of Switzerland
target1: A Train owned and operated by BHP Billiton of Australia and Glencore Interantional of Switzerland
target2: Railroad tracks connecting El Cerrejon mine and Puerto Bolivar
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Dynamite was used
propcomment: 14 train cars were derailed that contained 5,000 tons of coal

scite2: “FARC-Paramilitary Confrontations Leave 60 Wounded in Choco,” El Tiempo, May 3, 2002.
scite3: “Highlights: Colombian Guerrilla/Paramilitary Activities,” Caracol Colombia Radio, May 2, 2002.

location: The Guasimillas bridge was between the municipalities of Hobo and Gigante
summary: 05/07/2002: The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)’s (FARC) Teofilo Forero Column destroyed the Guasimillas Bridge with dynamite between the municipalities of Hobo and Gigante in Colombia’s Huila Department. The incident marked the second time in 45 days that FARC had destroyed the bridge. No casualties resulted from the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Guasimillas Bridge located between Hobo and Gigante
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Dynamite was used in the explosive device.
propcomment: The Guasimillas Bridge was destroyed.
addnotes: The attack left Huila Department cut off from the Caqueta, Cauca, and Putumayo Departments.
scite1: “Colombia: FARC Dynamite Attack Destroys Bridge in Huila Department,” Caracol Television, May 7, 2002.

summary: 05/08/2002: Three suspected members of Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)murdered a ranch worker, Rafael Enrique Menco, in Magangue, Colombia. FARC members were raiding the Bellavista Ranch where Menco was employed. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Bellavist Ranch worker Rafael Enrique Menco
motive: FARC rebels murdered the ranch worker to intimidate workers in the region not to work for two ranches in the region.
addnotes: The attackers were reportedly members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)'s (FARC) 37th Front.
scite1: “Highlights: Colombian Guerrilla/Paramilitary Activities 10 May 02,” El Universal, May 10, 2002.

location: The El Tacare bridge that joins Casanare and Arauca Departments.
summary: 05/08/2002: A truck bomb destroyed the El Tacare Bridge that joins Casanare and Arauca Departments in Colombia. There was no claim of responsibility, but local authorities suspected that the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)was behind the attack.
target1: The El Tacare Bridge located between the Casanare and Arauca Departments
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A truck bomb was used in the attack.
propcomment: The El Tacare Bridge was destroyed.
scite1: “Highlights: Colombian Guerrilla/Paramilitary Activities 10 May 02,” Caracol Colombia Radio, May 10, 2002.

summary: 05/08/2002: Three Colombian soldiers, Oscar Hernan Patino Bustamante, Orlando Campos Munoz, and Nefer Hernandez Serrano, were killed by explosive devices while they were searching for members of Front of the Popular Liberation Army (EPL) who were believed to have been operating in and around Teorama, Colombia. Another soldier, Jairo Cruz Pena, was injured in the attacks as well. The perpetrators detonated the explosive charges as the platoon was passing through. No group claimed responsibility for the attacks.
target1: Colombian soldiers, Oscar Hernan Patino Bustamante, Orlando Campos Munoz, Nefer Hernandez Serrano and Jairo Cruz Pena
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The attackers used booby trapped land mines.
scite1: “Highlights: Colombian Guerrilla/Paramilitary Activities 10 May 02,” La Vanguardia Liberal, May 10, 2002.

summary: 05/09/2002: The Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)’s (FARC) 25th Front reportedly shot and killed two policemen and wounded a three year old girl in Icononzo municipality, Colombia. No group claimed responsibility for the shootings.
target1: Two policemen stationed in Icononzo municipality
target2: A three year old girl in Icononzo municipality
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Highlights: Colombian Guerrilla/Paramilitary Activities 10 May 02,” Caracol Colombia Radio, May 10, 2002.

summary: 05/10/2002: Suspected members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)kidnapped, then executed former mayoral candidate Eliseo Acevedo in San Pablo, Colombia. The perpetrators, dressed in Colombian military uniforms, shot Acevedo, an Uribista, 18 times. No group claimed responsibility for the attacks, but local authorities believed the attack was part of a larger FARC operation to kill several anit-demilitarization leaders in the region.
target1: Eliseo Acevedo, a former San Pablo mayoral candidate
motive: The killing was to stop politicians in the Bolivar Department from supporting demilitarization of the region.
weapdetail: Acevedo was found with 18 bullet wounds on his body.
scite1: “May 10 FARC Colombia: FARC Reportedly Behind Killing of Anti-DMZ Leader,” El Espectador, May 13, 2002.

location: A road in northern Colombia
summary: 05/11/2002: Suspected members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)abducted Ramon Arizmendi Garmendia, a Spanish national, on a road in northern Colombia. He was released on May 26, 2002. No group claimed responsibility for the kidnapping.
target1: Ramon Arizmendi Garmendia, a Spanish national in Colombia
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Spaniard kidnapped by guerrillas in Colombia is released,” El Mundo, May 28, 2002.

summary: 05/14/2002: Members of The Popular Liberation Army (EPL) were suspected to have murdered a professional soldier on leave, Luis Alirio Tapasco Manzo, and injured his brother in Naranjal, Colombia. No group claimed responsibility for the murder.
target1: Professional soldier, Luis AlirioTapasco Manzo, and his brother
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Highlights: Colombian Guerrilla/Paramilitary Activities 15 May 02,” Pereira El Diario del Otun, May 15, 2002.

location: On Armenia-Cali Highway near Calarca, Colombia.
summary: 05/14/2002: Ten members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)reportedly installed a roadblock, stopped a bus and forced everyone to get out of the vehicle on the Armenia-Cali Highway near Calarca municipality in Quindio, Colombia. The perpetrators then dynamited the bus, partially destroying the vehicle. The Colombian Army’s 8th Brigade soon came onto the scene and pursued the perpetrators, killing one of them. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: A bus traveling on the Armenia-Cali highway near Calarca
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Two explosive devices composed of dynamite were used.
propcomment: A passenger bus was partially destroyed.
scite1: “Colombia: FARC Dynamites Bus, Army Foils Kidnapping Attempt,” Caracol Television, May 14, 2002.
scite2: “Highlights: Colombian Guerrilla/Paramilitary Activities 15 May 02,” Caracol Television, May 15, 2002.

summary: 05/14/2002:  The Colombian army was attacked by gas cylinders containing an unknown chemical agent in Los Farrallones, Colombia.  Four soldiers were injured in the attack.
target1: Colombian army in Los Farrallones, Colombia.
motive: Unknown.
weapdetail: Unknown chemical agent.
scite1: “Army Claims FARC Using Chemical Weapons,” El Espectador, May 15, 2002.
scite2: “Colombia: Army Accuses FARC of Using Unspecified Cheimcal Weapons,” BBC Monitoring Latin America-Political, May 15, 2002.
scite3: “Colombia-Conflict Colombian Army Accuses Rebels of Using Chemical Weapons,” EFE News Service, May 14, 2002.

summary: 05/15/2002: In an action that reportedly involved both members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)and the Army of National Liberation (ELN), four gas cylinder bombs were launched at a police station in Cocorna, Colombia. Two of the four bombs landed in the “park” and one police officer and one passerby were injured. Neither group claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Four gas cylinder bombs were launched at the police station.
scite1: “Highlights: Colombian Guerrilla/Paramilitary Activities 17 May 02,” El Espectador, May 17, 2002.

location: On a highway from Medellin to the Coast, at Ventanas.
summary: 05/15/2002: Members of the Army of National Liberation (ELN) established a roadblock on the highway from Medellin to the Coast, at Ventanas. The perpetrators set a bus on fire during the attack.
target1: Highway from Medellin to the Coast
target2: A bus on a highway from Medellin to the Coast, at Ventanas
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bus was incinerated
propcomment: One bus was destroyed.
scite1: “Highlights: Colombian Guerrilla/Paramilitary Activities 17 May 02,” El Espectador, May 17, 2002.

summary: 05/15/2002: A group of heavily men who identified themselves as members of the People's Revolutionary Army (ERP) abducted Ever Miguel Jimenez Ruz from his ranch in Hato Nuevo in Sucre Department.
target1: Rancher owner, Ever Miguel Jimenez Ruz
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Highlights: Colombia Regional Press 17 May 02,” El Universal, May 17, 2002.

summary: 05/19/2002: A bomb exploded in front of the main gate of the headquarters of Colombian presidential candidate Alvaro Uribe in Valledupar, Colombia. The office and some nearby homes were damaged, however there were no casualties. A second bomb was also found and safely defused. Authorities suspected the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) in this attack.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The second bomb, which was defused, was a cooking gas tank full of dynamite.
propcomment: The explosion damaged the headquarters and several nearby homes and left part of the sector without power for several hours.
scite1: “Colombia: Bomb Goes Off in Leading Candidate Uribe's Quarters in Valledupar," Notimex, May 19, 2002.
scite2: Jared Kotler, “Colombian Candidate Cancels Event," The Associated Press, May 19, 2002.
scite3: “Explosion reported outside Colombian leading presidential candidate Uribe's HQ," Notimex, May 19, 2002.

summary: 05/20/2002: Rebels with the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) set off a car bomb on the La Pintada Bridge in the Antioquia Department, Colombia. No one was hurt, but the blast damaged fiber optics hardware and interrupted internet service for the entire country.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Car Bomb Explosion in Antioquia Disrupts Internet Service Nationwide,” El Tiempo, May 21, 2002.

location: The incident occurred between the towns of La Guajira and Cesar.
summary: 05/23/2002: The National Liberation Army (NLA) destroyed a bridge connecting the towns of La Guajira and Cesar in northern Colombia. Five people were seriously hurt and power lines were damaged by the explosion.
target1: Bridge connecting La Guajira and Cesar
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Car Bomb Destroys Bridge Linking La Guajira, Cesar,” Caracol Television, May 23, 2002.
scite2: “Colombians gather at polls to elect a new president,” The Star Phoenix, May 27, 2002.

location: 40 kilometers from Florencia
summary: 5/25/2002: Twelve men abducted Arnulfo Silva Cabrera, the mayor of Montanitas, and his driver, Camilo Hernan Rojas, near Montanitas, Caquetá Department, Colombia.  Their dead bodies were found in the area later the same day.  Silva had only recently become mayor and had since reported receiving threats from paramilitary groups.  Authorities suspect United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC) are responsible for the incident.  Specific motive is unknown.
target1: Arnulfo Silva Cabrera, the mayor of Montanitas
target2: Camilo Hernan Rojas, the mayor's driver
gname: United Self Defense Units of Colombia (AUC)
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the mayor had reported receiving threats from paramilitary groups operating in the area; it used to be a neutral zone between rebels and the government but was recently reclaimed by the government and military
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
addnotes: One source states that Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) was suspected in connection with the incident.
scite1: "Mayor killed by paramilitaries in Colombia," EFE News Service, May 25, 2002.
scite2: Phil Stewart, "Colombians brace for election tainted by violence," Reuters News, May 25, 2002.
scite3: "Montanita Mayor Kidnapped - murdered," Bogota Radio Cadena Nacional, May 27, 2002.

summary: 05/28/2002: Rebels with the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) used gas tanks to attack a police station in Cali, Colombia, injuring no one.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Authorities Order Militarization of Cali Over FARC Attack,” Caracol Television, May 28, 2002.
scite2: “One killed, 3 hurt in roadblock near Bogota; 5 more injured in car bombing,” Miami Herald, May 29, 2002.

summary: 05/28/2002: A car bomb explosion just north of Bogota, Colombia, injured five citizens in a busy commercial area. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Car Bomb Goes Off in Bogota; 5 Injured,” Caracol Television, May 28, 2002.
scite2: “One killed, 3 hurt in roadblock near Bogota; 5 more injured in car bombing,” Miami Herald, May 29, 2002.

summary: 05/30/2002: Perpetrators were unsuccessful in an attempt to destroy a bus carrying the Mayor of Medellin, Luis Perez Gutierrez, in Medellin, Colombia. Authorities believed that the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) perpetrated the attack.

weapdetail: An explosive device consisting of 30-40kg of dynamite, was used in the attack

motive: Unknown

location: The Valledupar-Bosconia road in Cesar Department
summary: 3/5/2002: Members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) set up a roadblock in Cesar Department, Colombia. The assailants burned several vehicles, stole a trailer truck full of food, and kidnapped nine people.  The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown.

motive: Unknown

summary: 5/31/2002: Members of National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN) kidnapped three men in La Union, Antioquia Department, Colombia.  The motive behind the kidnapping is unknown.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made
addnotes: The motive behind the kidnapping is unknown.  It may have been financially motivated.

summary: 4/6/2002: Suspected members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) entered a village church and shot and killed the priest who was conducting Mass in La Argentina, Huila Department, Colombia. summary: 06/06/2002: The mayor of the Colombian town of Solita, Luis Carlos Caro Pacheco, was killed. Local officials have pinned the murder on the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) (FARC).
target1: Mayor of the town of Solita
motive: Unknown

summary: 06/06/2002: An explosion killed one and wounded 10 in a restaurant bathroom in Bogota. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack and authorities believe the bombing was the end result of failed extortion.

motive: Unknown

scite2: “Explosive Device Goes Off in Northern Bogota; One Dead, 10 Injured,” Caracol News, June 7, 2002.

summary: 06/14/2002: Rebels with the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)shot down a helicopter carrying 360 million pesos to the Agrarian Bank in Topaipi. Five policemen were killed and three have gone missing.

location: Between Cienaga and Port Papare in northern Colombia
summary: 06/17/2002: A dynamite attack damaged the multinational Drummond railway system in between the Cienaga and Papare terminals. Officials believe the 19th Front of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)were responsible.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The explosion destroyed four meters of the railroad, 10 crossties, and 10 pairs of railroad clips.
addnotes: Authorities assert the attack was retaliatory in nature as Drummond had failed to pay prior extortion demands.
scite1: Tony Perez Mier, “Dynamite Explosion Damages Drummond Railway,” El Tiempo, June 18, 2002.
scite2: “Rebels attack Drummond railroad,” Business News Americas, June 18, 2002.

summary: 6/16/2002: Approximately 80 members of National Liberation Army of Colombia (ELN) attacked an equestrian fair in Narino Department, Colombia.  The assailants surrounded the fair and took at least ten people hostage.  One of the hostages was former deputy minister Alberto Benavides.  The captives were taken into the mountains and the outcome of the kidnapping is unknown.
target1: Civilians at an equestrian fair, including former deputy minister Alberto Benavides
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Pastrana's security chief resigns, president-elect seeks UN mediation," Agence France Presse, June 18, 2002.
scite2: "Colombian guerrillas kidnap 10, including former agriculture vice minister," AFX European Focus, June 18, 2002.

summary: 06/24/2002: Armed assailants attacked city hall in Rio de Janeiro causing damage to the outside of the building. Two grenades left behind had to be detonated by the Rio bomb squad.
target1: City Hall in Rio de Janeiro
motive: Unknown
propcomment: Windows were broken causing minor material damage
scite1: “Rio de Janeiro city hall attacked by armed assailants,” Agence France Presse, June 25, 2002.

summary: 06/26/2002: Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC)rebels kidnapped the mayor of the town of La Sierra.
target1: The Mayor of the Town of La Sierra

motive: Unknown

summary: 07/01/2002: The owner of a radio station, who had recently criticized paramilitary fighters, was shot and killed by gunmen in Bogota, Colombia. The United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia, the target of the owner's criticism, were suspected of the attack.

location: This attack occurred in an unspecified location in Cauca.
summary: 07/02/2002: One soldier was killed and two wounded when a communications tower was bombed by Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) in Cauca, Colombia.
motive: The specific motive was to disrupt communications between the center and Pacific coast of Colombia
addnotes: Original source cited by Colombia Guerilla/Paramilitary Highlights was Bogota Caracol Television.
scite1: "Highlights: Columbian Guerilla/Paramilitary Activities," Colombia Guerilla/Paramilitary Activities, July 02, 2002.

summary: 07/11/2002: Two policemen and a civilian were killed when Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) militants attacked a police station in Maitos, Colombia.

propcomment: There were unofficial reports that the police station and several homes were burned.

scite2: "Highlights: Colombian Guerilla/Paramilitary Activities 11 Jul 02," Colombia Guerilla/Paramilitary Highlights, July 11, 2002.

summary: 7/18/2002: Members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) kidnapped the three-year-old daughter of Libardo Erazo, the mayor of Colon, Putumayo Department, Colombia.  FARC had issued threats to Colombian mayors that they would be targeted if they did not resign.  Erazo resigned following the abduction, but it is not known whether his daughter was released.
target1: Libardo Erazo, the mayor of Colon
target2: The three-year-old daughter of the mayor of Colon
motive: FARC issued statements threatening to target Colombian mayors if they did not resign

location: Dolores, 150 kilometers southwest of Bogota
summary: 7/17/2002: Members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) attacked the town of Dolores, Tolima Department, Colombia.  The rebels fought with the police for hours; at least four rebels and four civilians were killed in the violent exchange and at least three children were injured.  In addition, numerous buildings were destroyed, including private homes, city hall, businesses, and the civic center.
target1: Civilians and private homes in Dolores
target3: Small and large business buildings in Dolores
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Gas cylinder bombs, grenades, and firearms
propcomment: Numerous buildings were destroyed
addnotes: One source states that four rebels and four civilians were killed, while three children were injured; however, another source states that eight civilians and two policemen were injured and does not mention any fatalities.
scite1: "Rebel attack on Colombian town kills four civilians, four rebels," Associated Press, July 18, 2002.
scite2: "Caracol News," Caracol Television, July 18, 2002.
scite3: "Dolores Destroyed in Recent Attack," Bogota Caracol News, July 19, 2002.

summary: 07/18/2002: Three people were killed and sixteen injured by an explosion in Cartagena, Colombia. No group claimed responsibility.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: An explosive device consisting of 30kg of ammonal, was used in the attack
propcomment: One house was completely destroyed, and others were moderately damaged.
scite1: "Colombia: Explosion Kills 3, Injures 16 in Cartagena," Caracol Television, July 18, 2002.
scite2: "Highlights: Colombian Guerilla/Paramilitary Activities 18 Jul 02," Colombia Guerilla/Paramilitary Highlights, July 18, 2002.

location: 530 kilometers from Bogota
summary: 7/20/2002: A horse laden with explosives detonated in Guadalupe, Antioquia Department, Colombia.  Suspected members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) sent a horse loaded with dynamite towards the police station; it detonated prematurely and destroyed a private home, as well as damaging several businesses and the police station.  At least eight people were injured in the explosion; however, there were no reports of fatalities.  Specific motive is unknown.
target1: The police station and local police officers in Guadalupe
target2: Civilians and civilian homes in the vicinity of the police station
target3: Local businesses in the vicinity of the police station
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: 25-30 kilograms of dynamite
propcomment: Private and public buildings were destroyed and damaged in the explosion
addnotes: Only one source mentions injured victims.

scite2: "Horse bomb injures 8 in Colombia," The New Zealand Herald, July 21, 2002.
scite3: "Horse-Bomb Heavily Damages Police Station in Guadalupe," Bogota Caracol Radio, July 20, 2002.

summary: 07/23/2002: Two people were killed and thirteen injured by an explosion at a café in Medellin, Colombia. An ex-congressman was among the dead. No group claimed responsibility.

motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The bomb was "regular-strength" and thrown from a moving vehicle.

scite2: "Colombia: Explosion in Medellin Café Kills Ex-Congressman, Injures 6 People," El Tiempo, July 23, 2002.

location: Near the bull ring
summary: 7/24/2002: A bomb hidden in a car exploded near the bull ring in San Juan de Rioseco, Cundinamarca Department, Colombia.  The vehicle had been parked at the bull ring since dawn; when police went to investigate it, it exploded, killing three police officers and injuring at least six others, including both police and civilians.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident but authorities suspect that Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) was involved.  Specific motive is unknown.
target1: Police who were investigating the suspicious car at the bull ring
target2: Civilians in the vicinity of the bull ring
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: An explosive device hidden in a car and possibly detonated with a remote control
